summary:
assistant

This clinical trial aims to investigate the psychological factors associated with nociplastic pain (NP) in women with chronic migraine, fibromyalgia, and vulvodynia. The study will use a cluster analysis approach to identify specific psychological factors, including personality traits, defense mechanisms, central sensitization, and childhood traumatic experiences, that are associated with each condition. The study will also assess the presence and intensity of psychological symptoms of depression, anxiety, and psychosomatics, as well as physical and psychological quality of life, alexithymic traits, perceived social support, sexual satisfaction, and genital pain.

The study will recruit 150 women with a diagnosis of fibromyalgia, 150 women with a diagnosis of chronic migraine, 150 women with a diagnosis of vulvodynia, and 150 healthy controls. Participants will complete a protocol of self-report questionnaires, including measures of central sensitivity, traumatic experiences, personality traits, defense mechanisms, mental pain, environmental sensitivity, and other psychological and physical symptoms. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, combining both quantitative and qualitative data.

The primary outcome measures will include the Central Sensitivity Index, Traumatic Experiences Index, Personality Traits, Defense Mechanisms, Mental Pain, and Environmental Sensitivity. The secondary outcome measures will include the presence and intensity of psychological symptoms of depression, anxiety, and psychosomatics, as well as physical and psychological quality of life, alexithymic traits, perceived social support, sexual satisfaction, and genital pain.

The study aims to identify specific psychological factors that are associated with each condition and to provide a better understanding of the complex relationships between psychological and physical symptoms in women with chronic pain. The study will also provide insights into the development of tailored interventions for each condition, taking into account the unique psychological and physical characteristics of each patient.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

This randomized, parallel-group trial compares the effectiveness of two mattresses with different support surfaces in preventing pressure ulcers in bedridden patients. Patients with a low risk of pressure ulcers, as determined by the Braden Scale, were randomly assigned to either a group using a massage mattress with a cube/block system or a standard of care mattress. The primary outcome measure was the number of patients without pressure ulcers, which was assessed daily for four weeks. The study aimed to determine whether the massage mattress with a cube/block system is more effective in preventing pressure ulcers than the standard of care mattress.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: The Effect of Exercise with Augmented Reality Glasses on Metabolic Parameters, Anthropometric Measurement Values, and Quality of Life in Children Aged 10-12 with Type 1 Diabetes

Objective: To investigate the effect of exercise with augmented reality glasses on metabolic parameters, anthropometric measurement values, and quality of life in children aged 10-12 with Type 1 Diabetes.

Methodology: This randomized controlled trial will enroll 10-12 year old children with Type 1 Diabetes and randomly assign them to either an experimental group receiving exercise with augmented reality glasses or a control group with no intervention. The experimental group will perform moderate exercise with AR glasses for 60 minutes, twice a week, for 12 weeks. Primary outcomes will be changes in HbA1c levels, body mass index, and quality of life measured using the PedsQL 3.0 scale.

Population: Children aged 10-12 with Type 1 Diabetes, diagnosed at least 6 months prior, without other chronic diseases or psychiatric diagnoses, and able to read and write in Turkish.

Expected outcomes: The study aims to demonstrate the effectiveness of exercise with augmented reality glasses in improving metabolic control, anthropometric measurement values, and quality of life in children with Type 1 Diabetes.

assistant

The study aims to evaluate the effect of virtual reality on preoperative anxiety in patients undergoing abdominal surgery. The study will recruit 96 patients, aged 18-70 years, who will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: an experimental group using virtual reality glasses, a placebo group watching a video without virtual reality glasses, and a control group receiving anxiety control by a researcher. The primary outcome measures will be the preoperative anxiety level, measured using a smart wristband and the Visual Anxiety Scale (VAS-A) before and after watching a video. The study will use a parallel assignment design, with no masking, and will collect data using a patient information form, VAS-A, and a smart wristband with stress level measurement feature. The study is expected to provide insights into the effect of virtual reality on anxiety management before abdominal surgery.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Clinical Performance and Safety of Suture-TOOL for Abdominal Wound Closure

Objective: To evaluate the clinical performance and safety of Suture-TOOL, a device for fast and standardized closure of the abdominal fascia, in patients undergoing elective open abdominal surgery.

Eligibility: Male and female patients aged 18 years or older, with a body mass index (BMI) between 18-40 kg/m2, undergoing elective open abdominal surgery for benign or malignant colorectal disease through a midline incision.

Intervention: Suture-TOOL will be used to close the abdomen after laparotomy.

Primary Outcome Measure: Proportion of patients with a Suture length/Wound length (SL/WL) ratio ≥ 4.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Stitch count, number of sutures used, incision closure time, surgeons' comfort with the device, and surgeons' satisfaction with the final closure result.

The study is a single-arm, open-label, prospective interventional study with a primary purpose of prevention.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Immune Biomarker Study for Salivary Gland Carcinoma

Objective: To investigate the immune biomarkers in patients with primary salivary gland carcinoma and benign salivary gland tumors, as well as healthy controls, to better understand the immune characteristics and potential biomarkers for diagnosis and treatment.

Design: This is an observational study with three groups: patients with primary salivary gland carcinoma, patients with benign salivary gland tumors, and healthy controls. Participants will undergo sampling of stool, saliva, and blood samples to evaluate immune characteristics.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Changes in an established immune matrix (intratumoral and systemic)
* Longitudinal immunophenotyping of patients
* Analysis of cytokines in peripheral blood
* Analysis of patient's metabolic state
* Analysis of patient's microbiomic state

The study aims to identify potential biomarkers for diagnosis and treatment of salivary gland carcinoma and to understand the immune characteristics of patients with benign and malignant salivary gland tumors. The study will enroll patients aged 18 years or older and will follow them for up to 5 years.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between compliance with the Mediterranean diet, physical activity habits, walking-related problems, and quality of life in patients with Multiple Sclerosis (MS). The study will enroll patients aged 18-65 with a diagnosis of MS and assess their diet, physical activity, and quality of life using various scales and questionnaires. The primary outcome measures include Mediterranean diet compliance status, quality of life, impacts on walking, and expanded disability status scale. The study will evaluate whether there is a significant relationship between these parameters and explore the potential benefits of the Mediterranean diet on MS symptoms and quality of life.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

The SIIT-CD Study is a multicenter, prospective, randomized, controlled trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of selective intensive induction therapy based on ustekinumab clinical decision-making tools (UST-CDST) in patients with Crohn's Disease (CD). The study aims to compare the clinical response rate at week 24 between the experimental group receiving selective intensive induction therapy and the control group receiving non-intensive induction therapy. Eligible patients must be between 18-75 years old, have active CD, and have moderate to low responsive activity according to UST-CDST scores. The experimental group will receive ustekinumab induction therapy intravenously or subcutaneously at weeks 0, 8, and 16, while the control group will not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measure is the difference in clinical response rate at week 24 between the two groups.

This clinical trial, "The Preference of a Culturally and Linguistic Diverse (CALD) Population for Second Line OAB Therapy: a Discrete Choice Experiment", aims to understand the preferences of a diverse patient population with overactive bladder (OAB) for second-line treatments. The study includes adult patients with OAB who have not received sacral neuromodulation (SNM) or onabotulinum toxin A (Botox) in the past. Participants will fill out a questionnaire to choose between two fictive therapies, each with its own characteristics, to measure their preferences. The primary outcome measure is the discrete choice questionnaire, which will be completed within 1 hour.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

**Title:** Three-arm Pragmatic Randomized Study on the Effectiveness, Feasibility, Acceptability, and Cost of the Use of Continuous Glucose Monitoring Devices Among People Living With Type 1 Diabetes in South Africa

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness, feasibility, acceptability, and cost of using continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) devices among people living with type 1 diabetes in South Africa.

**Design:** A three-arm pragmatic randomized controlled trial with 15-month duration. Participants will be randomized to one of three arms: continuous use of CGM, intermittent use of CGM, or standard of care (self-monitoring of blood glucose).

**Population:** People living with type 1 diabetes aged 4 years and above, as well as their caregivers and healthcare providers.

**Interventions:** Continuous use of CGM for 9 months, intermittent use of CGM for 4 time points over 9 months, or standard of care (self-monitoring of blood glucose) for 9 months.

**Outcomes:** Primary outcome is the impact of CGM use on blood glucose levels, measured by HbA1c levels. Secondary outcomes include variability of blood glucose concentrations, unplanned visits to outpatient clinics and/or hospital, quality of life, acceptability and feasibility of CGM use, and cost of CGM use.

**Methodology:** Participants will undergo 6 study visits over 15 months. Blood glucose levels will be measured at each visit, and participants will complete surveys and participate in focus group discussions. Healthcare providers will also participate in semi-structured interviews.

**Expected Duration of Study Participation:** 15 months.

**Expected Number of Participants:** Not specified.

**Inclusion Criteria:** People living with type 1 diabetes with HbA1c levels ≥10% within the last 3 months, caregivers to children/adolescents living with type 1 diabetes, and healthcare providers engaged in diabetes care provision.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Fractionated Stereotactic Ablative Body Radiotherapy (SBRT) With Focal Dose Escalation on Dominant Lesion in Localized Prostate Cancer

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of SBRT with focal dose escalation on dominant lesion (DIL) in localized prostate cancer.

Eligibility: Men with histologically confirmed prostate adenocarcinoma, primary localized disease, intermediate or high-risk disease, and T2-T3a clinical stage with visible DIL on mpMRI.

Intervention: SBRT with focal boost to the DIL, delivered in 5 fractions of 7.25 Gy to the entire prostate and 50 Gy to the DIL, with partial protection of the prostatic urethra and bladder trigone.

Primary Outcome Measures: Biochemical progression-free survival (PSA nadir +2 ng/ml) at 3 years and local control (disappearance of suspicious image on mpMRI) at 12 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Incidence and severity of acute and late urinary and rectal treatment-related adverse events, patient-reported outcomes and quality of life assessment using EPIC-26 short form and IPSS at 2 years.

This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of SBRT with focal dose escalation on DIL in localized prostate cancer, with a focus on biochemical progression-free survival, local control, and patient-reported outcomes.

The SMILER study is a clinical trial investigating the effectiveness of a serious game (SG) as an e-health intervention for young people with neurologic or respiratory disorders, specifically asthma in children. The study aims to evaluate the impact of SG on the quality of life and skills of children with controlled asthma.

Eligible participants are children aged 12-17 years with controlled asthma, who are not experiencing flare-ups or using oral corticosteroids, leukotriene receptor antagonists, or therapy. Exclusion criteria include respiratory infections, immunological, metabolic, cardiac, or neurological diseases, obesity, preterm birth, major malformations of the respiratory system, active smoking, and pregnancy.

The study consists of two arms: Group 1, which receives the SG intervention to support their asthma treatment plan, and Group 2, which follows the standard treatment plan without SG. The SG is a running game that tracks the child's movements using an Azure's Kinect sensor and adapts to their specific motor skills.

The primary outcome measures include the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) and the Skills and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ-Ita), which will be assessed at 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include the Conserved Transcriptional Response to Adversity (CTRA) also assessed at 6 months.

assistant

The study "Cue Effects in Human Addiction: Pavlovian to Instrumental Transfer" aims to investigate the effects of acute and chronic stress on Pavlovian to Instrumental Transfer (PIT) in individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD) and healthy controls. The study consists of three experiments, each with a different design and outcome measures.

Experiment 1 assesses the effects of acute and chronic stress on PIT effects in AUD subjects and healthy controls using a behavioral and neural level. The study also examines the relationship between PIT effects and cognitive control abilities.

Experiment 2 uses a 2x3 factorial design to investigate the effects of smoking status and AUD on PIT effects. The study also examines the relationship between PIT effects and other continuous measures, such as alcohol use disorders identification test (AUDIT) scores and quantity-frequency indices.

Experiment 3 uses a full PIT paradigm to investigate the effects of general and outcome-specific PIT on instrumental behavior. The study also examines the relationship between PIT effects and chronic stress levels.

The primary outcome measures include neural PIT effects, behavioral PIT effects, and chronic stress effects on hair cortisol levels. The secondary outcome measures include saliva cortisol concentration, alcohol consumption after 12 months, and cognitive control interference effects.

The study's objectives are to:

1. Assess the effects of acute and chronic stress on PIT effects in AUD subjects and healthy controls.
2. Investigate the relationship between PIT effects and cognitive control abilities.
3. Examine the effects of smoking status and AUD on PIT effects.
4. Investigate the relationship between PIT effects and chronic stress levels.
5. Examine the effects of general and outcome-specific PIT on instrumental behavior.

The study's participants will include individuals with AUD and healthy controls, with a total of 210 participants. The study will use a variety of assessment tools, including behavioral and neural level measures, surveys and questionnaires, and neuroimaging techniques.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Flow and Grow - The Ideal Time to Wean CPAP Off In Extremely Low Birth Weight Infants

Objective: To investigate the effectiveness of a standardized CPAP weaning protocol in reducing the failure rate of CPAP weaning in extremely low birth weight infants.

Design: Multicenter, randomized controlled trial involving 130 premature neonates born between 23 0/7 and 29 6/7 weeks gestational age.

Intervention: Infants in the treatment group will receive a standardized CPAP weaning protocol, while those in the control group will undergo weaning based on unit-specific practices. The standardized protocol will be implemented for all infants in the treatment group until either 32 or 34 weeks gestational age, depending on their gestational age at birth.

Primary Outcome Measure: The number of participants with CPAP/NIS weaning failure, defined as needing more support and/or increased sleep stimulation events after weaning off CPAP/NIS.

Secondary Outcome Measures: The study will also assess various secondary outcomes, including the number of stimulation events per 24 hours, length of hospital stay, rate of bronchopulmonary dysplasia, use of postnatal steroids, and more.

Eligibility Criteria: Infants born at less than 30 weeks gestational age, with informed parental consent obtained.

The study aims to determine the optimal time to wean CPAP off in extremely low birth weight infants, with the goal of reducing the failure rate of CPAP weaning and improving outcomes for these vulnerable infants.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Efficacy and Safety Study of Frexalimab (SAR441344) in Adults With Nonrelapsing Secondary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of frexalimab compared to placebo in adult patients with nonrelapsing secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS).

Design: Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled phase 3 study.

Eligibility: Patients with a previous diagnosis of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) and a current diagnosis of SPMS, with documented evidence of disability progression, and an Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score of 3.0 to 6.5 points.

Interventions: Patients will receive either frexalimab (SAR441344) or placebo via intravenous infusion, along with MRI contrast-enhancing agents.

Primary Outcome Measure: Time to onset of composite confirmed disability progression (cCDP) confirmed over 6 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Include time to onset of individual components of the composite, confirmed over 3- or 6-months, as well as various other measures of efficacy and safety, such as brain volume loss, cognitive function, and patient-reported outcomes.

Duration: The study will last for approximately 5 years, with patients being followed for up to 204 weeks.

The study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of frexalimab in patients with nonrelapsing SPMS, with a focus on delaying disability progression and improving patient outcomes.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Comparative Study Between Modified Millard and Mishra Technique in Unilateral Cleft Lip Repair: a Randomised Controlled Study

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of the modified Millard and Mishra techniques in repairing unilateral cleft lip in infants aged 2-6 months.

Design: Randomized controlled trial with three arms: control group, Mishra technique group, and modified Millard technique group.

Inclusion criteria: Infants with unilateral isolated cleft lip aged 2-6 months, with incomplete and complete unilateral cleft lip (reaching the floor of the nose).

Exclusion criteria: Infants less than 2 months or more than 6 months, bilateral cleft lip patients, recurrent repair cleft lip cases, facial cleft cases, and 5-Syndromic patients.

Primary outcome measures: Surgical repair unilateral cleft lip measurements, including vertical lip height, horizontal lip length, and philtral length, at 3 months post-operative.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Endoscopic Management of Controlled Colo-cutaneous Fistula as a Complication of Acute Sigmoid Diverticulitis: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of endoscopic management using the OTSC (Ovesco Endoscopy) clip system in closing colo-cutaneous fistulas as a complication of acute sigmoid diverticulitis, compared to surgical management.

Design: Randomized controlled trial with 66 patients divided into two groups: Endoscopic Group (EG) and Surgical Group (SG).

Intervention: Endoscopic management using the OTSC clip system in the EG, and sigmoid resection with primary anastomosis in the SG.

Primary Outcome Measure: Incidence of recurrence of fistula within one week after endoscopy.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Incidence of side effects of endoscopy within one month after surgery.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients with controlled colo-cutaneous fistula as a complication of acute sigmoid diverticulitis, recurrent fistula, and failed conservative measures, with good general condition (ASA I&II).

Exclusion Criteria: Patients with poor general condition (ASA III&IV&V), high output fistula, or those who respond to conservative measures.

The study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of endoscopic management using the OTSC clip system in closing colo-cutaneous fistulas, and to reduce morbidity and mortality.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

The "Multidisciplinary Approach for High Risk Patients Leading to Early Diagnosis of Canadians in Heart Failure" study aims to improve the screening of heart failure and identify patients at risk for heart failure earlier. The randomized, un-blinded study compares usual care to an intervention group receiving early heart failure testing. Participants with elevated NT-proBNP levels (>125pg/mL) will undergo a study visit with assessments including physical examination, electrocardiogram, and AI echocardiogram. The primary outcome measures include the number of participants diagnosed with heart failure, outpatient HF visits, urgent HF visits, and HF hospitalizations. The study aims to determine if early-screening and treatment can help prevent further decline in high-risk patients.

assistant

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of propofol dosing based on lean body weight (LBW) for anesthesia induction in patients with a body mass index (BMI) below 35. The study will enroll 80 patients aged 18-65 years who will undergo general anesthesia for 2-6 hours. Patients will have their height, weight, age, and other general information recorded, and their total body weight (TBW), ideal body weight (IBW), and LBW will be calculated. Propofol infusion will be started according to TBW, and the infusion will be stopped when the Bispectral Index (BIS) value is between 50 and 40. The total dose of propofol given will be calculated according to TBW, IBW, and LBW, and the relationship between the doses given and BMI will be evaluated. The primary outcome measure is the ratio of propofol dose with sufficient depth of anesthesia according to TBW and LBW.

assistant

This is an open-label, prospective cohort study evaluating the efficacy and tolerability of oral letermovir for cytomegalovirus (CMV) prophylaxis in heart and lung transplant recipients. The study compares subjects receiving letermovir with those who received standard valganciclovir prophylaxis in the two years prior to the study. The primary outcome measures are CMV viral load, proportion of days with appropriate renal dosing, and CMV syndrome or tissue invasive CMV disease. Secondary outcomes include frequency of acute cellular rejection, CMV resistance, neutropenia, severe thrombocytopenia, unplanned discontinuation of mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) or azathioprine, and incorrect renal dosing. The study will enroll 18 years and older, heart or lung transplant recipients who are CMV seropositive and have a functioning graft.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

The study aimed to develop and validate the PHYSIOSCORE, a tool to assess the complexity level and physical therapy care in hospitalized patients with heart and lung diseases. The study consisted of three phases: 

1. Questionnaire validation construct, where a committee of physical therapists developed and validated the PHYSIOSCORE based on variables used in clinical practice.
2. Concordance and interrater reliability, where 10 physical therapists assessed 110 patients with cardiac conditions to establish interrater agreement and reliability.
3. Clinical validation of the instrument, where 110 consecutive patients were selected to assess the level of attention and complexity of physical therapy care.

The study used a sequential assignment design and did not involve randomization. The primary outcome measures were respiratory and neuromuscular variables, including lung function, breath sounds, PaO2/FiO2, and muscle strength, tone, and postural control. The study aimed to establish the reliability and validity of the PHYSIOSCORE as a tool to assess physical therapy care in hospitalized patients.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Selective Adjuvant Therapy for HPV-mediated Oropharynx SCCs Based on Residual Circulating Tumor DNA Levels (SAVAL)

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of selective adjuvant therapy for HPV-mediated oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC) based on residual circulating tumor DNA levels.

Study Design: Single-arm phase II trial with a single experimental arm.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients with pathologically proven p16+ OPSCC, clinical stage T0-3, N0-N1, and M0 disease, and positive ctDNA levels prior to surgery.

Intervention: Patients will undergo observation only if they meet specific criteria, including pathological T1-3 N1-2 with negative surgical margins, absent or microscopic extracapsular extension, and negative post-operative ctDNA levels.

Primary Outcome Measure: Progression-free Survival (PFS) at 2 years post last treatment.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Rate of recurrence, rate of salvage, locoregional recurrence, overall survival, freedom from distant metastases, patient-reported outcomes, and quality of life.

The study aims to reduce acute and long-term side effects of treatment while maintaining excellent clinical outcomes for patients with HPV-mediated OPSCC.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

This is a single-institution, prospective, phase 2 trial comparing ultra-hypofractionated whole breast irradiation (WBI) with partial breast irradiation (PBI) in women with breast cancer who have undergone breast-conserving surgery. The trial aims to evaluate the acute and late toxicity of these two radiotherapy regimens, as well as their effects on local-regional control, disease-free survival, overall survival, distant metastasis occurrence, cosmetic outcome, and quality of life.

The trial includes 50-70 patients aged 50 or older with invasive ductal carcinoma, tumor size ≤ 3 cm, and R0 resection. Patients are randomized to receive either ultra-fractionated PBI (26Gy in 5 fractions) or ultra-fractionated WBI (26Gy in 5 fractions). The primary outcome measures are acute and late toxicity, assessed using the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) scale version 5.0. Secondary outcome measures include local-regional control, disease-free survival, overall survival, distant metastasis occurrence, cosmetic outcome, and quality of life, assessed using standardized questionnaires.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

This is a prospective, single-arm study evaluating the feasibility and preliminary outcomes of a digital health coaching program (DLC) for patients with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma (R/R MM). The study aims to explore the use of symptom monitoring and digital life coaching to inform a more complete understanding of the impact of multiple myeloma on symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and financial, physiologic, and psychosocial well-being.

The study will enroll 100 patients with R/R MM who will be assigned to a health advisor for digital health coaching and will receive a Fitbit device for activity tracking. Patients will complete patient-reported outcomes (PROs) at multiple time points to assess their status and explore relationships between medical management, health-related quality of life, and engagement in the program.

The primary outcome measure is the feasibility of the digital health coaching intervention, defined as a retention rate greater than or equal to 70% at 3 months following the start of the coaching intervention. Secondary outcome measures include changes in self-efficacy in coping with cancer and symptom burden.

The study will provide insight into the symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and financial, physiologic, and psychosocial well-being of patients with R/R MM and explore the potential of digital health coaching to augment existing standards of care for patient support.

assistant

This is a pilot study to explore the effect of a 4-week intervention with a dietary supplement containing dried chicory root (WholeFiberTM) on patients with mild to moderate Inflammatory Bowel Diseases (IBD), including Ulcerative Colitis (UC) and Crohn's Disease (CD). The study aims to investigate the effects of WholeFiberTM on fecal calprotectin, IBD complaints, quality of life, serum inflammatory markers, gut microbiota, and short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) levels.

The study will enroll 12 patients with IBD, divided into two groups of 6 patients with UC and 6 patients with CD. Participants will receive 10-20 grams of WholeFiberTM per day for 4 weeks, with measurements taken before and after the intervention. The primary outcome measure is the change in fecal calprotectin levels, while secondary outcomes include changes in IBD complaints, quality of life, and various biomarkers.

The study will also assess the feasibility and acceptance of the WholeFiberTM intervention in this population. The results of this pilot study will provide valuable information on the potential benefits and limitations of WholeFiberTM as a dietary supplement for patients with IBD.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Porcine Acellular Dermal Matrix for the Treatment of Localized Gingival Recessions: A Multicenter Randomized Clinical Trial

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of porcine acellular dermal matrix (PADM) in combination with a coronally advanced flap (CAF) for the treatment of localized gingival recessions.

Eligibility: Patients with localized gingival recessions with a height of 3-5mm and at least 2mm of keratinized tissue width are eligible. Exclusion criteria include smokers, pregnant or nursing women, patients with diabetes or other conditions that interfere with tissue repair.

Design: This is a randomized, parallel-group, quadruple-masked clinical trial. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either CAF alone or CAF combined with PADM.

Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measure is recession reduction, evaluated at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include the thickness of keratinized tissue, also evaluated at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months.

The study aims to assess the efficacy and safety of PADM in combination with CAF for the treatment of localized gingival recessions.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

This longitudinal crossover clinical trial aims to compare the effects of physical exercise performed through virtual reality games (VR) and conventional physical exercise (SB) on heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients undergoing hemodialysis. The study consists of two groups: Group A, which performs VR exercise for 10 interventions, and Group B, which performs SB exercise for 10 interventions. After a 1-week washout period, the groups switch exercises. The primary outcome measure is heart rate variability behavior during interventions with VR and SB while in hemodialysis. Secondary outcomes include blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation during interventions. The study aims to determine the relative effectiveness of VR exercise compared to SB exercise in improving heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients during hemodialysis.

assistant

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between ventilatory variability and dyspnea in patients undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation during a weaning trial. The study will assess the presence and intensity of dyspnea using the Dyspnea Visual Analog Scale (D-VAS) and the Mechanical Ventilation Respiratory Distress Observation Scale (MV-RDOS). Ventilatory variability will be measured using two indices: the coefficient of variation (CV) of chest expansion and the H1/DC component of the respiratory signal. The study will also record surface electromyography of inspiratory extra-diaphragmatic muscles and airway flow and pressure. The primary outcome measures are clinically significant dyspnea (D-VAS > 30 mm) and clinically significant dyspnea (MV-RDOS ≥ 2.6). The study will enroll 100 patients, including 50 communicative patients and 50 non-communicative patients, and will compare the variability indices and surface EMG between patients with clinically significant dyspnea and those without. The study will also evaluate the performance of the variability indices and MV-RDOS to predict dyspnea and failure of the weaning trial.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Randomized Control Trial Comparing the Outcome of a Modified Mini-incision Approach Versus the Conventional Approach for Carpal Tunnel Release

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of a modified mini-incision approach versus the conventional approach for carpal tunnel release in patients with primary carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).

Design: Randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and single-blinded design.

Participants: Patients with primary CTS attending Mansoura university hospitals with EMG-and NCS-proved median neuropathy at the wrist, failed conservative treatment, and absence of other hand pathology.

Interventions:

* Mini-incision approach: A longitudinal mini-incision started just above the proximal flexor wrist crease and extended for 1.5-2 cm in a proximal direction.
* Conventional approach: A longitudinal incision created between the thenar and hypothenar eminences along the longitudinal axis of the ring finger and extended to the proximal flexor wrist crease.

Primary Outcome Measure: Improvement in carpal tunnel syndrome associated pain, measured using the visual analogue scale (VAS) at 6 months postoperative.

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Pillar pain, measured using VAS at 1, 3, and 6 months postoperative.
* Recurrence of neuropathic symptoms, measured using VAS till 6 months postoperative.
* Operative time, measured from skin incision to the end of the procedure.
* Scar effect, measured using the SCAR-Q scale at 3 and 6 months postoperative.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the modified mini-incision approach compared to the conventional approach in terms of pain relief, recurrence of symptoms, operative time, and scar effect in patients with primary CTS.

assistant

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of an intervention using Action Observation Therapy (AOT) among patients with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI). AOT involves observing a motor gesture performed by another individual and then imitating the same movement. The study will compare the effectiveness of AOT in three groups: patients with MCI who observe the therapist, patients with MCI who observe patients without cognitive impairment, and a control group.

The primary objective is to compare the effectiveness of AOT in patients with MCI who observe the therapist, patients with MCI who observe patients without cognitive impairment, and a control group. Secondary objectives include assessing the benefits of AOT on upper limb functionality, ADL, balance, and cognitive status.

The study will recruit 60 patients with MCI and randomly assign them to one of three groups: experimental group 1 (therapist-led imitation exercises), experimental group 2 (peer learning), and control group (standard treatment). The intervention will consist of a 5-week exercise program based on observation and action, with three sessions per week, lasting 20-30 minutes each.

The primary outcome measures will include changes in cognitive impairment (MoCA), activities of daily living (Barthel index), functionality (Fugl-meyer scale), upper limb dexterity (Box and block test), balance (Berg Balance Scale), and gait (10 Meters Walking Test). The study will also assess the benefits of AOT on ADL, balance, and cognitive status.

The study aims to investigate whether AOT is effective in improving cognitive status, upper limb function, ADL, gait, and balance in patients with MCI, and whether there are better outcomes when AOT is conducted under the guidance of a therapist or under the direction of MCI-free individuals, compared to self-directed AOT.

assistant

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of central line placement using an ultraportable ultrasound device compared to standard central line placement. The study will enroll patients aged 18 years or older who are scheduled to have a right or left jugular central venous line placed preoperatively or in the ICU. Objective: To evaluate the immunogenicity and safety of a recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) in individuals aged 18 years and older with different immunization programs, including a 0-1-month and a 0-6-month immunization schedule.

Secondary Outcome Measures: The study will also assess laboratory markers of immunity, including GMT of neutralizing antibodies against the prototype novel coronavirus strain, Omicron strain (BA.4/5, BF.7), and growth multiples (GMI) of the prototype new coronavirus strain and the Omicron variant (BA.4/5, BF.7).

**Title:** The Pain Intervention Via Video Optimization Trial (PIVOT)

**Title:** Paraphilic Disorders and Other Conditions With Risk for Sexual Violence: a Case-control Study

**Objective:** To investigate the relationship between paraphilic disorders, compulsive sexual behavior disorder, and sexsomnia with risk for sexual violence.

**Design:** A case-control study with two arms: a clinical cohort of patients seeking treatment for paraphilic disorders, compulsive sexual behavior disorder, and/or sexsomnia, and a healthy control group.

Secondary outcome measures include various psychological and behavioral assessments, such as the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview, Personality Inventory for DSM-5, and Hypersexual Disorder: Current Assessment Scale.

**Sample Size:** The study will recruit 20 participants with paraphilic disorders, compulsive sexual behavior disorder, and/or sexsomnia, and 20 healthy controls.

**Duration:** The study will last for approximately 6 years, with follow-up assessments conducted at 3, 6, and 12 months.

**Ethics:** The study has been approved by the relevant ethics committee and will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the International Conference on Harmonisation of Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

Title: Pulsed-field Ablation in Patients With Persistent Atrial Fibrillation

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness and safety of pulsed-field ablation (PFA) with two different ablation strategies in patients with persistent atrial fibrillation (AF).

Design: Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study comparing PFA with pulmonary vein isolation (PVI) alone to PFA with PVI plus additional lesions on the left atrial posterior wall, mitral and cavotricuspid isthmus lines.

Eligibility: Patients with persistent AF, aged 18-75 years, with no history of AF ablation or significant valvular defects.

Interventions: PFA using the Farapulse system, with either PVI alone or PVI plus additional lesions.

Primary Endpoint: Recurrence of AF or atrial tachycardia lasting >30 seconds, assessed using 7-day ECG Holter monitoring, starting three months after the index procedure and continuing for 12 months.

Secondary Endpoints: Recurrence of AF on anti-arrhythmic drugs, hospitalization rate, number of electrical cardioversions, PFA-related complications, quality of life assessment using AFEQT and EuroQol questionnaires, and feasibility of achieving complete block of the mitral isthmus and posterior wall using PFA.

Title: A Study to Compare Two Dosing Regimens for a New Malaria Vaccine

Objective: To assess the safety and immunogenicity of the malaria vaccine candidate RH5.1 soluble protein in Matrix-M using two dosing regimens.

A Study of the Genetic Basis of Response to Growth Hormone Treatment in Children With Idiopathic Short Stature:

This study aims to investigate the genetic determinants of response to growth hormone (GH) treatment in children with idiopathic short stature (ISS). The study will enroll children who have been diagnosed with ISS and have received at least one year of GH therapy. Participants will be classified into two groups: good responders (those with a change in height Standard Deviation Score (SDS) greater than 1.0) and poor responders (those with a change in SDS less than 0.4). The study will collect non-invasive biological samples from each participant and measure the frequency of genetic variants that significantly differ between the two responder groups. The study will also examine the enrichment of genetic variants per gene/pathway. The primary outcome measure is the frequency of genetic variants that significantly differ between the two responder groups, measured as an odds ratio. The study will enroll children aged 3-11 years, with a minimum of one year of GH therapy prior to study entry.

**Title:** Bedside Bone Biopsy Versus Conventional Bone Biopsy for Management of Diabetic Foot Osteomyelitis: an Open-label Controlled Randomized Non-inferiority Trial

**Hypothesis:** Bedside BB is non-inferior to conventional CB in DFO outcomes and can be used as a simpler alternative procedure.

Title: Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of BLEX 404 Oral Liquid Combined With Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 Oral Liquid combined with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy in patients with advanced inoperable or metastatic EGFR wild-type non-small cell lung cancer.

Design: Phase I/II, open-label study with a sequential assignment design. The study consists of two phases: Phase I to determine the dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) and recommended dose level (RDL) in the first cycle of combination use, and Phase II to determine the efficacy of BLEX 404 Oral Liquid combined with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy in 20 patients with stage-IV or recurrent non-small cell lung cancer.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients aged 20-70 years with histologically or pathologically diagnosed advanced inoperable or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer, EGFR wild-type, Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0-2, and adequate hematologic, hepatic, and renal function.

Interventions: Patients will receive BLEX 404 Oral Liquid at one of three dose levels (1.5 mg/kg, 3.0 mg/kg, or 6.0 mg/kg) orally twice daily, combined with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy.

Primary Outcome Measures: DLT determination, RDL determination, and overall response rate (PR + CR) after 4 cycles of combination use.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Overall response rate (PR + CR) after at least 1 cycle of combination use, rate of grade 3/4 hematological toxicity, and effect on quality of life by EORTC QLQ-C30.

This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 Oral Liquid combined with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer, with the primary outcome measures focused on determining the dose-limiting toxicity and recommended dose level, as well as the overall response rate after 4 cycles of combination use.

The PREPARE-iVAC trial is a multicentre, open-label, controlled, randomized study evaluating the replacement of Mycophenolate Mofetil/Mycophenolic Acid (MMF/MPA) with everolimus in kidney transplant recipients to improve immunogenicity and safety after vaccination. The primary objective is to investigate whether replacing MMF/MPA with everolimus results in superior immunogenicity of COVID-19 vaccination, as measured by neutralizing antibody titer against the Omicron XBB.1.5 strain.

The study will randomize 1:1 kidney transplant recipients to continue immunosuppressive therapy with MMF/MPA or replace it with everolimus. Participants will receive COVID-19 vaccination and, optionally, herpes zoster vaccination. The study will assess immunogenicity, safety, and kidney function in both groups. The primary outcome measure is the virus-neutralizing capacity of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies 28 days after COVID-19 vaccination.

Secondary objectives include investigating humoral and cellular immunogenicity, as well as safety outcomes such as incidence of treated acute rejection, kidney function decline, serious adverse events, and solicited adverse events. The study will also evaluate the safety of kidney transplant and the impact of everolimus on kidney function.

The study aims to recruit 120 kidney transplant recipients aged 18 years or older who have received maintenance immunosuppressive therapy with MMF/MPA. Exclusion criteria include previous CNI trough levels not sufficient, more than two previous kidney transplantations, and calculated level of panel reactive antibodies prior to last transplantation above 85%. The study is expected to provide valuable insights into the effects of everolimus on immunogenicity and safety in kidney transplant recipients.

This prospective observational study aimed to investigate the use of a water-soluble contrast-based protocol to assist in the management of pediatric adhesive small bowel obstruction (ASBO). The study enrolled 314 patients aged 1-20 years who were diagnosed with ASBO and underwent a trial of non-operative management (NOM) on hospital admission. The primary outcome measure was the number of patients who required an operation, and the secondary outcomes included total hospital length of stay and adverse events related to contrast administration.

The study found that the use of enteral contrast challenge was not standardized across sites, but the protocol was standardized across sites for other aspects. The contrast agent used was Diatrizoate meglumine or Ioversol, and patients received 30-200ml of enteral contrast followed by X-rays at 8-12 hours and 24 hours after contrast administration.

The study showed that the use of enteral contrast challenge did not significantly affect the need for operation, but it may have affected the total hospital length of stay and the rate of adverse events related to contrast administration. The study also found that the type of contrast agent used and the final osmolality of the contrast administered did not significantly affect the outcomes.

Overall, the study suggests that the use of enteral contrast challenge may be useful in the management of pediatric ASBO, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and to determine the optimal protocol for its use.

Objective: To evaluate the effect of selective reporting for antibiotic susceptibility testing on general practitioners' (GPs') prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics in women with E. coli urinary tract infections (UTIs).

Primary Outcome Measure: The rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing within 5 days after report of the antibiotic susceptibility testing.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Include rates of directed broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing, antibiotic de-escalation rate, and rates of antibiotic dispensing as a function of GP and patient characteristics.

The TINO study aims to investigate the underlying mechanisms and consequences of the loss of nasal T cells in older adults, particularly those who are vital, frail, or have respiratory tract infections. The study will enroll three groups: young adults (18-30 years old), healthy elderly (65+ years old), and frail elderly (65+ years old) with recurrent respiratory tract infections. Participants will provide nasal and blood samples at baseline and three months later, and will be followed up for six months if they develop respiratory symptoms.

The primary outcome measure is the frequency of nasal CD8+ T cells in young adults and frail older adults. Secondary outcomes include the phenotype, functionality, and clonality of nasal and blood T cells, as well as the transcriptomic cluster composition, stability of nasal T cells, and comparison of nasal and peripheral immune cell populations between the three groups.

The study also aims to investigate the effect of sex on aging effects of nasal and blood immune populations, and to identify asymptomatic viral infections and their association with T cells and other immune parameters. Additionally, the study will examine the frequencies of antigen-specific T cells in the nose and blood post-infection.

The TINO study will provide valuable insights into the mechanisms underlying the loss of nasal T cells in older adults and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies to prevent respiratory tract infections in this population.

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of using celluloid matrix tapes and oral tapes in reducing the palatoglossal air space shadow error in panoramic imaging.

Methods: Patients were randomly assigned to one of the three groups and instructed to place the corresponding strip on their tongue before panoramic imaging. The strips were positioned in the anterior-posterior dimension at the middle third of the tongue and in the transverse dimension in the central groove of the tongue. The radiographs were assessed by an oral and maxillofacial radiologist for the presence of palatoglossal air space shadow error.

Results: The study found that the use of celluloid matrix tapes and oral tapes significantly reduced the palatoglossal air space shadow error in panoramic imaging compared to the control group.

Conclusion: The study suggests that using celluloid matrix tapes and oral tapes can be an effective method for reducing the palatoglossal air space shadow error in panoramic imaging, improving the quality of radiographs and reducing diagnostic errors.

Title: Pilot Study for the Evaluation of Algorithms for the Detection of Subcutaneous Insulin Pump Malfunctions in Subjects With Type 1 Diabetes

Objective: To test new algorithms for detecting pump/infusion set malfunctions in artificial pancreas systems that result in reduced or interrupted insulin delivery in individuals with type 1 diabetes.

Study Design: The study consists of three phases: Phase 1 (Preliminary Data Collection), Phase 2 (Induction of Hyperglycemia), and Phase 3 (Retrospective Data Analysis). In Phase 1, patients use their artificial pancreas in daily life, and data is collected. In Phase 2, patients visit the clinic, where insulin infusion is temporarily suspended to simulate a pump malfunction. In Phase 3, the collected data is analyzed to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms in detecting insulin suspension.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients with type 1 diabetes, aged 18-70, using an automated insulin delivery system for at least 3 months, and with a glycated hemoglobin level less than 10%.

Primary Outcome Measure: Sensitivity, defined as the fraction of correctly detected insulin suspension in the population, during the intervention.

Secondary Outcome Measure: False positive per day, defined as the number of false alarms (normalized by the number of days of monitoring), at baseline pre-intervention.

The study aims to develop and evaluate algorithms for detecting insulin pump malfunctions in artificial pancreas systems, which can help prevent hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis in individuals with type 1 diabetes.

**Title:** The Value of a Risk Prediction Tool (PERSARC) for Effective Treatment Decisions of Soft-tissue Sarcomas Patients

**Objective:** To assess the effectiveness of PERSARC, a personalized risk assessment tool, in reducing decisional conflict and increasing informed choices in high-grade extremity Soft-Tissue Sarcoma patients compared to usual care.

**Design:** A parallel cluster randomized trial will be conducted in 6 Dutch hospitals, with hospitals randomized to either standard care or care with the use of PERSARC.

**Population:** Patients aged 18 years or older with histologically confirmed grade 2-3 extremity Soft-Tissue Sarcoma, who do not have a treatment plan yet and will be treated with curative intent.

Secondary outcomes include regret, worry, involvement in decision-making, patient-reported outcomes, utilities for cost-effectiveness analysis, healthcare costs, and absenteeism/presenteeism from paid work.

**Timeline:** Outcomes will be assessed at one week, three months, six months, and 12 months after the treatment decision.

Title: Early Childhood Caries in Jordanian Children: Prevalence, Risk Factors and Prevention Using Silver Diamine Fluoride

Objective: To investigate the prevalence of early childhood caries in Jordanian children, identify associated risk factors, and evaluate the effectiveness of silver diamine fluoride (SDF) as a caries control material.

Methodology: This cross-sectional epidemiological study included 887 children aged 3-5 years who attended kindergartens in Jordan. A subset of 159 children with early childhood caries were randomly assigned to either a study group receiving a single application of 38% SDF or a control group with no intervention. The study followed up the children for 1 year to assess the prevalence of early childhood caries, caries prevention, and caries arrest.

Key Findings:

* The prevalence of early childhood caries in Jordanian children was high.
* SDF was found to be effective in preventing new cavities and arresting existing cavities.
* Parental acceptance of SDF was high, with most parents agreeing to the application.

This study aims to provide valuable insights into the prevalence and prevention of early childhood caries in Jordanian children, and the effectiveness of SDF as a caries control material.

Title: Comparison of Post Facilitation Stretch and Maitland Mobilization in Post-traumatic Stiff Elbow

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of post-facilitation stretch and Maitland mobilization in improving range of motion in patients with post-traumatic stiff elbow.

Design: Randomized, controlled trial with 32 participants aged 18-35 years with post-traumatic stiff elbow. Participants were randomly assigned to either the post-facilitation stretch group or the Maitland mobilization group.

Interventions:

* Post-facilitation stretch group: Participants received post-facilitation stretch therapy 4-5 times a day, 5 days a week for 4 weeks.
* Maitland mobilization group: Participants received Maitland mobilization therapy 2-3 times a day, 5 days a week for 4 weeks.

Outcomes:

* Primary outcomes: Changes in range of motion (ROM) of the elbow joint, forearm supination, and forearm pronation at 4 weeks.
* Secondary outcomes: Changes in numeric pain rating scale, disability measured by the DASH questionnaire, and ROM of the elbow joint flexion and extension at 4 weeks.

Conclusion: This study aims to compare the effectiveness of post-facilitation stretch and Maitland mobilization in improving range of motion and reducing pain and disability in patients with post-traumatic stiff elbow.

Title: Acetated Ringer's Solution in Experimental Hypovolemia

Objective: To investigate the effects of intravenous fluid bolus on central and cerebral hemodynamic effects and volume kinetics in healthy human volunteers with experimental hypovolemia.

Design: Randomized, crossover, placebo-controlled, single-center study with a factorial 2x2 design. Participants will receive either Ringer's acetate or no intravenous fluid, and will undergo lower body negative pressure (LBNP) at either 0 mmHg or 40 mmHg.

Population: Healthy male and female volunteers aged 18-40 years.

Inclusion criteria: Overtly healthy participants who are capable of giving informed consent and meet specific criteria for contraception and menstrual status.

Exclusion criteria: Participants with medical conditions, pregnancy, breastfeeding, history of syncope, cardiac arrhythmia, or regular medication use.

Secondary outcome measures: Hemodynamic variables, including cardiac output, mean arterial pressure, and central venous pressure.

The study aims to explore the effects of Ringer's acetate on hemodynamic variables and volume kinetics in healthy volunteers with experimental hypovolemia, and to compare these effects with those of no intravenous fluid administration.

The study will assess the effectiveness of the BWSS system in improving motor function, as measured by various scales and checklists, including the Neuromuscular Gross Motor Outcome (GRO) scale, Hammersmith Functional Motor Scale Expanded (HFMSE), Revised Hammersmith Scale (RHS), Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development 3rd ed. Title: DMEK Endothelial Keratoplasty in Patients With a History of Anterior or Posterior Segment Surgery

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of Descemet Membrane Endothelial Keratoplasty (DMEK) in patients with a history of anterior or posterior segment surgery, specifically assessing the occurrence rate of serious complications and visual efficacy at 12 months.

Eligibility: Patients scheduled for corneal endothelial transplantation in one or both eyes, with a history of vitrectomy, trabeculectomy, or other anterior or posterior segment surgeries, and no contraindications to endothelial transplantation.

Intervention: DMEK procedure, which involves replacing the diseased corneal endothelium with a healthy donor endothelium.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Occurrence rate of at least one serious DMEK post-op complication (rebulling, graft failure, graft rejection, macular cystoid edema, or intraocular hypertension) at 12 months.
* Visual efficacy, measured by best-corrected and uncorrected visual acuity, at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Various measures of graft function, including rebulling, graft failure, graft rejection, and macular cystoid edema, at 12 months.
* Refractive results, measured by autorefractometer, at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months.
* Endothelial loss, measured by specular microscopy, at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months.
* Corneal thickness, measured by OCT, at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months.
* Posterior keratometry, measured by Scheimpflug corneal topography, at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months.

Duration: The study will enroll patients for 12 months, with follow-up assessments at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months.

Title: Utility of the Measurement of Median Nerve Stenosis for Diagnosis of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

Objective: To assess the utility of measurements made at the point of maximal stenosis of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).

Methodology: The study will include patients with CTS and healthy controls. Participants will undergo nerve conduction studies (NCS) and ultrasound (US) of the median nerve to measure cross-sectional area, diameter, and echogenicity at various points, including the point of maximal stenosis. Patients will also complete the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ) and a demographic questionnaire.

Primary outcome measures include the difference in diameter, cross-sectional area, and echogenicity of the median nerve at the point of maximal compression between patients with CTS and healthy controls.

Secondary outcome measures include the correlation of these measurements with the BCTQ score and CTS electrophysiological severity grade.

The study aims to evaluate the diagnostic utility of measuring median nerve stenosis in patients with CTS and to identify potential correlations between these measurements and clinical severity.

Title: Adolescent Contraception: Communication Training Intervention to Engage Pediatrician-Adolescent-Mother Triads

This study aims to develop and test an artificial intelligence (AI) communication training tool to improve reproductive health encounters between pediatricians, adolescents, and mothers. The tool will be designed to simulate a mother-daughter conversation about contraception, allowing pediatricians to practice communication skills.

The study consists of three stages: formative, development, and proof-of-concept. In the formative stage, pediatricians and adolescent-mother dyads will participate in real-life clinical encounters, and their communication styles and content will be characterized. In the development stage, the AI tool will be developed and refined through prompt engineering and performance evaluation with advisory boards.

In the proof-of-concept stage, 10 pediatrician learners will receive training with the AI tool and then participate in 10 real-life clinical encounters before and after training. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the AI tool in improving communication interactions, acceptability, and feasibility.

The primary outcome measures include the quality of communication interactions, while secondary outcome measures include acceptability and feasibility of the AI tool. The study aims to advance pediatrician communication training, empower adolescent sexual health, and support mothers' priorities.

The "Healthcare Disparities in Vitiligo: a Population-based Cohort Study in the UK" aims to investigate healthcare disparities in vitiligo patients in the UK. The study estimates the cumulative lifetime risk of vitiligo in the population and by sociodemographic groups, including age, sex, ethnicity, and deprivation. It also examines health-related disparities across these groups in mental health conditions, healthcare utilization, and work impact.

The study uses a population-based cohort design, analyzing data from the Optimal Prediction of Clinical Risk in Dementia (OPCRD) database. The cohort consists of adults and adolescents with vitiligo, newly diagnosed between 2004 and 2020. The study does not involve an intervention, instead, it is an observational analysis of usual care.

The primary outcome measure is the total disease burden of vitiligo, measured using cumulative lifetime incidence against age. Secondary outcome measures include the incidence and prevalence of mental health conditions, healthcare utilization, and work impact in patients with vitiligo. The study aims to identify disparities in these outcomes across different sociodemographic groups.

The study, titled "The Effect of Self-efficacy and Relationship Through Behavior Modification by Hybrid Mode in Caregivers With Toddler Receiving Early Intervention," aims to investigate the effects of a hybrid behavior modification program on stress, self-efficacy, relationships, and conflict in caregivers of children with developmental delay.

The study recruited 39 caregivers and randomly assigned them to either a hybrid group (n=20) or a self-learning group (n=19). The hybrid group received an 8-week training program that included online sessions, individual consultations, and a role structure and game structure. The self-learning group received a description of the course goals and a reading of the Atomic Habits book, with no additional support.

The study measured several outcomes, including intervention fidelity, parenting sense of confidence, parenting stress index, conflict tactics scales, and satisfaction questionnaire. The primary outcome measures were intervention fidelity and parenting sense of confidence, while the secondary outcome measures included parenting stress index, conflict tactics scales, and satisfaction questionnaire.

The study used a randomized controlled trial design, with a parallel assignment and single-blinded assessment. The data will be analyzed using Mann-Whitney U test, Wilcoxon Signed Ranked Test, and Spearman correlation analysis.

The study aims to improve the mental health and well-being of caregivers of children with developmental delay, as well as their relationships with their children, by promoting self-efficacy and reducing stress and conflict.

Here is a summary of the clinical trial document:

**Study Overview**

The study is a Phase I/IB trial investigating the combination of trotabresib, an oral BET inhibitor, with vinorelbine and radiation therapy for the treatment of HER2+ breast cancer patients with central nervous system (CNS) metastasis and leptomeningeal disease (LMD).

**Objectives**

The primary objectives are to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended Phase II dose of trotabresib in combination with vinorelbine, and to measure progression-free survival (PFS) from the date of first treatment to the date of first observation of progressive disease in both intracranial and extracranial sites.

**Study Design**

The study consists of two cohorts: Cohort I, which includes patients with CNS metastases or LMD who receive radiation therapy followed by trotabresib and vinorelbine, and Cohort S, which includes patients who undergo tumor resection and receive trotabresib and vinorelbine.

**Eligibility Criteria**

Patients must have histologically or cytologically confirmed HER2+ breast cancer, newly diagnosed or progressive CNS metastases or LMD, and an estimated life expectancy of at least 3 months. Patients must also have adequate bone marrow reserve, liver function, and kidney function.

**Exclusion Criteria**

Patients with a history of allergic reactions to compounds similar to trotabresib and vinorelbine, impaired cardiac function, or known additional malignancies are excluded.

**Primary Outcome Measures**

The primary outcome measures are dose-limiting toxicities (Phase I) and incidence of adverse events (Phase Ib).

**Secondary Outcome Measures**

The secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival, overall survival, objective response rate, and disease monitoring using circulating tumor cells and circulating tumor DNA.

**Study Timeline**

The study will enroll patients for up to 1 year, with follow-up assessments every 6 months for up to 1 year.

Title: Treating Binge Eating and Obesity Digitally in Black Women: A Feasibility Study

Objective: To develop and test a culturally-relevant digital health tool for binge eating and weight management in Black women with obesity (BMI > 30 kg/m^2).

Methodology: A randomized clinical trial with two arms: (1) Centering Appetite Intervention, and (2) Attention-Control Group. Participants will receive either the digital treatment (AAT and BWL) or weekly psychoeducation emails for 6 months.

Eligibility: Black women aged 18-75, with BMI ≥ 30 kg/m^2, who binge eat and live or work within 30 miles of Kannapolis, NC.

Outcome Measures:

* Feasibility: Total number of eligible adults enrolled and retained in the study.
* Retention: Percentage of participants retained in the study through 6 months.
* Attendance: Percentage of intervention sessions attended.
* Secondary outcomes: Change in weight regain, number of binge eating episodes, and body weight at baseline, 3, and 6 months.

This study aims to examine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a digital health appetite awareness + behavioral weight program in primary care for Black women with obesity and binge eating.

Title: The Effect of Beetroot Juice Supplementation Dose on Neuromuscular Performance During Resistance Exercise

Objective: To investigate the effect of dietary nitrate supplementation from beetroot juice on neuromuscular performance during resistance exercise and to determine the optimal dose of nitrate for improving performance.

Design: A randomized, double-blind, crossover study with four experimental trials: low, moderate, high nitrate doses, and a placebo.

Intervention: Participants ingested either a low (6.5 mmol), moderate (13 mmol), or high (26 mmol) dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice or a nitrate-depleted placebo 2.5 hours before exercise.

Primary Outcome Measures: Plasma nitrate and nitrite concentrations, and neuromuscular performance during countermovement jumps, including peak force, average propulsion force, rate of power development, peak positive power, concentric mean power, jump height, takeoff velocity, and flight time.

Secondary Outcome Measure: Mood, assessed using a 24-item questionnaire.

Eligibility Criteria: Recreational males aged 18-45 years who performed resistance exercise at least twice weekly for the last two years, with no contraindications to exercise, cardiometabolic disease, or consumption of dietary supplements containing caffeine, sodium bicarbonate, creatine, beta-alanine, or NO precursor supplements.

This study aims to investigate the effect of beetroot juice supplementation on neuromuscular performance during resistance exercise and to determine the optimal dose of nitrate for improving performance.

This randomized controlled trial aims to investigate the effect of two different intra-abdominal pressure levels (12 mmHg and 14 mmHg) on mechanical power during laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgery. Mechanical power is a measure of the energy transferred from the mechanical ventilator to the respiratory system, and is associated with ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study will enroll patients aged 18-75 years with ASA 1-2 undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. The primary outcome measure is ventilator-induced lung injury (barotrauma) measured by mechanical power values during the operation. The study will measure mechanical power values at various time points during the operation, including before and after insufflation. The results of this study may help determine the optimal intra-abdominal pressure level for laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgery to minimize the risk of VILI and ARDS.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Implant success rate at 12 months post-implant.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Intra-operative fluoroscopic exposure time, intra-operative intracardiac electrogram, post-operative imaging data, serial paced 12-lead electrocardiogram and intracardiac EGM changes, serial echocardiography changes, and serial changes of pacing parameters.

Title: Calisthenics Exercise Program and Pulsed Electromagnetic Therapy on Liver Function Following Burn Injuries

Objective: To evaluate the effect of calisthenics exercise and pulsed electromagnetic therapy on liver function in patients with burn injuries.

Design: Randomized, parallel-group, double-blind study with three arms: calisthenics exercise group, pulsed electromagnetic therapy group, and combination group.

Interventions:

* Calisthenics exercise group: Participants will perform a 12-week calisthenics exercise program, 3 times a week, in addition to traditional physical therapy and medical treatment.
* Pulsed electromagnetic therapy group: Participants will receive pulsed electromagnetic therapy, 3 times a week, for 20 minutes, in addition to traditional physical therapy and medical treatment.
* Combination group: Participants will perform calisthenics exercise and receive pulsed electromagnetic therapy, 3 times a week, for 20 minutes, in addition to traditional physical therapy and medical treatment.

Outcome Measures:

* Concentration of Alanine transaminase (ALT) and Aspartate transaminase (AST) enzymes in blood plasma, measured at baseline and 3 months.

Eligibility Criteria:

* Age: 20-45 years
* Male and female patients
* Burns with BBSA 30-50%
* No history of liver disease, cardiac disease, or other exclusion criteria

The study aims to investigate the effects of calisthenics exercise and pulsed electromagnetic therapy on liver function in patients with burn injuries, and to determine which intervention is most effective in improving liver function.

Title: The Effects of an Oncology Tailored Nutritional Intervention on the Bioavailability and Immune-activity of PD-1 Immune Checkpoint Inhibitors in Patients With Lung Cancer

Objective: To investigate the variability of pembrolizumab clearance during a 12-week nutritional intervention period in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients receiving anti-PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs).

The Integrins and Protocadherins in Glutamatergic Circuits (GAPsy) study aims to identify common signaling pathways and molecular targets in anxiety and major depressive disorders. The study is divided into two parts: a clinical trial in humans and a murine model study.

In the clinical trial, 10 patients with anxiety-depressive disorder (MDD-AD) and 10 healthy controls will be recruited. Participants will undergo a 7T multimodal neuroimaging session, including T1-weighted, 1H-MRS, and fMRI, as well as a structured clinical interview and administration of scales such as HAM-A, HAM-D, BPRS, and MADRS. The primary outcome measures include brain structure differences in the prefrontal-limbic pathway, functional connectivity differences in the prefrontal-limbic pathway, and differences in glutamatergic neurotransmission in the anterior cingulate and prefrontal dorsolateral cortices.

In the murine model study, the investigators will use Pcdh9-knockout mice to assess whether Pcdh9 deficits affect the number and morphology of excitatory synapses. They will also study glutamatergic signaling at the biochemical level and characterize the interaction between integrin β3 and Protocadherin9 using co-immunoprecipitation analysis. Additionally, they will perform electrophysiological characterization of Itgb3 and Pcdh9 patterns in the medial prefrontal cortex and evaluate functional recovery of behavioral and electrophysiological deficits mediated by CRISPRa.

**Title:** Association Analysis of Cardiovascular and Nervous System Diseases and Intestinal Microbiome Based on Multi-omics Big Data and Related Applications

**Objective:** To investigate the association between cardiovascular and nervous system diseases and the intestinal microbiome using multi-omics big data and machine learning methods.

**Methods:** This study will collect fecal and blood samples from patients with cardiovascular and neurological diseases, as well as healthy controls. The samples will be sequenced for genome, transcriptome, metagenome, and metabolome analysis. The data will be integrated using machine learning methods to identify key genes and bacteria associated with disease development and progression.

**Population:** The study will include patients with idiopathic ventricular tachycardia, postoperative coronary artery stenosis injury, moyamoya disease, carotid atherosclerosis, and healthy controls.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients with confirmed diagnoses and age between 18-75 years.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with organic heart disease, antibiotic use within 45 days, and previous history of vascular surgery or trauma.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Stool sampling and blood collection to analyze the association between intestinal microbiome and cardiovascular and neurological diseases.

**Study Design:** A non-interventional study with two arms: disease group and healthy control group.

**Sample Size:** 250 patients with disease and 240 healthy controls.

**Expected Outcomes:** The study aims to identify key genes and bacteria associated with disease development and progression, and to develop predictive models for early disease prevention and diagnosis.

**Title:** A Phase II Study of Sacituzumab Govitecan With or Without Atezolizumab Immunotherapy in Rare Genitourinary Tumors (SMART)

**Objective:** To evaluate the clinical efficacy of sacituzumab govitecan (SG) alone or in combination with atezolizumab in patients with rare metastatic non-prostate genitourinary tumors.

**Eligibility:** Patients with histologically confirmed diagnosis of locally advanced or metastatic genitourinary tumors, including small cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, primary adenocarcinoma of the bladder or urinary tract, renal medullary carcinoma, or squamous cell carcinoma of the penis.

**Intervention:** Patients will receive sacituzumab govitecan (SG) alone or in combination with atezolizumab. SG will be administered intravenously at 10 mg/kg on days 1 and 8 of each 21-day cycle. Atezolizumab will be administered intravenously at 1200 mg on day 1 of each 21-day cycle.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Objective response rate (ORR) defined as the percentage of patients with best overall response (CR, PR, SD, PD) to therapy.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Duration of response (DoR), overall survival (OS), progression-free survival (PFS), clinical benefit rate (CBR), and safety of sacituzumab govitecan with or without atezolizumab.

**Study Plan:** This is an open-label, non-randomized phase II trial with two arms. Patients will be treated with SG alone or in combination with atezolizumab for a maximum of 5 years or until signs of progression or intolerable side effects.

**Title:** Influence of Nutrition in Depression Treatment (INDEPT)

**Masking:** Double-blinded, with concealment of participants' allocation to the researchers involved in data collection and statistical analysis.

Title: Improving Incurable Head and Neck Cancer Healthcare Experiences

Objective: To understand and identify priorities for improving the healthcare experiences of people with incurable head and neck cancer (HNC) through a qualitative investigation and co-design approach.

Design: A prospective longitudinal qualitative study across three regions of North England, accompanied by co-design workshops.

Methodology:

* Work Package 1: Longitudinal interviews with patients and family carers (n=18-25) to explore their experiences and identify themes.
* Work Package 1b: Online focus groups with healthcare professionals (n=20) to gather their perspectives on improving care for incurable HNC patients.
* Work Package 2: Co-design workshops with stakeholders (n=15-20) to prioritize areas for intervention development and generate potential solutions.

Inclusion Criteria:

* Patients with incurable HNC (primary, recurrent, or metastatic) aged 18 years or older.
* Family carers of patients with incurable HNC.
* Healthcare professionals involved in the care of incurable HNC patients over the last 12 months.
