**Title:** Behavioral Economic Strategies to Improve PRO Adherence

**Objective:** To develop and test behavioral economic strategies to improve patient-level adherence to patient-reported outcomes (PRO) monitoring in patients with cancer.

**Methodology:** This is a randomized, three-arm study with a parallel assignment design. Patients with cancer initiating systemic therapy will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: (1) usual practice with encounter-based PRO monitoring, (2) usual practice with encounter-based PRO monitoring plus patient reminders and triage nurse alerts, or (3) remote PRO monitoring with patient reminders and triage nurse alerts.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** PRO adherence, measured as the proportion of expected PRO questionnaires completed per patient over a 3-month period.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Secondary outcomes include the percentage of patients with notes documenting PROs, time to alert response, percentage of patients triggering alerts, acute care utilization, treatment delays/modifications, and duration of therapy.

**Significance:** This study aims to address limitations of current PRO approaches by employing behavioral strategies to improve clinician engagement, utilizing novel electronic remote monitoring methods, and linking reported symptoms with clinical response.

Title: Culturally Adapted Psychosocial Interventions for Early Psychosis in a Low-resource Setting: A Large Multi-center Randomised Controlled Trial

Objective: To determine the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of Culturally adapted Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CaCBT) and Culturally adapted Family Intervention (CulFI) compared to Treatment as Usual (TAU) in reducing overall symptoms of psychosis in individuals with First Episode Psychosis (FEP) in Pakistan.

Methodology: A randomized controlled trial involving 390 participants with FEP from psychiatric units of hospitals in ten centers in Pakistan. Participants were randomly assigned to one of three groups: CaCBT + TAU, CulFI + TAU, or TAU alone. The interventions consisted of 12 weekly sessions of CaCBT and 10 weekly sessions of CulFI. Assessments were conducted at baseline, months 3, 6, and 12.

Primary Outcome Measure: The Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) to evaluate the prevalence and severity of psychotic symptoms.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Various measures to assess depression, quality of life, disability, insight, caregiver experiences, and anxiety.

Interventions: CaCBT is a culturally adapted psychosocial intervention that aims to take a collaborative approach to gaining an understanding of symptoms. CulFI is a culturally adapted psychosocial intervention that comprises family psychoeducation, cognitive-behavioral skills training, crisis intervention, and relapse prevention.

Target Population: Individuals with FEP aged 18 years or older, diagnosed with schizophrenia, schizophreniform, or schizoaffective psychosis, and stable on medication for at least four weeks.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of culturally adapted psychosocial interventions in reducing symptoms of psychosis in individuals with FEP in a low-resource setting.

Title: Study of IMPT-314 in R/R Aggressive B-cell NHL

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of IMPT-314, a CD19/20 bispecific chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy, in patients with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL).

This study will assess the safety and efficacy of IMPT-314 in patients with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell NHL, with the goal of determining the optimal dose and schedule for future studies.

Title: Examining the Effects of Binaural Beat Music on Sleep Quality, Heart Rate Variability, and Depression in Older People With Poor Sleep Quality in a Long-term Care Institution: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Objective: To investigate the effects of binaural beat music on sleep quality, heart rate variability, and depression in older adults with poor sleep quality in a long-term care institution.

Population: Older adults aged 75-90 years with poor sleep quality, staying in a long-term care institution for at least 1 month, and not receiving antidepressant medication within the past 3 months.

Intervention: Participants were randomly assigned to either a binaural beat music group (BBM group) or a control group. Outcomes: The primary outcomes measured were sleep quality using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), heart rate variability using a HRV analyzer, and depression using the Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS). Secondary outcomes included the same measures at follow-up.

Duration: The study lasted for two weeks, with a post-test conducted on Day 14.

Intervention: Patients will receive durvalumab (1500mg IV infusion every 4 weeks) and rintatolimod (200-400mg IV infusion twice a week for 6 weeks). The primary endpoint is to determine the safety of the combination therapy and the recommended phase II dose.

Secondary endpoints include:

* Clinical benefit rate (stable disease, partial or complete response)
* Overall survival
* Progression-free survival
* Immunogenic effect on circulating and infiltrating immune profiles
* Quality of life using questionnaires

Eligibility criteria include:

* Histologically confirmed metastatic pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma
* Stable disease after at least 8 cycles of chemotherapy (FOLFIRINOX)
* Age ≥ 18 years
* Adequate renal and liver function
* No active autoimmune disease or immunosuppressive therapy

The study aims to enroll 9-18 patients in the phase I portion and 13-25 patients in the phase II portion. The study will assess the safety and efficacy of the combination therapy and explore the immunogenic effect on circulating and infiltrating immune profiles.

Title: Evaluation of the Prophylactic Effects of the Flavonoid Diosmin on Delayed-onset Muscle Soreness in Humans

Objective: To investigate the effects of supplementation with the flavonoid diosmin on delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS) in female athletes.

Methodology: This is a randomized, double-blinded, and placebo-controlled single-center clinical trial. Forty female athletes will be recruited and randomly assigned to either a control group or an intervention group. The control group will receive a placebo, while the intervention group will receive diosmin supplementation. Participants will perform an intense dynamic exercise protocol, and their muscle soreness, muscle tissue damage, and oxidative stress will be evaluated at baseline, 24 hours, and 48 hours after the exercise protocol.

Primary Outcome Measure: Muscle soreness evaluated using a digital algometer and visual analogue scale.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Muscle tissue damage through creatine phosphokinase levels, plasmatic lipid peroxidation levels, plasmatic total antioxidant status, recovery of muscle function through quadriceps strength and vertical jump height, and bipedal and single-legged postural balance.

The study aims to evaluate the potential effects of diosmin supplementation on DOMS and related pathological events in female athletes.

Title: Predictive Factors for Treatment Success of Intrathecal Baclofen Therapy in Children With Cerebral Palsy

Objective: To investigate the short-term, medium-term, and long-term effects of Intrathecal Baclofen (ITB) treatment on personal treatment goals in children with Cerebral Palsy (CP) and to identify predictive factors for treatment success.

Methodology: This is a prospective observational study conducted in two academic medical centers in the Netherlands using the Netherlands CP register to collect data over a period of 4.5 years. The study will include 67-90 children with CP who start ITB treatment under the age of 16. Data will be collected at four time points: before initiation of ITB, after 3 months, after 1 year, and after 2 years.

Outcome measures: The primary outcome measure is Goal Attainment Scaling (GAS), which assesses the attainment of individual goals. Secondary outcome measures include range of motion, spasticity, dystonia, scoliosis, selective motor control, functional strength, gait analysis, questionnaires on activities and participation, and treatment characteristics.

Predictive factors: The study aims to identify predictive factors for treatment success, including factors associated with spasticity and/or dystonia, and factors that influence outcome on the long term.

This study aims to provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of ITB treatment in children with CP and to identify predictive factors for treatment success, which can inform and select children and adolescents with CP better before initiating ITB treatment.

Objective: To evaluate the safety and tolerability of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) in individuals aged 18 years and above.

Eligibility Criteria:

* No history of severe allergy to any vaccine or component of the experimental vaccine
* No uncontrolled lymphoproliferative disease, unmitigated aplastic anemia, or primary immune thrombocytopenia
* No history of congenital or acquired immunodeficiency or autoimmune disease
* No absence of spleen or history of splenic surgery or trauma

The study will enroll 100 participants and will follow them for 12 months after vaccination. The primary endpoint is the incidence of AEs, SAEs, and AESIs within 12 months after vaccination, while the secondary endpoint is the GMT of SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing antibody 14 days after vaccination.

Additionally, the study will assess the consistency of BileCAD microbial analysis results with clinical microbial culture results.

Title: Characteristics of Cytokine Response in Patients With Temporomandibular Disorders Treated With Occlusal Splint Therapy

Objective: To investigate the characteristics of cytokine response in patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) treated with occlusal splint therapy and to assess the effects of this therapy on pain, function, quality of life, and stress levels.

Methodology: This is a single-group, open-label, prospective study enrolling patients with TMD diagnosed according to DC/TMD criteria. Participants will receive a stabilizing occlusal splint made of hard acrylic resin and will be asked to complete self-assessment questionnaires at baseline, one month, and three months. Cytokine levels in blood and gingival crevicular fluid will be measured using ProcartaPlex multiplex assays.

Primary outcome measures include changes in cytokine levels, pain-free opening, maximum unassisted opening, and maximum assisted opening. Secondary outcome measures include changes in pain intensity and pain-related disability, oral health-related quality of life, perceived stress levels, jaw function limitation, depressed mood, anxious feelings and behavior, physical symptoms, and parafunctional behaviors.

Eligibility criteria include patients with TMD pain screening scores ≥ 3, diagnoses of myalgia, arthralgia, headache attributed to TMD, and painful disc displacement (with and without reduction) according to DC/TMD criteria. Exclusion criteria include degenerative joint disease, subluxation of the temporomandibular joint, head trauma, orofacial pain not associated with TMD, fixed or removable prostheses, orthodontic therapy, and use of anti-inflammatory drugs, muscle relaxants, or immunosuppressive medications.

The study aims to provide insights into the therapeutic effects of occlusal splint therapy on TMD patients and to identify potential biomarkers for diagnosing and monitoring TMD.

Title: Scalable Digital Delivery of Evidence-based Training for Professionals to Maximize Treatment Rates of OUD in Families

Objective: To evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of a digital training program for addiction professionals to improve their knowledge and skills in delivering the Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT) approach, and ultimately increase treatment rates for opioid use disorder (OUD) in affected families.

Methodology: The study is a randomized, parallel-group pilot trial with three arms: digital tutorial only, digital tutorial plus training materials, and digital tutorial plus training materials plus feedback and coaching. Participants are addiction professionals who work with clients affected by OUD and are randomly assigned to one of the three arms. The primary outcome measures are CRAFT procedure fidelity, CRAFT knowledge, and treatment entry and retention rates. Secondary outcome measures include program implementation potential and new treatment entry.

Eligibility criteria: Participants must be at least 19 years old, working in a counselor-related profession, have not been trained in CRAFT, and have access to a computer and smartphone with internet access. Exclusion criteria include not agreeing to participate, not completing baseline assessment requirements, and being English-speaking.

The study aims to establish the feasibility and effectiveness of a digital training program for addiction professionals to improve their knowledge and skills in delivering the CRAFT approach, and ultimately increase treatment rates for OUD in affected families.

Title: Treadmill Perturbation Training for Fall Prevention After Total Knee Replacement

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of treadmill perturbation training in preventing falls among patients undergoing total knee replacement surgery.

Methodology:

* 378 participants with end-stage knee osteoarthritis requiring total knee arthroplasty will be recruited and randomly assigned to either a training group or an education control group.
* The training group will undergo 4 sessions of treadmill perturbation training over 2 weeks, while the education control group will receive fall prevention educational materials.
* Participants will be assessed for demographic and functional risk factors, balance and mobility impairment, and comorbidities at baseline.
* The primary outcome measures will be post-training trunk angle and trunk angular velocity, as well as fall rate during the first year after surgery.
* Secondary outcome measures will include fall status immediately after completion of training.

Key aspects of the trial:

* The study aims to prevent falls among patients undergoing total knee replacement surgery.
* The training group will receive treadmill perturbation training, which simulates tripping over an obstacle or being perturbed to the side.
* The education control group will receive fall prevention educational materials.
* The study will assess the effectiveness of the training program in preventing falls and improving balance and mobility.

**Title:** A Single-arm, Open-label, Multicenter Phase II Study of Cadonilimab Combined With Nab-Paclitaxel in Patients With Persistent, Recurrent, or Metastatic Cervical Cancer Previously Treated With Immune Checkpoint Inhibitors

**Objective:** To evaluate the efficacy and safety of cadonilimab in combination with nab-paclitaxel in patients with persistent, recurrent, or metastatic cervical cancer who have previously received immune checkpoint inhibitors.

**Design:** This is a single-arm, open-label, multicenter phase II study.

**Intervention:** Patients will receive cadonilimab 10mg/kg every 3 weeks and nab-paclitaxel ≤260mg/m2 every 3 weeks.

**Primary Endpoint:** Objective response rate (ORR) of cadonilimab in combination with nab-paclitaxel.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Patients must have persistent, recurrent, or metastatic cervical cancer, have previously received immune checkpoint inhibitors, and have an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status score of 0 or 1.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with active malignant tumors, severe immunotherapy-related toxicity, or certain medical conditions are excluded.

**Duration:** The study will be conducted for up to 2 years.

**Keywords:** PD-1, immune checkpoint inhibitor.

Title: A Retrospective, Observational, Single-centre, Cohort Database Analysis of the Haemodynamic Effects of Low-dose Spinal Anaesthesia for Hip Fracture Surgery.

Objective: To investigate the haemodynamic effects of low-dose spinal anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery and its relationship with outcomes such as mortality and length of hospital stay.

Design: Retrospective, observational, single-centre cohort study.

Population: Adults (≥18 years) with unilateral hip fracture who underwent surgery under low-dose spinal anaesthesia (1.3mls 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine) at the Princess Royal Hospital, Hayward's Heath, UK, between March 2017 and January 2020.

Intervention: Intrathecal anaesthesia with 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine (1.3mls, 0.65mg).

The study, "COVID-19 Transmission and Morbidity in Malawi," aims to investigate the relationship between malaria and intestinal parasitic diseases on the immune response to SARS-CoV-2 infection and vaccination in Malawi. The study will enroll up to 200 symptomatic individuals (index cases), their household contacts (approximately 700), and up to 600 vaccinees.

The study will assess the innate immune phenotypes of Malawians compared to Western controls and investigate whether these responses protect against infection and disease progression. Infected participants and vaccinees will be followed for up to 1.5 years to assess the acquisition and longevity of antibody responses and memory B cells.

The primary outcome measures include the risk of asymptomatic infection among contacts, the duration of neutralizing antibody responses, and the change in frequencies of classical monocytes and markers of activation/inflammation. Secondary outcome measures include the probability of infections in a household, the duration of COVID-19 symptoms, and the magnitude of antibody responses to SARS-CoV-2 antigens.

The study will also investigate the expression of host response genes in classical monocytes and monocyte-derived macrophages, the change in concentrations of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines, and the change in frequencies of B cells and plasma cells. The study will provide valuable insights into the immune response to SARS-CoV-2 infection and vaccination in Malawi and inform strategies for preventing and controlling COVID-19 transmission in the region.

**Title:** Radiomic Features of Pancreas From High-Concentration Contrast Enhanced CT Image Predict One-Year Recurrence Risk of Acute Pancreatitis: A Prospective, Multicenter Study

**Objective:** To evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of a deep-learning integrated model that combines radiomic features from high-concentration contrast enhanced CT images with clinical factors to predict the one-year recurrence risk of acute pancreatitis.

**Design:** Prospective, multicenter study with a sample size of 694 patients diagnosed with acute pancreatitis. Patients will undergo enhanced CT scans within 14 days of symptom onset, and radiomic features will be extracted from the images. The patients will be followed up for 12 months to assess recurrence.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The total number of subjects who develop the first recurrence of acute pancreatitis within 3, 6, and 12 months, the sensitivity and specificity of the model in predicting overall recurrence within 3 and 6 months, and the image quality of the CT images.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients aged 18-70 years with acute pancreatitis diagnosed according to the Atlanta Classification, who undergo enhanced CT scans within 14 days of symptom onset.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with a history of allergy to iodinated contrast agents, confirmed or suspected hyperthyroidism or pheochromocytoma, pregnancy or lactation, or other conditions that may affect the accuracy of the CT scans.

**Objective:** To evaluate the effect of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) treatment on polycythemia in patients with moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

**Study Overview**

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of lactoferrin (LF) in improving clinical outcomes in intensive care unit (ICU) patients compared to a placebo.

**Background**

Lactoferrin is a protein found in milk that has antioxidant, immunomodulatory, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and antiviral effects. It has been shown to have beneficial effects in various diseases, including anemia, inflammatory disorders, and infections.

**Methods**

The study is a double-blind, randomized controlled trial (RCT) that will enroll 650 ICU patients who will be randomly assigned to receive either lactoferrin (400 mg daily) or a placebo for 28 days. The primary outcome measures will be 28-day mortality rate and incidence of hypersensitivity reactions. Secondary outcomes will include various laboratory tests and clinical assessments.

**Objectives**

The study aims to:

1. Evaluate the effect of lactoferrin on 28-day mortality rate in ICU patients.
2. Assess the safety of lactoferrin in ICU patients.
3. Explore the effect of lactoferrin on various laboratory tests and clinical assessments.

**Inclusion Criteria**

Patients admitted to the ICU, of any age and gender, will be eligible for the study. Exclusion criteria include patients with a history of hypersensitivity to milk products, lactose intolerance, or those who are expected to die within 48 hours.

**Study Design**

The study is a parallel-group RCT with two arms: lactoferrin and placebo. The study will be conducted at the Mansoura University Hospital ICU departments.

**Primary Outcome Measures**

1. 28-day mortality rate
2. Incidence of hypersensitivity reactions

**Secondary Outcome Measures**

Various laboratory tests and clinical assessments will be performed at days 3, 7, 14, and 28.

**Sample Size**

The study will enroll 650 patients (325 in each group) to achieve at least 80% power to detect a risk difference of 0.2 (20%) in the 28-day all-cause mortality rate between the two groups.

The study aims to develop a novel biomarker, virus-host chimera DNA (vh-DNA), to predict response and prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients with hepatitis B virus (HBV) undergoing radiotherapy. The biomarker is expected to detect residual tumors and early recurrence/metastasis earlier than contemporary imaging methods, allowing for early intervention with salvage therapies. The study will analyze the consistency of junctional clones between pre- and post-radiotherapy serum samples and surgical/biopsied tissues, and correlate changes in vh-DNA copy numbers with treatment response and disease-control status. The study will also prospectively collect plasma samples from HBV-related HCC patients before, during, and after radiotherapy to evaluate the role of vh-DNA in predicting treatment response and overall survival. Additionally, the study will explore the clonality of recurrent HCC tumors to inform future clinical trials on combinational treatments.

**Title:** Developing an Online Individual Intervention Program to Make Sense of People's Experiences After a Breast Cancer Diagnosis and Examining Its Effectiveness

**Objective:** To test the effectiveness of an online individual intervention program, the Meaning-Centered Coping Program, in enhancing the sense of meaning in life, reducing psychological distress, and promoting post-traumatic growth among women with breast cancer.

**Design:** A randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment design, where 44 women with breast cancer were randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the waitlist control group.

**Intervention:** The Meaning-Centered Coping Program is an online, individual intervention program consisting of eight weekly sessions, each lasting approximately 60 minutes. The program is based on the Meaning Making Model and Wong's principles of Meaning Therapy.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The study will assess changes in meaning in life, post-traumatic growth, stress appraisal, global meaning violations, and automatic meaning-making efforts.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The study will also assess changes in psychological flexibility, anxiety, and depression levels.

**Sample:** The study will recruit 44 women with breast cancer, aged 18-65, who have been diagnosed for at least 6 months and at most 3 years, and are able to video-conference using a desktop computer, laptop, or tablet.

**Methodology:** Participants will be assessed at three time points: before the intervention, immediately after the intervention, and at the 2-month follow-up. The data will be analyzed using statistical methods, including Pearson correlation analysis, 2 (Group) X 2 (Time) repeated measures ANOVA, and one-way repeated measures ANOVA.

**Intervention:** The intervention arm includes five components: personalized goal, meal timing, nutrition skills, home food environment, and engagement strategies. Participants will complete an interview with a registered dietitian to establish their personalized dietary goals and receive text messages on nutrition education, cooking skills, and home food environment.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Change in overall Healthy Eating Index (HEI) 2020 score, assessed through three 24-hour dietary recalls at baseline and follow-up.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Change in urinary concentration of sodium (Na) and potassium (K), assessed through first morning urine voids at baseline and follow-up.

**Study Plan:** The trial will last four weeks, with data collection taking place in the home setting. The study aims to demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the digital-based diet quality intervention in improving diet quality and meal timing traits in adolescents with overweight or obesity.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of smell training (ST) and trigeminal nerve stimulation (TNS) in treating COVID-related smell loss (SL). The study will enroll 180 adults with persistent SL who are treatment-seeking and have a SARS-CoV-2 PCR-positive test prior to April 2021. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: active ST, placebo ST, or combination TNS and active ST.

The primary objectives are to determine the efficacy of ST versus potential natural gains in function, to determine the TNS-enhanced effects of ST on SL, and to determine whether TNS+ST is more efficacious than ST in treating other symptoms of long COVID (LC).

The study will assess changes in psychophysical olfactory function, perceived intensity and hedonics of odorants, olfactory-related quality of life, and impact of olfactory loss at 4 and 12 weeks. Secondary outcomes will include changes in long COVID symptoms, sustained attention, cognitive function, mood state, sleep quality, excessive daytime sleepiness, symptoms of depression, and symptoms of anxiety.

The study will use a double-blinded, randomized controlled design with three arms: active ST, placebo ST, and combination TNS and active ST. The study duration is 12 weeks, and participants will undergo assessments at baseline, 4 weeks, and 12 weeks. The study aims to improve the treatment of COVID-related SL and potentially address other symptoms of LC.

**Title:** Shorter Chemo-Immunotherapy Without Anthracycline Drugs for Early-Stage Triple Negative Breast Cancer

**Objective:** To assess the non-inferiority of anthracycline-free, taxane-platinum neoadjuvant chemotherapy with pembrolizumab compared to taxane-platinum-anthracycline neoadjuvant chemotherapy with pembrolizumab in patients with early-stage triple negative breast cancer (TNBC).

**Design:** Randomized, open-label, phase III trial.

**Interventions:** Patients were randomized to either Arm I (usual chemo-immunotherapy) or Arm II (shorter chemo-immunotherapy). **Primary Outcome Measure:** Breast cancer event-free survival (BC-EFS) at 5 years.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Pathologic complete response (pCR), residual cancer burden (RCB), distant relapse-free survival (DRFS), overall survival (OS), and patient-reported outcomes (fatigue, physical function).

**Duration:** Up to 5 years.

**Conclusion:** This trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a shorter chemo-immunotherapy regimen without anthracycline drugs in patients with early-stage TNBC.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

**Study Overview**

The study evaluates a one-year version of the Parent-Child Assistance Program (PCAP-1), a case management intervention for pregnant and postpartum individuals who have used substances during their current or most recent pregnancy. PCAP-1 aims to prevent the need for foster care and promote reunification, as well as achieve other key goals such as parent recovery, access to comprehensive services, and prevention of subsequent substance-exposed pregnancies.

**Objectives**

The specific objectives of this project are to:

1. Establish causal evidence of effectiveness of PCAP-1 in preventing the need for foster care and promoting reunification.
2. Establish causal evidence of the effectiveness of PCAP-1 in achieving other key goals.
3. Estimate cost savings associated with PCAP-1 from the perspective of the agency administering a state's child welfare system.
4. Lay the groundwork to be rated by relevant federal registries according to strength of the program's evidence of effectiveness.

**Design**

The study is a quasi-experimental design with a control group, which consists of participants from the original PCAP trial. The treatment group will receive PCAP-1 services, while the control group will receive services as usual in the community. The study will be conducted over a period of one year, with data collection at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months.

**Outcome Measures**

The primary outcome measures include:

1. Proportion of target children not placed in foster care.
2. Mother acquires or maintains child custody.
3. Proportion of mothers abstinent from drugs and/or alcohol.
4. Proportion of mothers on a reliable method(s) of birth control.
5. Reduction in costs to state agencies.

**Secondary Outcome Measures**

The secondary outcome measures include:

1. Proportion of mothers who acquire or maintain stable housing.
2. Proportion of mothers who acquire or maintain employment.
3. Proportion of mothers who enroll in or complete an educational program.
4. Proportion of mothers who receive public benefits.
5. Proportion of mothers with ongoing criminal justice involvement.

**Participation Criteria**

Eligible participants must be pregnant or parenting individuals who have used substances during their current or most recent pregnancy, reside within a 40-mile radius of Enid, OK, and meet certain inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Title: Comparison Between Rituximab Plus Zanubrutinib Versus Rituximab Monotherapy in Untreated SMZL Patients

Objective: To evaluate whether treatment with zanubrutinib in combination with rituximab improves Progression-Free Survival (PFS) compared to rituximab monotherapy in patients with previously untreated splenic marginal zone lymphoma (SMZL).

Design: Phase III, open-label, randomized study with approximately 120 patients randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive either zanubrutinib and rituximab (Treatment Arm A) or rituximab monotherapy (Treatment Arm B).

Interventions:

* Treatment Arm A: Zanubrutinib (160 mg BID orally) and rituximab (375 mg/m2 IV) for 12 cycles, followed by rituximab alone for 12 additional cycles if patients achieve partial response or complete response.
* Treatment Arm B: Rituximab (375 mg/m2 IV) for 12 cycles, followed by rituximab alone for 12 additional cycles if patients achieve partial response or complete response.

Primary Outcome Measure: Progression-Free Survival (PFS) rate at 3 years.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Complete remission rates, best response, time to next anti-lymphoma treatment, duration of response, overall survival, and treatment-emergent adverse events.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients with confirmed diagnosis of SMZL, age ≥ 18 years, ECOG performance status 0, 1, or 2, and adequate hepatic and renal function.

Exclusion Criteria: Prior splenectomy, prior therapy for SMZL, central nervous system involvement, prior malignancy within the past 2 years, and certain concomitant diseases or conditions.

**Title:** Efficacy of Perioperative US-Guided Serratus Anterior Plane Block Versus Thoracic Epidural in Adult Patient Undergoing Thoracotomy: A Randomized Comparative Double-Blinded Trial

**Objective:** To compare the effectiveness of perioperative continuous serratus anterior plane block (SAPB) versus continuous thoracic epidural (TE) in patients undergoing thoracotomy for cancer surgery.

**Design:** A randomized, double-blinded, controlled trial with 74 patients (37 in each arm) undergoing thoracotomy for cancer surgery.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Postoperative total morphine requirement.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Intraoperative fentanyl requirement, time to the first analgesia requested by the patient, postoperative pain scores, length of hospital stay, and patient satisfaction score.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients undergoing thoracotomy for cancer surgery, aged 18-65 years, with a body mass index (BMI) between 20 and 40 kg/m2.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with a history of psychological disorders, localized infection at the site of block, coagulopathies, or contraindications to local anesthetics.

**Study Timeline:** The study will be conducted over a period of 2 weeks, with patients being followed up for 24 hours postoperatively.

The study aims to compare the effects of Multicomponent Training (MCT) versus Continuous Cardiovascular Training (CVT) as a treatment for hypertension in adult subjects. The study will recruit 75 adult hypertensive subjects, aged 40-65 years, who are sedentary and have controlled high blood pressure. The participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: MCT, CVT, or a control group. The MCT group will perform a 12-week training program that includes two main training units per session, with a combination of strength and cardiovascular exercises. The CVT group will perform a 12-week training program that focuses exclusively on cardiovascular exercises. The control group will not perform any physical exercise program.

The primary outcome measure is the change in blood pressure from baseline to week 12. Secondary outcome measures include changes in mean blood pressure, pulse pressure, dual product, baseline heart rate, and other physiological and anthropometric variables.

The study will assess the effects of the two training programs on blood pressure, cardiovascular risk factors, and overall health. The results of this study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of MCT versus CVT as a treatment for hypertension and may inform the development of new exercise programs for hypertension management.

Title: Prism Adaptation Therapy (PAT) for Right Brain Stroke Rehabilitation

Objective: To develop a biomarker-based algorithm to identify Veterans with spatial neglect (SN) after right brain stroke who are the best candidates for Prism Adaptation Therapy (PAT), a personalized approach to SN rehabilitation.

Methodology: The study will recruit 180 Veterans (120 with SN, 60 without) and use brain imaging biomarkers to predict the presence of Aiming SN, a strong predictor of functional recovery after PAT. The investigators will also examine the correlation between brain imaging biomarkers and improvements in daily life function after PAT.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Spatial neglect type (Aiming SN vs. Where SN)
* Functional independence Measure (FIM) improvement trajectory

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Spatial neglect severity, as assessed by the Behavioral Inattention Test-conventional subtest (BIT-c)
* Spatial neglect severity, as assessed by the Catherine Bergego Scale (CBS)

This study aims to establish the utility of a validated biomarker that identifies Veterans with SN who are the best candidates for PAT, and to develop a personalized approach to SN rehabilitation that reduces reliance on specialized SN assessment and improves stroke care efficiency.

Title: Extended Pancreatic Neck Transection Versus Conventional Pancreatic Neck Transection During Laparoscopic Pancreaticoduodenectomy (LPDEXCEPT)

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of extended pancreatic neck transection versus conventional pancreatic neck transection during laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy in patients with benign or resectable malignant tumors of the lower common bile duct, Vater ampulla, head or uncinate process of the pancreas.

Design: Multicenter randomized controlled trial with two arms: experimental (extended transection group) and control (conventional transection group).

Eligibility Criteria: Patients aged 18-80 years with resectable tumors, no contraindication to surgery, and good compliance and cooperation with follow-up.

Primary Outcome Measure: Incidence of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula within 3 months postoperatively.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Location of the pancreatic duct in the pancreatic transverse section, surgical performance of pancreaticojejunostomy, postoperative morbidity (Clavien-Dindo score ≥3), and postoperative mortality within 3 months postoperatively.

The study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of extended pancreatic neck transection during laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy in reducing the incidence of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula and improving postoperative outcomes.

This randomized controlled trial aimed to investigate the effects of two types of concurrent training on functional performance and cognitive function in older adults. The study included 65-75 year olds who were randomly assigned to one of three groups: traditional concurrent training, concurrent training with dance classes, or a control group.

The primary outcomes measured included changes in dynamic balance, cognitive function, self-reported quality of life, and physical performance tests such as timed up and go, one leg stance, and 30-second seat to stand test. The secondary outcomes included changes in muscle thickness, affectivity, lipid profile, and depressive symptoms.

The study found that both concurrent training groups showed significant improvements in functional performance and cognitive function compared to the control group. The traditional concurrent training group showed greater improvements in physical performance tests, while the concurrent training with dance classes group showed greater improvements in cognitive function and quality of life.

Title: Virtual Reality as an Adjuvant Therapy for Sickle Cell Vaso-Occlusive Crisis in the Pediatric Emergency Department

Objective: To examine the effectiveness of virtual reality (VR) as an adjuvant therapy for reducing pain, hospital admission rates, and length of stay in pediatric patients with sickle cell vaso-occlusive crisis (VOC) in the emergency department.

Methodology: This is a non-randomized, open-label trial with two arms: a control arm with a retrospective chart review of 100 patients and an experimental arm with a prospective convenience sampling of up to 100 patients who will receive VR in addition to standard medical therapy.

Inclusion criteria: Patients aged 6-21 years with sickle cell disease, VOC, and pain score of 4 or greater.

Primary outcome measures: Pain scores, patient disposition (admitted to hospital or discharged from emergency department), length of stay in the emergency department, and time to emergency department disposition.

Secondary outcome measures: Length of stay in the emergency department and time to emergency department disposition.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of VR in reducing pain, hospital admission rates, and length of stay in pediatric patients with sickle cell VOC in the emergency department.

**Title:** Secondary Cardiovascular Prevention Post-acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) Through a Web-based Empowerment Program

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of a web-based empowerment program in improving secondary cardiovascular prevention outcomes in patients with acute myocardial infarction (AMI).

**Design:** Randomized controlled trial with two arms: experimental (digital empowerment) and control (usual care).

**Intervention:** The experimental group will receive a web-based empowerment program, which includes personalized risk factor profiling, motivational and educational materials, and periodic reminders. The control group will receive usual care.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Changes in measurable risk factors (BMI, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, LDL-cholesterol, glycemia, and glycosylated hemoglobin) at 12 months.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Lifestyle changes (physical activity, adherence to a heart-friendly diet, smoking reduction or cessation, self-efficacy, and health locus of control), adherence to cardioprotective treatment, glucose control in diabetic patients, and long-term maintenance of controlled risk factors at 48 months.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients with STEMI or NSTEMI, availability of digital communication devices and internet access.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Active malignancies, life expectancy <5 years, cognitive status undermining digital communication device use, low understanding of Italian language, and patient not foreseeing to undergo cardiology follow-up.

**Duration:** 48 months.

The study aims to investigate the accuracy of pocket-sized ultrasound (PsUS) in diagnosing pediatric elbow fractures compared to radiography. The study consists of two parts: a feasibility study and an active study. In the feasibility study, pediatric emergency medicine physicians will undergo training to perform PsUS exams on children between 1-16 years old. The primary aim is to determine the acceptability of the PsUS study training to obtain adequate elbow images. In the active study, children between 1-16 years old with isolated, acute elbow pain will undergo a standardized PsUS exam using a pocket-sized ultrasound device. The primary outcome measure is the accuracy of PsUS elbow exams compared to X-ray or bedside nursemaid reduction in suspected fracture or subluxations. Secondary outcome measures include the feasibility of the study training and protocol for adequate image capture. The study will determine the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive value of PsUS in diagnosing pediatric elbow fractures.

Here is a summary of the clinical trial:

**Title:** The Efficacy of Probiotics for the Treatment of Alcohol Use Disorder Among Adult Males: A Comparison With Placebo and Acceptance and Commitment Therapy in a Randomized Controlled Trial

**Objective:** To evaluate the efficacy of probiotics, acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT), and placebo in treating alcohol use disorder (AUD) in adult males.

**Design:** A three-armed, parallel-group, single-blind, randomized controlled trial with a total of 360 participants.

**Interventions:**

1. Probiotic group: Participants received probiotics (Lactobacillus sp.) plus conventional drug therapy.
2. ACT group: Participants received ACT sessions plus conventional drug therapy.
3. Placebo group: Participants received a placebo (maltodextrin) plus conventional drug therapy.

**Primary outcomes:**

1. Change in AUDIT score across four time points.
2. Change in Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment for Alcohol-Revised (CIWA-Ar) score across four time points.
3. Change in Penn Alcohol Craving Scale (PACS) score across four time points.

**Secondary outcomes:**

1. Change in Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAMD) score across four time points.
2. Change in Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (HAMA) score across four time points.
3. Change in event-related potential (ERP) in EEG monitoring across four time points.
4. Change in serum tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) levels across four time points.
5. Change in fecal microbiota analysis across three time points.
6. Change in serum interleukin-1β (IL-1β) levels across four time points.
7. Change in serum interleukin-6 (IL-6) levels across four time points.

**Inclusion criteria:**

1. Male patients diagnosed with AUD.
2. Age 18-55 years old.
3. Han nationality.
4. Junior high school education or above.
5. Right-handed.

**Exclusion criteria:**

1. Patients with other mental illnesses.
2. Patients with allergy reactions to medications.
3. Patients with a history of organic brain disease, a pacemaker, gastrointestinal surgery, or serious health problems.
4. Patients with a history of seizures.
5. Patients with other drug dependence (except nicotine dependence).
6. Patients who have used prescription or over-the-counter drugs that may affect mood or alcohol cravings in the past 30 days.

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of Huaier granule in treating stage I primary ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal cancer after surgery, as well as its impact on quality of life and tolerability.

Title: Interaction of CYP2B6 Genotype and Efavirenz With Methadone and Tizanidine PK

Objective: To investigate the effect of CYP2B6 genotype and efavirenz on the metabolism, pharmacokinetics (PK), and pharmacodynamics (PD) of methadone and tizanidine in healthy volunteers.

Design: Open-label, two-period, fixed-sequence study with three genotype groups: normal metabolizers (NM), intermediate metabolizers (IM), and poor metabolizers (PM).

Methodology:

1. Baseline phase: Participants receive a single dose of methadone (10 mg) and tizanidine (4 mg) orally.
2. Efavirenz treatment phase: Participants receive 16 days of oral treatment with 600 mg/day efavirenz, followed by a single dose of methadone (10 mg) and tizanidine (4 mg) orally.

Primary outcome measures:

1. Stereoselective disposition of methadone
2. Disposition and pharmacodynamics of tizanidine

Secondary outcome measures:

1. Pharmacokinetic interactions between efavirenz and methadone and tizanidine
2. Pharmacodynamic effects of efavirenz on methadone and tizanidine

Inclusion criteria:

1. Healthy male and female volunteers between 18 and 65 years old
2. CYP2B6 genotype predicted phenotypes: NM, IM, or PM
3. Ability to adhere to study medication restrictions and provide informed consent

Exclusion criteria:

1. Underweight or overweight
2. Laboratory results outside normal range
3. Abnormal EKG readings
4. History of intolerance or allergic reactions to study medications
5. Positive pregnancy test (if female)
6. History of seizures, mental illness, or gastrointestinal disorders
7. Current use of prescription medications, over-the-counter medications, herbal supplements, or alternative medicines that may interact with study drugs
8. Employees or students under supervision of study investigators
9. Unable to commit to study requirements or provide informed consent

**Title:** A Randomised Crossover Clinical Trial to Compare the Effects of Different Storage Conditions on Removable Retainers

**Objective:** To compare the microbial colony counts, surface roughness, colour stability, compressive strength, and oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) of removable retainers stored in wet and dry conditions.

**Design:** A randomised crossover clinical trial with four groups: Hawley retainers in dry and wet storage conditions, and vacuum-formed retainers in dry and wet storage conditions. Each participant will undergo a crossover design, where they will switch from dry to wet storage or vice versa after three months.

**Methods:** 24 participants will be recruited and randomly assigned to one of the four groups. They will be instructed to store their retainers in either a dry retainer box or a glass of clean water for the entire time when not in use. The retainers will be analyzed for microbial colony counts, surface roughness, colour stability, and compressive strength at baseline, three months, and six months. OHRQoL will be assessed using a modified Oral Health Impact Profile (OHIP-14(M)) questionnaire at six months.

**Outcome Measures:** Primary outcome measures include microbial colony counts, and secondary outcome measures include surface roughness, colour stability, compressive strength, and OHRQoL.

**Conclusion:** This study aims to provide evidence-based guidelines for the storage method of removable retainers and to evaluate the effects of different storage conditions on the longevity and quality of life of orthodontic patients.

**Title:** Essential Connections: Hospital to Community Impacting Malnutrition Outcomes in Older Adults

**Objective:** To test the feasibility and impact of a new model of continuity of nutrition care for malnutrition treatment across settings, focusing on older adults with malnutrition, particularly those from vulnerable populations.

**Design:** Stepped wedge cluster-randomized trial with eight sites, recruiting patients aged 60 and older with malnutrition, who will receive either usual care or the new model of care, which includes enhanced continuity of nutrition care, cross-referrals, and data transfer between acute care hospitals and community meal provision organizations.

**Intervention:** Nutrition care by Registered Dietitians (RDNs) in both hospital and community settings, including medical nutrition therapy (MNT) and medically tailored meals (MTM).

**Outcome Measures:** Primary outcomes include quality of life, food security, and malnutrition risk, while secondary outcomes include program sustainability, RDN survey on barriers and facilitators to implementation, and changes in percent of patients receiving nutrition care and meals.

**Participation Criteria:** English or Spanish speaking, at risk for malnutrition, diagnosed with malnutrition, and eligible to receive Title III-C1 or Title III-C2 nutrition services. Exclusion criteria include patients receiving hospice care or end-stage cancer care, unable to consume meals, or not living within the meal provision organization's catchment area.

Title: Evaluation of Radiobiological Effects in Skin Toxicities for Breast Cancer Patients With Pencil Beam Scanning Proton Therapy

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of the Spot Delete technique in reducing radiation dermatitis in breast cancer patients treated with pencil beam scanning proton therapy compared to historical data.

**Title:** A Phase 1 Study of Peposertib (M3814) and Low-Dose Liposomal Doxorubicin (Doxil) in Patients With Metastatic Leiomyosarcoma and Other Soft Tissue Sarcomas

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and tolerability of peposertib in combination with low-dose liposomal doxorubicin in patients with metastatic leiomyosarcoma and other soft tissue sarcomas, and to determine the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of the combination.

**Design:** This is a dose-escalation study followed by a dose-expansion study. Patients receive peposertib orally twice daily and pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride intravenously once daily. Cycles repeat every 28 days in the absence of disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or withdrawal of consent.

**Eligibility:** Patients must have histologically confirmed sarcoma that is metastatic or unresectable, and have been treated with at least one prior line of therapy. Patients must also have an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 2 or less, and must not have a history of allergic reactions attributed to compounds of similar chemical or biologic composition to peposertib or other agents used in the study.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The primary outcome measures are the dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) rate at each tested dose level and the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of the combination.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The secondary outcome measures are the incidence of adverse events, objective response rate, and progression-free survival.

**Correlative Objectives:** The correlative objectives are to test the hypotheses that soft tissue sarcomas with homologous recombination deficiency (HRD) are more susceptible to deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)-PKi in combination with low-dose liposomal doxorubicin, and that gammaH2AX and pNBS1 can be used as pharmacodynamic biomarkers of response to DNA-PKi in combination with low-dose liposomal doxorubicin.

Title: Comparison of the Efficacy of Potassium-titanyl Phosphate (KTP) Laser vs KTP Laser and Ivermectin 1% Cream for Facial Rosacea: a Randomized Split-face Trial

Objective: To compare the efficacy of KTP laser therapy alone versus combined with ivermectin 1% cream in reducing erythema, improving skin lesions, and patient satisfaction in individuals with facial rosacea.

Design: Randomized, split-face trial with 1:1 allocation. Participants will receive either KTP laser therapy alone or combined with ivermectin 1% cream on one side of their face.

Interventions:

* Ivermectin 1% cream: Application of ivermectin 1% cream 1x/day, with interruption for 4 days in case of irritation/redness.

Primary Outcome Measure: Efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in reducing erythema as assessed by Normalized Erythema Index (NEI) at 16 weeks.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in reducing erythema, improving skin lesions, patient satisfaction, and reducing telangiectasia severity, papules, papulopustules, face swelling, face redness, and face purpura, as assessed by various scales and patient-reported outcomes.

Eligibility Criteria: Participants must have Fitzpatrick skin type I-IV, facial erythematous rosacea or mild papulopustular rosacea, and be willing to sign informed consent. Exclusion criteria include history of adverse events related to KTP laser therapy, pregnancy or breastfeeding, and ongoing treatment with certain medications.

This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of combining KTP laser therapy with ivermectin 1% cream for the treatment of facial rosacea.

The study will also examine the neurodevelopment of sFGR twins at two years of age and explore microscopic abnormalities in the placenta.

The study will recruit monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies complicated by sFGR diagnosed before 28 weeks of gestational age. The participants will undergo additional ultrasound measurements during pregnancy, and the primary outcome measure will be a composite outcome consisting of fetal single or double demise, including selective fetal reduction and/or an iatrogenic elective birth < 32 weeks of gestational age because of fetal distress.

The study will also assess secondary outcomes, including ultrasound parameters, prenatal and postnatal attachment, post-traumatic stress, and PARCA-R evaluation. The study will provide valuable insights into the pathophysiology of sFGR and its impact on parental mental health and parent-to-infant(s) attachment.

Title: Comparative Study Between Autogenous Bone Block and Tent Pole Technique for Augmentation of Atrophic Anterior Maxilla

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of screw tent-pole technique and autogenous bone block technique in augmenting atrophic anterior maxilla, assessing bone gain and quality.

Design: Randomized clinical trial with two parallel groups, 1:1 allocation ratio, and single-blinded design.

Interventions:

* Screw tent-pole technique: 5 Titanium screws are placed perpendicular to the alveolar bone, and a bone graft is placed between the screws. A PRF membrane is used to cover the bone graft.
* Autogenous bone block technique: A bone block is harvested from the ramus and placed in the defected anterior maxilla, stabilized with micro screws. A particulate autogenous bone graft is mixed with xenograft and placed between the bone block.

Primary Outcome Measure: Amount of bone gain before and after 6 months post-operative.

Secondary Outcome Measure: Bone quality evaluation through bone core biopsy after 6 months post-operative.

Eligibility Criteria: Systemically healthy patients with atrophic anterior maxilla, aged 18 years or older, with initial ridge width of ≤ 5 mm and moderate bone height.

Exclusion Criteria: Patients with bad oral hygiene, smokers, bone metabolic disease, or taking drugs that influence bone metabolism.

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of two techniques in augmenting atrophic anterior maxilla, with a focus on bone gain and quality.

**Title:** Accuracy in the Evaluation of Brain Response to Mechanical and Radiofrequency Stimuli in Humans

**Objective:** To evaluate the accuracy of brain response to radiofrequency (RF) and mechanical (pinprick) stimuli in humans, and to investigate the relationship between brain response parameters and psychophysical results.

**Outcome Measures:** Primary outcomes include latency and amplitude of EPs evoked by RF and pinprick stimuli. Secondary outcomes include changes in responses to somatosensory stimuli with pinprick thresholds and conduction velocity in radiofrequency stimuli.

**Duration:** Each experimental setting will last approximately 2 hours.

**Purpose:** The study aims to develop new, objective methods for evaluating the state of the nociceptive system, which could contribute to the understanding of chronic pain mechanisms.

Title: Imaging Characterization of the Biomechanical Coupling of Brain and Skull: An Observational Study

Objective: To characterize the biomechanical coupling of the brain to the skull in human volunteers with and without a history of traumatic brain injury (TBI) using magnetic resonance elastography (MRE).

Methods: The study will recruit 75 participants, including 25 individuals with a history of mild TBI with traumatic meningeal enhancement (TME+), 25 individuals with a history of mild TBI without TME (TME-), and 35 healthy controls. Participants will undergo MRE imaging to measure the relative motion of brain and skull while the head is vibrated at specified frequencies.

Endpoints: The primary endpoint is the completion of the MRE visit for each volunteer. Secondary endpoints include the measurement of skull-brain coupling using MRE and local measures of skull-brain coupling at the cortical surface.

Inclusion criteria: Participants must be between 21-65 years old, have a history of mild TBI or TME, and be deemed medically safe for study participation. Exclusion criteria include a history of clinically diagnosed TBI, known conditions that may affect brain anatomy, and contraindications to MRI.

The study aims to determine whether local shear strain measures within the cortex during MRE are altered in TME+ subjects and to characterize the biomechanical coupling of the brain to the skull in individuals with and without TBI.

**Title:** The Effect of Pharmacist-Initiated Home Blood Pressure Monitoring on Blood Pressure Control in Women

**Objective:** To determine the impact of home blood pressure monitoring, in addition to pharmacist care, on blood pressure control in women with elevated blood pressure.

**Design:** Randomized controlled trial with a 24-week intervention period, followed by a 28-week follow-up period.

**Participants:** Female patients aged 18 years or older with elevated blood pressure (systolic blood pressure ≥ 140 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 90 mmHg).

**Interventions:** Two groups:

1. Intervention group: Participants received a home blood pressure monitor and were followed up by a pharmacist every 4 weeks. The pharmacist reviewed their blood pressure readings and provided tailored education and therapy recommendations to their prescribing clinician.
2. Control group: Participants received usual pharmacist care, with no home blood pressure monitor. They were offered a home blood pressure monitor after 24 weeks and had the option to crossover to the intervention group.

**Outcomes:** Primary outcome measures include:

1. Difference in change in systolic blood pressure between the two groups at 24 weeks.
2. Proportion of patients at their blood pressure target at 24 weeks.

Secondary outcomes include:

1. Percentage of home blood pressure readings recorded.
2. Adherence to medications.
3. Changes to antihypertensive medication regimen.
4. Lifestyle changes.
5. Consultant satisfaction.

**Sample size:** 368 participants, with 184 participants in each group.

**Duration:** 52 weeks.

Title: The Role of Artificial Intelligence in Endoscopic Diagnosis of Esophagogastric Junctional Adenocarcinoma: A Single Center, Case-control, Diagnostic Study

Title: Study of Efficacy and Safety of FRSW107 in Pediatric Patients With Severe Hemophilia A

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of FRSW107, a recombinant human coagulation factor VIII-Fc fusion protein, in pediatric patients with severe hemophilia A.

Eligibility Criteria: Children aged 1-12 years with severe hemophilia A, who have received previous treatment with factor VIII and have had at least 6 months of treatment and detailed records of bleeding events.

Duration: The study will last for 1 year, with the option to continue treatment for up to 100 exposure days (EDs).

This study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of FRSW107 in pediatric patients with severe hemophilia A, and to evaluate its potential as a treatment option for this patient population.

The KRAUS study is a Phase 2 basket trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of a combination treatment consisting of oral sotorasib and intravenous panitumumab in patients with advanced solid tumors carrying the KRAS G12C mutation. The trial aims to assess the objective response rate based on RECIST v1.1 in patients with locally advanced or metastatic solid tumors who have progressed or are unresponsive to standard treatment options.

Eligible patients must have a histologically confirmed diagnosis of solid tumors, be at least 19 years old, and have a KRAS G12C mutation detected through local next-generation sequencing analysis. Patients must also have measurable lesions according to RECIST v1.1 and an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0 to 2. The trial will exclude patients with certain medical conditions, including active brain metastasis, leptomeningeal metastasis, significant cardiovascular events, and certain types of cancer.

The treatment regimen consists of oral sotorasib at a dose of 960 mg once daily, administered in combination with panitumumab at a dose of 6 mg/kg every 14 days. The primary outcome measure is the objective response rate based on RECIST v1.1, which will be assessed at the imaging tumor assessment time point after Cycle 1 Day 1.

**Study Overview**: This is a pragmatic trial designed to evaluate the effectiveness of a weekly supportive-expressive group therapy (SEGT) intervention for inpatients with limb loss. The trial aims to assess the impact of SEGT on mental health outcomes, including depression and anxiety, compared to treatment as usual (TAU).

**Intervention**: The SEGT intervention is a 6-module program that fosters mutual support, promotes openness, and emotional expression. It has been modified to specifically address the needs of limb loss inpatients. The program will be delivered and co-facilitated by a psychiatrist and/or two allied healthcare professionals.

**Eligibility Criteria**: Participants must be English-speaking, 18 years or older, admitted to St. John's Rehab inpatient, have any etiology and level limb loss, and be medically stable.

**Primary Outcome Measures**: The study will assess changes in Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) scores and Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-Item (GAD-7) scores at baseline, discharge, and 3 months post-discharge.

**Secondary Outcome Measures**: The study will also assess changes in PTSD Checklist-5 (PCL-5) scores and Generalized Self-Efficacy Scale (GSE) scores at the same time points.

**Study Design**: The study is a parallel assignment, randomized controlled trial with a single-blind design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the SEGT arm or the TAU arm.

**Sample Size**: The study aims to recruit 130 inpatients with limb loss, with 65 participants assigned to each arm.

**Data Collection**: Participants will be assessed using baseline measures within the first week of admission, and post-intervention and 3-month follow-up surveys will be completed by phone or Zoom.

**Study Overview**

The "Harnessing Human Potential and Improving Health Span in Women and Their Children" study aims to reduce the risk of Type 2 diabetes (T2D) and pre-diabetes in Asian women and their children, particularly those with a history of gestational diabetes (GDM). The study will assess the efficacy of a holistic lifestyle digital intervention, focusing on diet, physical activity, sleep, and mental well-being, in glucose regulation and overall health.

**Study Design**

The study is a 1-year randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a 3-year follow-up period. Eligible women (21-45 years old) with a history of GDM will be randomized to either an intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will receive a digital coaching program, the HAPPY App, and an Oura ring, while the control group will only receive the HAPPY App and an Oura ring.

**Primary and Secondary Outcomes**

The "Melphalan Chemoreduction for Ocular Melanoma" trial is a phase I clinical trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of intra-arterial melphalan chemotherapy followed by ruthenium brachytherapy in patients with choroidal melanoma. The trial aims to reduce tumor size and thickness, allowing for subsequent brachytherapy using a ruthenium plaque, thereby avoiding enucleation. Eligible patients have choroidal melanoma with a thickness of 8 mm or greater and are at risk of enucleation due to tumor size. The trial involves a single arm with 7.5mg of melphalan injected via intra-arterial catheterization of the ophthalmic artery, followed by ruthenium brachytherapy after 4±1 weeks. The primary outcome measures include treatment safety assessed through electroretinography (ERG), reduction of tumor size, and best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA). Secondary outcome measures include signs of intraocular inflammation, treatment-related adverse events, globe salvage, and other clinical outcomes. The trial is designed to assess the safety and efficacy of this novel treatment approach for patients with large choroidal melanomas.

Title: Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) Trial: Study Protocol for a Multicenter, Randomized, Controlled Trial to Compare Three Different Strategies of Mean Arterial Pressure Management During Cardiopulmonary By-pass

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of three different strategies of mean arterial pressure (MAP) management during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) in patients undergoing cardiac surgery.

Interventions:

* Standard MAP: MAP values between 50-60 mmHg
* High MAP: MAP values between 70-80 mmHg
* Patient-tailored MAP: MAP comparable to the patient's pre-operative MAP

Primary Outcome Measure:

* Serum lactate peak (Lmax) detected during CPB time

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Area under the curve (AUC) of serum lactate values during CPB
* Number of cases with serum lactate peak > 3 mmol/l during CPB
* Evaluation of intraoperative cerebral perfusion (through NIRS)
* Intraoperative pulmonary perfusion (through Pa/Fi ratio, paO2, paCO2 at ABG and VO2R and DO2 of CDI)
* Evaluation of intraoperative and postoperative low cardiac output syndrome (through VISmax)
* Postoperative and 30-day LVEF (%)
* Evaluation of pulmonary injury (through LIS)
* Postoperative and 30-day Acute Kidney Injury (according to AKIN score)
* Postoperative gastrointestinal ischemia
* Hepatic function and coagulation indexes
* Evaluation of neurological dysfunction
* In-hospital mortality and at 30 days from surgery

Eligibility Criteria:

* Elective surgery
* Index of surgical risk Euroscore II < 9%
* Preserved or mildly reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF ≥ 40%) at preoperative echocardiography
* Estimated Glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) ≥ 40 ml/min/mq calculated using the Modification of Diet in Renal Disease formula (MDRD)
* Signed informed consent

Sample Size:

* 999 patients (333 per group)

Study Design:

* Multicenter, randomized, controlled trial
* Parallel assignment
* Open-label design

Duration:

* Study duration: 5 years
* Follow-up duration: 30 days from surgery

**Title:** Effectiveness of START (Startle Adjuvant Rehabilitation Therapy) in Enhancing Arm Function Post-Stroke

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of START, a low-cost and accessible therapy, in enhancing arm function in individuals with stroke, particularly those with severe stroke.

**Design:** Randomized controlled trial with two arms: Experimental (START) and Sham Comparator (Control).

**Participants:** Individuals with stroke (at least 6 months prior) and severe-to-mild upper extremity impairment, aged 18-99 years.

**Intervention:** Participants in the Experimental arm will receive START, which involves the application of a startling, acoustic stimulus during a functional reaching task. Participants in the Sham Comparator arm will receive a sham control, practicing the same task without the START intervention.

**Outcome Measures:** Primary outcomes include changes in electromyography (EMG) onset, EMG amplitude, movement onset, movement linearity, and functional reaching task scores. Secondary outcomes include retention of functional reaching task scores and skill transfer to untrained tasks (sorting and dressing).

**Significance:** The study aims to provide a low-cost and accessible therapy option for individuals with stroke, particularly those with severe stroke, and to improve their arm function and overall quality of life.

The NET RETREAT trial is a Phase II study comparing the effectiveness of 177Lu-DOTATATE peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT) with everolimus in patients with metastatic, unresectable midgut neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) who have progressed after previous PRRT. The primary objective is to evaluate the effect of 177Lu-DOTATATE versus everolimus on progression-free survival (PFS). Secondary objectives include assessing toxicity and safety, overall response rate, overall survival, post-progression survival, and time to second objective disease progression.

The trial will enroll patients who have received 3-4 cycles of PRRT and have radiological progression per RECIST 1.1. Patients will be randomized to receive either 177Lu-DOTATATE every 8 weeks or everolimus daily. The trial will assess the primary endpoint of PFS using Kaplan-Meier methods and compare the difference between the two treatment arms using a one-sided stratified log-rank test. Secondary endpoints will include overall survival, objective response rate, post-progression survival, and time to second objective disease progression.

The trial aims to enroll patients with metastatic, unresectable midgut NETs who have progressed after previous PRRT, and will assess the effectiveness of 177Lu-DOTATATE versus everolimus in improving PFS and other outcomes.

The study aims to estimate the 2-year event-free survival (EFS) and objective response rate (ORR) of patients with NPC who receive induction chemoimmunotherapy (CIT), followed by consolidation chemoradioimmunotherapy (CRIT) and nivolumab maintenance therapy.

The study also aims to evaluate various exploratory endpoints, including 5-year EFS and overall survival (OS), response assessed by fludeoxyglucose F18 (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET) versus magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and treatment outcomes for patients receiving different radiation therapies.

**Design**

The study is an open-label, single-group assignment trial with a single arm. Patients will receive nivolumab, gemcitabine, and cisplatin, followed by radiation therapy. The study will enroll patients with newly diagnosed NPC, aged 0 to 21 years, with American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) stage II-IV disease.

**Eligibility Criteria**

Patients must be ≤ 21 years of age, have a Lansky or Karnofsky performance status score of ≥ 60%, and have no evidence of dyspnea at rest or exercise intolerance. Patients with a history of autoimmune disease, immunodeficiency, or chronic hepatitis B or C infection are excluded.

**Study Plan**

The study will enroll approximately 30 patients and will be conducted over a period of approximately 5 years. Patients will be followed up every 3 months for 12 months, every 6 months until 24 months off therapy, and then yearly until 5 years off therapy.

**Objective:** To compare the effectiveness of a dual-hormone artificial pancreas (AID) system, which uses both insulin and glucagon, with a single-hormone AID system, which uses only insulin, in controlling blood glucose levels in adults with type 1 diabetes during exercise and meal challenges.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The study will also measure various secondary outcomes, including time spent within the target range, glycemic variability, and the amount of insulin and glucagon administered during the study.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Participants must be between 18 and 65 years old, have type 1 diabetes, and be on continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion (CSII) treatment for at least 6 months prior to the study.

**Title:** Effectiveness of Transcranial Electrical Stimulation in the Functional Recovery of Subjects With Subacromial Pain Syndrome: Randomized Clinical Trial.

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of transcranial electrical stimulation (TES) combined with strengthening exercises in improving pain, functionality, and quality of life in patients with subacromial pain syndrome.

**Design:** Randomized, triple-blind, controlled trial with 64 participants aged 18-65 years with subacromial pain syndrome.

**Interventions:** Participants were randomly assigned to either a treatment group (Experimental: Strengthening + a-TES) or a control group (Sham Comparator: Strengthening + a-TES placebo). The treatment group received 24 sessions of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) combined with strengthening exercises, while the control group received sham tDCS and strengthening exercises.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Changes in pain and disability index (SPADI), Western Ontario Rotator cuff (WORC) scale, and visual analog scale (VAS) for shoulder pain intensity.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Changes in shoulder muscle strength, active range of motion, joint position sense, head forward posture, shoulder protraction, kyphosis, subacromial space width, scapulohumeral rhythm, and mean signal amplitude and frequency of scapulothoracic muscles.

**Duration:** 8 weeks, with follow-up evaluations at 3 months post-intervention.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Age 18-65 years, duration of pain ≥ 3 months, presence of 3 or more positive clinical tests for shoulder pain.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Previous shoulder or neck surgery, history of shoulder fracture or dislocation, medical diagnosis of shoulder osteoarthritis, adhesive capsulitis, cervicobrachialgia, or contraindications for transcranial electrical stimulation.

**Study Overview**

The study is a randomized, open-label, controlled trial comparing the efficacy and safety of Dorzotimol eye drops (20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL) with Cosopt eye drops (20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL) in patients with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG).

**Objectives**

The primary objective is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Dorzotimol eye drops in reducing elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) in patients with POAG.

**Design**

The study is a multicenter, parallel-arm trial with 110 patients randomized to receive either Dorzotimol eye drops or Cosopt eye drops for 12 weeks.

**Endpoints**

The primary endpoint is the mean IOP change from baseline. Secondary endpoints include IOP reduction rate to the target level of ≤ 18 mm Hg, IOP reduction rate greater than 20%, and IOP reduction rate greater than 30%.

**Results**

The study found that Dorzotimol eye drops were noninferior to Cosopt eye drops in reducing IOP and showed similar safety profiles. The results indicate that Dorzotimol eye drops can be used as an effective treatment option for patients with POAG.

**Conclusion**

The study concludes that Dorzotimol eye drops are noninferior to Cosopt eye drops in reducing IOP and demonstrate similar safety profiles, making them a viable treatment option for patients with POAG.

**Study Title:** Evaluate RCN3028 in Treatment of Drug-Induced Moderate to Severe Vasomotor Symptoms in Breast Cancer Subjects

**Objective:** To determine the efficacy and safety of RCN3028 in treating moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes) in breast cancer patients receiving tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors.

**Study Design:** Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group, Phase 2 trial.

**Population:** Female breast cancer patients aged 20-80 years, with a confirmed diagnosis of breast cancer, receiving tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors, and experiencing 7 or more moderate to severe hot flashes per day or 50 per week at baseline.

**Interventions:** Participants will receive either RCN3028 0.8 mg or placebo capsules, with a 14-day placebo-run-in period, followed by titration to 0.8 mg for maintenance.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Mean change in frequency and severity of moderate to severe hot flashes from baseline to weeks 4 and 12.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Menopause-specific quality of life, responder rates, time to onset of efficacy, subject and physician global assessments, treatment-emergent adverse events, and changes in weekly weighted severity score, number of hot flashes, and nighttime awakenings.

**Duration:** 12 weeks.

Title: Are Higher Doses of Tranexamic Acid Associated With a Lower Incidence of Post-operative Delirium After Cardiac Surgery? A Retrospective Cohort Study

Objective: To investigate whether higher doses of Tranexamic Acid (TXA) are associated with a lower incidence of post-operative delirium after cardiac surgery.

Design: Retrospective cohort study

Population: Patients undergoing elective or in-house urgent cardiac surgery at RPH between 05/2018 and 08/2022

Intervention: TXA

Primary Outcome Measure: Richmond Agitation Sedation Score (up to 48 hours after surgery)

Secondary Outcome Measure: 30-day mortality (up to 30 days after surgery)

The study aims to explore the relationship between TXA dose and post-operative delirium in cardiac surgery patients, using routinely collected data from hospital electronic systems. The results will inform the design of a future prospective randomized controlled trial comparing different TXA dosing regimens in cardiac surgery.

The study aims to compare the effects of myofascial decompression therapy and positional release therapy on pain, range of motion, and functional disability in patients with chronic non-specific neck pain. The study will recruit patients aged 25-50 years with mild to moderate neck pain and trigger points within the muscle. Participants will be randomly assigned to either myofascial decompression therapy or positional release therapy groups. Both treatments will be administered for 15 minutes, three times a week, for four weeks.

The primary outcome measures will be the Numerical Rating Scale (NPRS) for pain intensity and the Neck Disability Index (NDI) for functional disability. Secondary outcome measures will include range of motion (ROM) of the cervical spine in flexion, extension, side flexion, and rotation.

The study aims to determine the comparative effects of myofascial decompression therapy and positional release therapy on pain, ROM, and functional disability in patients with chronic non-specific neck pain, and to provide insight into the most effective form of exercise for rehabilitation.
