Title: A Randomized Parallel-controlled Study Comparing the Ileostomy Dumpling Suture Method With Traditional Suture Method in Rectal Anterior Resection Surgery With Specimen Extraction Via Stoma

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of the Ileostomy Dumpling Suture Method and Traditional Suture Method in reducing stoma complications in patients undergoing rectal anterior resection surgery with specimen extraction via stoma.

Design: Randomized, parallel-controlled, open-label study with two arms: Dumpling Suture Method and Traditional Suture Method.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients aged 18-100 years, scheduled for rectal anterior resection surgery with specimen extraction via stoma, and expected survival time > 6 months.

Primary Outcome Measure: Complication rate of stoma at 30 days after surgery.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Stoma DET score, stoma pain score, and quality of life scale score for patients with stoma at 30 days after surgery.

The study aims to investigate whether the Ileostomy Dumpling Suture Method is more effective than the Traditional Suture Method in reducing stoma complications and improving patient quality of life.

The study uses a range of assessments, including neuropsychological tests, to evaluate cognitive function, ADL impairment, and non-motor symptoms. The primary outcome measures include the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD) or mild cognitive impairment in Parkinson's disease (PD-MCI), while secondary outcome measures include the Pfeffer Activities of daily living scale, follow-up score in global cognition, and follow-up cognitive domain performance.

**Title:** Investigating the Effects of Dietary Phospholipids on Measures of Human Brain Health and Psychological Wellbeing

**Objective:** To evaluate the effects of dietary phospholipids on cognitive function, mood, and psychological wellbeing in healthy adults aged 25-49 years.

**Design:** Randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel groups design with 220 participants.

**Intervention:** Participants will receive either 40g of bioactive whey protein concentrate powder containing dairy phospholipids or a matched placebo powder for 12 weeks.

**Outcome Measures:** Primary outcomes include cognitive function (cognitive domain factor scores), mood (Profile of Mood States, Perceived Stress Scale, and Depression, Anxiety, and Stress Scale), and psychological wellbeing (Cohen-Hoberman Inventory of Physical Symptoms and Patient-Reported Outcome Measurement, Information System Sleep Disturbance Scale). **Inclusion Criteria:** Healthy adults aged 25-49 years who are fluent in English and have no pre-existing medical conditions that would impact participation.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Participants with a history of neurological disorders, learning or behavioral disorders, or those taking certain medications or supplements that may interact with the study treatments.

**Study Duration:** 12 weeks, with assessments at baseline, 6 weeks, and 12 weeks.

Title: Presence of Environmental Pollutants in Human Carotid Atherosclerotic Plaques and Their Relationship With the Plaque Phenotype and Clinical Outcomes

Objective: To investigate the presence of environmental pollutants (microplastics and volatile organic compounds) in carotid atherosclerotic plaques and their relationship with plaque phenotype and clinical outcomes in patients with carotid stenosis undergoing carotid endarterectomy.

Methodology:

* 300 patients with asymptomatic carotid stenosis will be enrolled and undergo a baseline clinical examination, computed tomography or MRI, and health record collection.
* Carotid plaque specimens will be obtained and analyzed for the presence of microplastics and volatile organic compounds using pyrolysis-gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, transmission electron microscopy, immunohistochemistry, ELISAs, and Western Blot.
* Patients will be categorized as having polluted or non-polluted plaques, and Cox regression analysis will be used to examine the association between pollutant presence and incidence of a composite outcome (myocardial infarction, stroke, and all-cause mortality).
* Secondary outcome measures include the incidence of the composite outcome according to terciles of pollutant burden.

Eligibility Criteria:

* Patients with carotid stenosis (>70%) undergoing carotid endarterectomy
* Exclusion criteria: heart failure, valvular defects, malignant neoplasms, or secondary causes of hypertension

Study Duration: 24 months

The Liver Care Trial is a randomized controlled study aiming to screen for liver disease in individuals attending treatment for alcohol use disorder (AUD). Title: Five Days for Health (FDH): Small Group-based Lifestyle Modification Program on Weight Loss

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of a 5-day small group-based lifestyle modification program on weight loss and related outcomes in overweight and obese adults.

Design: Single-group, open-label study with a 12-month follow-up period.

Eligibility: Participants must be between 18 and 70 years old, have a BMI between 25-45, and be interested in participating in a weight loss program. Keywords: obesity, overweight, lifestyle modification, weight loss, small group program, multidisciplinary team.

**Title:** A Phase I Study of BIO-008 Injection for Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, Immunogenicity, and Antitumor Activity in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, immunogenicity, and antitumor activity of BIO-008 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

**Design:** Open-label, non-randomized, dose-escalation study with 7 dose groups (0.3mg/kg, 1.0mg/kg, 3.3mg/kg, 10.0mg/kg, 20.0mg/kg, 30.0mg/kg, and 40.0mg/kg) of BIO-008 administered intravenously every 3 weeks.

**Population:** Patients with advanced solid tumors who have failed standard therapy or are not suitable for standard therapy.

**Key Inclusion Criteria:** Patients aged 18-75 years with a confirmed diagnosis of advanced solid tumors, who have failed standard therapy or are not suitable for standard therapy, and who have a Karnofsky Performance Status (KPS) of 0-1.

**Key Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with a history of allergic reactions to similar products, patients who have received other clinical trial drugs or treatments within 28 days prior to the first dose, patients with a history of severe cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases, and patients with active infections or autoimmune diseases.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Adverse events, incidence of dose-limiting toxicity, maximum tolerated dose, and objective response rate.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Pharmacokinetic characteristics, immunogenicity, disease control rate, duration of response, and progression-free survival.

**Study Overview:** This is a multicentric, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase III clinical trial to assess the safety and efficacy of Sovateltide in patients with acute cerebral ischemic stroke (ACIS).

**Objective:** To evaluate the efficacy of Sovateltide in patients with ACIS, as measured by the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score at day 90 post-randomization.

**Design:** The study will enroll patients with ACIS who are within 24 hours of stroke onset and have a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of ≥ 8 and < 20. Patients will be randomized to receive either Sovateltide or normal saline (vehicle) as an IV bolus dose over 1 minute within 24 hours of stroke onset. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with a good outcome (mRS score of 0-2) at day 90 post-randomization.

**Secondary Outcomes:** The study will also assess secondary outcomes, including excellent outcome (mRS score of 0-1), improvement in functional outcome (NIHSS, mRS, and Barthel Index scores), quality of life (EuroQol-EQ-5D and Stroke-Specific Quality of Life scores), incidence of recurrent cerebral ischemic stroke, mortality, radiographic or symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage, and adverse events.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Patients aged 18-80 years with ACIS, radiologically confirmed, and within 24 hours of stroke onset, with NIHSS score of ≥ 8 and < 20, and NIHSS Level of Consciousness (1A) score < 2.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with intracranial hemorrhage, comatose patients, known pregnancy or lactating women, confounding pre-existing neurological or psychiatric disease, and concurrent participation in another therapeutic clinical trial.

**Study Timeline:** The study will enroll patients over a period of approximately 12 months, with follow-up visits at days 6, 30, 60, and 90 post-randomization.

**Title:** Methotrexate for Immune Related Arthritis or Arthralgias (IMPACT 2.1)

**Objective:** To evaluate the efficacy and safety of methotrexate in patients with immune-related arthritis or arthralgias who have developed recurrent grade ≥ 2 irAA or remain on glucocorticoids for irAA at 3 months.

**Title:** Comparison of the Effects of General and Regional Anesthesia on Sleep Quality in Patients Planning Total Hip Arthroplasty

**Objective:** To evaluate the effects of general anesthesia (GA) and regional anesthesia (RA) on sleep quality in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty (THA) and to determine which type of anesthesia is more effective in maintaining good sleep quality.

**Methodology:** This randomized controlled trial will enroll 60 patients aged 18 years or older undergoing elective THA. Patients will be randomized to receive either GA or RA. Sleep quality will be assessed using the Pittsburgh Insomnia Rating Scale (PIRS-20) at three time points: one month before surgery, the day before surgery, and one week after surgery. Anxiety and pain levels will also be evaluated using standardized scales.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Subjective sleep quality, evaluated by PIRS-20.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Subjective anxiety level, evaluated by the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI), and subjective pain level, evaluated by the Visual Analog Scale (VAS).

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients planning THA, aged 18 years or older, with an American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) score between I-III.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with urgent indication for THA, patients under 18 years of age, patients with ASA score 4 or above, and patients who refuse to participate in the study.

**Study Design:** This is a randomized, parallel-group, triple-masked study with two arms: general anesthesia and regional anesthesia.

**Title:** Evaluating Efgartigimod in Patients With Guillain-Barré Syndrome

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and efficacy of efgartigimod, an anti-neonatal Fc receptor (FcRn) immunoglobulin G1 Fc fragment, compared to intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg), in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).

**Design:** This is a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, controlled, single-site trial with two arms: efgartigimod (20mg/kg on days 1 and 5) and IVIg (0.4g/kg daily for 5 days).

**Eligibility Criteria:** Patients with a diagnosis of GBS, aged 18 years or older, with a GBS Disability Scale (GBS-DS) score of 3, 4, or 5, and onset of GBS-related weakness within 14 days prior to infusion.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The primary outcome measures are the GBS-DS score at 12 weeks and the number and seriousness of adverse events through study completion.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Secondary outcomes include GBS-DS scores at 4, 24, and 48 weeks, Neuropathy Impairment Scale (NIS) scores, Inflammatory Rasch-Built Overall Disability Scale (I-RODS) scores, and pulmonary function tests (FVC, MIP, and MEP) at 4, 24, and 48 weeks.

**Study Plan:** The study will enroll patients and randomize them to receive either efgartigimod or IVIg. Patients will undergo regular assessments, including physical examinations, vital sign measurements, and laboratory tests, throughout the 48-week study period.

Title: Evaluation of the Therapeutic Effect of Adding Letrozole to the Protocol of Combined Treatment of Cesarean Scar Pregnancy

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of adding letrozole to the treatment protocol for cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) in reducing blood loss and complications during hysteroscopic evacuation of products of conception (POC).

Design: Prospective cohort study with two arms: MTX monotherapy and MTX + letrozole add-on. Women with CSP were randomly assigned to receive either MTX alone or MTX with letrozole (5 mg orally for 10 days). Blood parameters were measured on days 0, 4, 7, and every 7 days until surgery.

Primary outcomes: Blood loss during the procedure, blood loss volume, and conversion rate from hysteroscopy to laparoscopy or laparotomy due to hemorrhage.

Secondary outcomes: Effect of treatment on bone marrow function, liver function, and kidney function.

Eligibility criteria: Women with CSP confirmed on pelvic ultrasound, increasing B-hCG concentrations, and consent of the Bioethics Committee for termination of CSP. Exclusion criteria included heterotopic pregnancy and decreasing B-hCG concentrations.

Study population: Women aged 18-45 years with CSP.

Conclusion: This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of adding letrozole to the treatment protocol for CSP in reducing blood loss and complications during hysteroscopic evacuation of POC.

Title: Comparison of Quadriceps Strengthening and Kinesiotaping on Gait in Knee Osteoarthritis

Objective: To compare the effects of concentric quadriceps strengthening and facilitatory kinesiotaping on gait parameters in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.

Design: Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study with two arms: concentric quadriceps strengthening (group A) and facilitatory kinesiotaping (group B).

* Functional Status (WOMAC Questionnaire) at 6 weeks.
* Strength (quadriceps strength measured using a handheld dynamometer) at 6 weeks.

The study aims to compare the effects of two interventions on gait parameters, pain, functional status, and strength in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.

Title: A Preliminary Clinical Study of Freshly Manufactured 35kDa Hyaluronan Fragment in the Treatment of Herpes Zoster Pain and Shoulder, Neck, Back and Temporal Pain

Objective: To evaluate the analgesic effect of freshly manufactured 35kDa Hyaluronan fragment HA35 on herpes zoster pain and shoulder, neck, back, and temporal pain.

Design: Single-group, open-label, investigator-initiated clinical study.

Population: 26 patients with shoulder, neck, back, and temporal pain, and 10 patients with herpes zoster pain, aged 39-63 years.

Intervention: HA35 injection (100mg Hyaluronan + 2000 units hyaluronidase) was administered locally at the pain point or nerve trunk innervation.

Outcome Measures: Primary outcome was pain scores assessed using a 0-10 scale, evaluated at 30 seconds and 3 hours post-treatment.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients with shoulder, neck, back, and temporal pain, or herpes zoster pain, with disease duration ≤8 months.

Exclusion Criteria: Patients with severe spinal pathology.

The study aimed to investigate the safety and efficacy of HA35 in treating various types of pain, including herpes zoster pain, and shoulder, neck, back, and temporal pain.

**Title:** Hysteroscopic Septoplasty by Different Modalities: A Randomized Clinical Trial

**Objective:** To compare the effectiveness and safety of two different modalities of hysteroscopic septoplasty (resection of the septum) in treating women with a septate uterus and recurrent pregnancy loss or subfertility.

**Design:** Prospective, randomized, controlled trial with two arms: scissors and resectoscope.

**Population:** Women of reproductive age (18-45 years) with a diagnosis of septate or subseptate uterus and a history of recurrent pregnancy loss, subfertility, or preterm birth.

This randomized controlled trial investigates the effect of bicarbonate profiling in dialysis fluid on phosphate removal during hemodialysis and blood pH in patients with phosphorus metabolism disorders and acid-base balance disorder. The study enrolled 20 chronic hemodialysis patients who were randomly assigned to one of two groups. Each group underwent four 4-hour hemodialysis treatments with varying bicarbonate levels: constant 35 mmol/L, alternating between 35 and 30 mmol/L, or alternating between 30 and 35 mmol/L. The primary outcome measure is the change in blood phosphorus concentration, and the secondary outcome measure is the maintenance of acid-base balance. The study aims to determine the optimal bicarbonate profiling strategy for improving phosphate removal during hemodialysis and maintaining acid-base balance in patients with end-stage renal disease.

Title: Boosting Psychotherapy Effects by Means of Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of a multimodal intervention for treating unipolar depression by combining transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) with metacognitive therapy (MCT).

Design: Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study with three arms: tDCS alone, MCT alone, and combination of tDCS and MCT.

Interventions:

* tDCS: Non-invasive neurostimulation technique applying a low-amperage electric current to the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.
* MCT: Metacognitive therapy based on the metacognitive model, using attention training techniques, detached mindfulness, and behavioral interventions on metacognitions.

Primary Outcome Measure: Change in Hamilton Depression Rating Scale scores at end of treatment and follow-up (1, 3, 6, and 12 months).

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* TMS-EEG correlates of change in depressive symptomatology in a subgroup of patients.
* Changes in various scales and neuropsychological tests, including Beck Depression Inventory, SCL-90, Remorse Rating Scales, and others.

Eligibility Criteria: Participants must have a DSM-5 diagnosis of Major Depressive Disorder, be between 18-65 years old, and able to provide informed consent.

The study aims to evaluate the potential additive/synergistic effect of combining tDCS and MCT, as well as the TMS-EEG correlates of change in depressive symptomatology.

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness and safety of proton pump inhibitor (PPI) use in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with moderate gastrointestinal bleeding risk, and to compare the incidence of gastrointestinal and cardiovascular events between patients receiving PPI and those not receiving PPI.

Keywords: proton pump inhibitor, percutaneous coronary intervention, gastrointestinal bleeding of moderate risk, dual anti-platelet drugs.

Title: Dry Needling vs Lasertherapy in Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome (GTPS): Randomized Clinical Trial

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of dry needling and laser therapy in reducing pain and improving function in patients with lateral hip pain (GTPS) who have had symptoms for at least 3 months.

Methodology:

* Randomized, double-blind clinical trial
* Participants will be assigned to either dry needling or laser therapy groups
* Each group will receive 6 weeks of treatment, 2 times a week
* Primary outcome measures include pain intensity (VAS), hip function (VISA-G), and lower limb function (TUG and 30'' Sit To Stand Test)
* Secondary outcome measures include quality of life and functional assessment

Inclusion criteria:

* Lateral hip pain (VAS 3) for at least 3 months
* Pain refers to the insertion of the tendon of the middle and maximum gluteus in the major trochanter
* Symptoms reproduced in at least one of the following tests: FABER, Resistive External Rotation, Resistive Isometric Abduction, and Unipodal Support

Exclusion criteria:

* Surgery on lower limbs or spine in the last 12 months
* Symptoms of osteoarthritis or intra-articular disease of the hip
* Infiltration of the hip with corticosteroids in the last 6 months
* Received physical therapy for this condition in the past three months
* Need to use anti-inflammatory drugs

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of dry needling and laser therapy in reducing pain and improving function in patients with GTPS.

Title: Pilot Study of the RAPID AFib Decision Aid for Stroke Prevention in Atrial Fibrillation

Objective: To evaluate the acceptability and impact of the RAPID AFib decision aid on shared decision-making for stroke prevention therapy in patients with recent onset atrial fibrillation (AF).

Eligibility Criteria: Patients with non-valvular AF diagnosed within 12 months, with any level of stroke risk assessed by CHA2DS2-VASc score, and initial specialist AF visit scheduled in 7-30 days.

**Title:** A Phase I, Randomized, Placebo-controlled Study to Assess the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, and Pharmacodynamics of NNC0491-6075 in Healthy Participants and Participants with Dyslipidaemia.

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of NNC0491-6075 in healthy participants and participants with dyslipidaemia after single and multiple doses.

**Design:** This is a phase I, randomized, placebo-controlled study with three parts: Part A (single ascending dose in healthy participants), Part B (multiple ascending dose in participants with dyslipidaemia), and Part C (single ascending dose in healthy Japanese participants).

**Eligibility Criteria:** Healthy participants aged 18-55 years and participants with dyslipidaemia aged 18-64 years are eligible to participate. Participants must have a body mass index (BMI) between 18.5 and 34.9 kg/m² and meet other inclusion criteria.

**Interventions:** Participants will receive either NNC0491-6075 or placebo as a single or multiple dose via subcutaneous or intravenous injection.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The primary outcome measures are the number of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) in each part of the study.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The secondary outcome measures include pharmacokinetic parameters such as area under the curve (AUC), maximum serum concentration (Cmax), terminal half-life (t½), and time to maximum concentration (tmax) of NNC0491-6075.

**Duration:** The study will last approximately 110-131 days, depending on the part of the study.

This randomized controlled trial aims to evaluate the efficiency of high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) versus non-invasive ventilation (NIV) in patients with acute type 2 respiratory failure (RF). The study includes 100 adult patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure, defined as pH >7.25 and <7.35 and PCO2 >45mmHg. Patients were randomly assigned to either the HFNC group or the NIV group and received either high-flow oxygen therapy or non-invasive ventilation, respectively.

The primary outcome measure is the failure of treatment modality, defined as failure to improve pH within 1 hour. Secondary outcomes include mortality and ICU stay at 28 days. The study uses various devices and interfaces, including Airvo 2, Precision flow Hi-VNI, and Puritan Bennett 840 ventilator, as well as oronasal masks and nasal cannulas. The trial aims to determine which treatment modality is more effective in improving patient outcomes in acute type 2 RF.

**Title:** ImpleMEntation of a Digital-first Care deLiverY Model for Heart Failure in Uganda

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of a digital-first care delivery model for heart failure patients in Uganda, combining enhanced clinical care with a digital health intervention.

**Design:** Randomized, open-label trial with a mixed-methods process evaluation to inform iterative adjustments to the implementation processes.

**Population:** Patients with clinical diagnosis of New York Heart Association (NYHA) Class II-III heart failure, aged 18 years and above, with access to a mobile phone and basic reading skills.

**Interventions:** Two arms:

1. **Core-HF**: Enhanced clinical care bundle for heart failure patients, including training for clinical care providers and self-care training for patients.
2. **Medly Uganda**: Digital health intervention, including a patient-facing mobile application and clinician-facing internet dashboard, designed to improve self-care among patients with heart failure.

**Outcomes:** Primary outcomes include changes in Self-Care of Heart Failure Index (SCHFI) and clinical effectiveness (composite of mortality and heart failure hospitalization). Secondary outcomes include various measures of patient and facility fidelity, clinical markers, and quality of life.

**Duration:** 3 years, with follow-up assessments at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, 18 months, 24 months, 30 months, and 36 months.

Title: Comparative Pharmacokinetic (PK) Study of Ibuprofen and Diphenhydramine Hydrochloride MR Tablets in Healthy Adults Under Fasting Condition

Objective: To compare the pharmacokinetic profiles of Ibuprofen and Diphenhydramine Hydrochloride Modified-Release Tablets (400mg/50mg) with Motrin IB (Ibuprofen Tablets USP 200mg) and Benadryl (Diphenhydramine Hydrochloride Tablet 25mg) in healthy adults under fasting conditions.

Design: Open-label, balanced, randomized, single-dose, two-treatment, two-sequence, two-period, two-way crossover study.

Population: 16 healthy adults aged 18 years or older, including both male and female participants.

Interventions: Participants received either Ibuprofen and Diphenhydramine Hydrochloride Modified-Release Tablets (400mg/50mg) or Motrin IB (Ibuprofen Tablets USP 200mg) and Benadryl (Diphenhydramine Hydrochloride Tablet 25mg) under fasting conditions.

Primary Outcome Measures: Area under the curve from time zero to the time of the last quantifiable plasma concentration of the period (AUC0-last), Area under the curve from time zero to infinity (AUC0-inf), and Peak concentration at each treatment period (Cmax,tp).

Secondary Outcome Measures: Peak concentration of the first dosing (Cmax), Time to reach peak concentration of the first dosing (Tmax), Terminal half-life (T1/2), and Mean residence time (MRT).

Conclusion: This study aims to evaluate the pharmacokinetic profiles of Ibuprofen and Diphenhydramine Hydrochloride Modified-Release Tablets compared to Motrin IB and Benadryl in healthy adults under fasting conditions.

**Title:** iSTAR: Phase 1b Trial of Idasanutlin and Selinexor Therapy For Children With Progressive/Relapsed Atypical Teratoid Rhabdoid Tumors, Extra-CNS Malignant Rhabdoid Tumors Or Synchronous/Metachronous Rhabdoid Tumors

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of the combination therapy of idasanutlin and selinexor in children with relapsed or progressive atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumors (AT/RT) or malignant rhabdoid tumors (MRT).

**Design:** Open-label, non-randomized, phase 1b trial with three strata: patients with AT/RT, MRT, or synchronous/metachronous AT/RT and MRT.

**Interventions:** Patients will receive idasanutlin once daily on Days 1-5 of a 28-day cycle, starting with 80% of the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) determined in the ongoing pediatric iMATRIX trial. Selinexor will be administered on Day 4 of each of the first 3 weeks of a 28-day cycle, with a break in week 4.

**Primary Outcome Measures:**

1. Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of combination treatment with oral idasanutlin and selinexor in children with recurrent or progressive AT/RT or MRT.
2. Idasanutlin plasma apparent systemic clearance (CL/F) and area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUC) in children with recurrent or progressive AT/RT or MRT.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:**

1. Objective response rate in subjects with progressive/relapsed AT/RT or MRT.
2. Progression-free survival and overall survival in subjects with progressive/relapsed AT/RT or MRT.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Children aged 6 months to 25 years with relapsed or progressive AT/RT or MRT, who have failed at least one frontline therapy and have measurable disease. Patients must have adequate organ function and be able to swallow oral medication or have a nasogastric or gastrostomy tube for medication administration. Females of childbearing potential must have a negative pregnancy test and agree to use effective contraception during the study and for 28 weeks after treatment.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18-65 years with stages II and III disease, who have undergone a thorough medical evaluation to ensure they do not have any serious medical conditions, severe osteoporosis, or other contraindications.

The study is a randomized, open-label trial with two arms: one involving radial shortening and the other involving capitate shortening. The primary outcome measure is the Modified Mayo Wrist Score, which assesses wrist pain, hand grip, work status, and range of motion at one year post-surgery.

The "Prehabilitation in Pancreatic Surgery" study is a randomized controlled trial aiming to evaluate the effectiveness of a 4-week multimodal prehabilitation program in improving functional capacity, nutritional status, and patient-reported health-related quality of life in patients with pancreatic cancer undergoing surgery. The program includes physical exercise, nutritional therapy, and anxiety-reducing techniques.

The study will recruit 226 patients with pancreatic or periampullary cancer who are undergoing surgery. Patients will be randomized to either the intervention group, which will receive the prehabilitation program, or the control group, which will receive usual care. The primary outcome measures will be the Comprehensive Complication Index (CCI), functional capacity, and pro-inflammatory cytokines.

The prehabilitation program will consist of a personalized intervention program, including exercise training, nutritional therapy, and anxiety-reducing techniques. Patients will follow a two-to-three-day-per-week training schedule for four weeks, and will receive dietary advice and oral nutritional supplements to achieve estimated daily energy and protein requirements.

The study will assess various outcomes, including postoperative complications, functional capacity, nutritional status, and patient-reported health-related quality of life. The study will also evaluate the impact of prehabilitation on circulating molecules involved in cancer cachexia and skeletal muscle wasting.

The study aims to demonstrate that the prehabilitation program can reduce postoperative complications, improve functional capacity, and enhance patient-reported health-related quality of life in patients with pancreatic cancer undergoing surgery.

Title: The Effectiveness of Dual Task Exercise Training on Balance, Mobility, Physical Performance and Quality of Life in Children With Cerebral Palsy

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of dual task exercise training in addition to conventional rehabilitation on balance, mobility, physical performance, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy.

Design: Randomized, parallel-group study with two arms: Experimental (dual task exercise training) and Control (conventional rehabilitation only).

Population: Children with cerebral palsy, aged 5-12 years, with Gross Motor Function Classification (GMFCS) level 1 or 2, who are able to understand simple commands and sign the consent form.

Interventions:

* Experimental arm: Conventional rehabilitation (stretching, strengthening, balance) plus dual task exercise training (simple math during active stretching, carrying a ball while on a balance pad) for 12 weeks, 3 days a week.
* Control arm: Conventional rehabilitation only for 12 weeks, 3 days a week.

Outcome measures:

* Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS)
* Timed Up and Go Test (TUG)
* One Leg Standing Test (OLST)
* 3-Meter Backward Walk Test (3MBWT)
* 6-Meter Walk Test (6MWT)
* Generic Children's Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire (KINDL)

Primary outcome measures are the changes in PBS, TUG, OLST, 3MBWT, and 6MWT at 12 weeks. The study aims to assess the effectiveness of dual task exercise training in improving balance, mobility, physical performance, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy.

Title: Active Surveillance of Influenza Virus Zoonotic Transmission Events: a Pilot Study in Belgium

Objective: To monitor and detect zoonotic transmission of influenza viruses from animals to humans in Belgium.

Design: A pilot study with active surveillance in four sentinel networks: Avian Influenza Outbreak Farms, Poultry Farm Sentinel Network, Wild Bird/Life Rehabilitation Centre Sentinel Network, and Pig Industry Veterinarian Sentinel Network.

Participants: Workers and volunteers from these networks who are in regular contact with animals and are willing to participate in the study.

Interventions: Participants will perform self-sampling with a nasopharyngeal swab every 2 days (outbreak participants) or every 2 weeks (sentinel participants) for a duration of 2 weeks (outbreak participants) or the entire study duration (sentinel participants). They will also provide a blood sample for serological testing.

Outcomes: The study will measure the number of participants positive for non-seasonal influenza viruses, as detected by RT-qPCR and serological tests.

The study aims to investigate the relationship between decidual leukocyte subpopulations and their associated activation markers in women who have experienced a miscarriage, specifically those with a trisomy 16 conceptus or a chromosomally normal male conceptus. The study aims to evaluate the acceptability, cost-effectiveness, and required capacity of a facility-based seasonal influenza vaccination program in Bangladesh. The study will be conducted in nine tertiary-level hospitals across Bangladesh and will enroll high-risk groups, including children aged 6-8 years, pregnant women, elderly individuals aged 60 years or older, and adults with chronic diseases. The study will assess the acceptability of the vaccine using a health belief model survey, and will estimate the cost-effectiveness of the vaccine using a cost-effectiveness analysis. The study will also collect data on the costs associated with influenza illness, including direct and indirect medical costs, and will estimate the disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) gained or saved by the vaccine. The study will use a quasi-experimental design, with a vaccination campaign conducted in one hospital and no vaccination campaign conducted in the other hospital. The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

The study includes patients aged 18 years or older who are willing and able to provide informed consent and undergo a clinically indicated procedure. The primary outcome measures are technical performance and procedural performance, assessed over a 24-month period. The study aims to investigate the safety and effectiveness of single-use duodenoscopes in clinical practice.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the Hybrid Pulmonary Rehabilitation Study:

The study aims to evaluate the feasibility of a hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) program, which combines in-person and remote exercise and education, in patients with chronic respiratory disease. The program uses the Active+me REMOTE App, which includes remote tracking of adherence, symptoms, and physiological parameters, as well as live and pre-recorded exercise classes, educational programs, and personalized care plans.

The study will recruit patients with chronic respiratory disease who are referred to the Harefield Pulmonary Rehabilitation Programme and will compare outcomes between patients who receive the hybrid PR program and those who have previously received standard PR. The primary outcomes will be patient recruitment rates, participant retention rates, and the success of propensity matching of the control group.

Secondary outcomes will include patient uptake of the hybrid PR program, pulmonary rehabilitation class sessions completed, dropout rates, changes in exercise capacity, adherence to the program, symptoms, disease knowledge, lower limb function, health-related quality of life, anxiety, and depression.

The study will also assess the feasibility of integrating the hybrid PR program into routine practice and its acceptability to patients and staff. The study will provide evidence to support a larger trial to compare the effectiveness of hybrid PR versus standard PR delivery models on patient outcomes and service capacity.

The study is expected to include approximately 280 patients and will provide real-world data on the use of EVUSHELD as PrEP in Japan.

**Title:** Study to Assess the Safety and Efficacy of Subcutaneously Injected Risankizumab in Adult Participants With Genital or Scalp Psoriasis

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and efficacy of risankizumab in treating adult participants with moderate to severe genital or scalp psoriasis.

**Design:** This is a Phase 4, multicenter, randomized, double-blind study with parallel assignment. Participants will receive either risankizumab or placebo for 16 weeks, followed by risankizumab for an additional 36 weeks.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Participants must have a clinical diagnosis of chronic plaque psoriasis with or without psoriatic arthritis, and have a current diagnosis of moderate to severe genital or scalp psoriasis.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The study will assess the percentage of participants who achieve a static Physician Global Assessment of Genitalia (sPGA-G) of 0 or 1, and the percentage of participants who achieve a Scalp Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) of 0 or 1.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The study will also assess various secondary outcomes, including the percentage of participants who achieve a Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI) of 0 or 1, and the percentage of participants who achieve a Clinically Meaningful (≥ 4-point) Improvement from Baseline on the Genital Psoriasis Itch Numerical Rating Scale (NRS).

**Keywords:** Genital Psoriasis, Scalp Psoriasis, Plaque Psoriasis, Psoriasis, ABBV066, Skyrizi, Risankizumab.

Title: A Study to Assess the Adverse Events and Change in Disease Activity of Oral Atogepant Tablets in Pediatric Participants (6-17 Years of Age) With Episodic Migraine

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of atogepant for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in pediatric subjects aged 6-17 years.

Design: Phase 3, multicenter, 12-week, double-blind, placebo-controlled study with an open-label PK substudy.

Population: Pediatric participants with episodic migraine, aged 6-17 years, with a history of at least 6 months of migraine and 4-14 migraine days in the 28-day baseline period.

Title: Combination of Paclitaxel-bevacizumab ± Atezolizumab in Patients With Advanced NSCLC Progressing After Immunotherapy & Chemotherapy

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of paclitaxel-bevacizumab with or without atezolizumab in patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who have progressed after immunotherapy and chemotherapy.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients must have a histologically or cytologically confirmed diagnosis of locally advanced or metastatic NSCLC, be at least 18 years old, have an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0 or 1, and have received prior treatment with immunotherapy and chemotherapy.

Intervention: Patients will be randomized to receive either paclitaxel-bevacizumab alone or paclitaxel-bevacizumab with atezolizumab. Paclitaxel will be administered at a dose of 200 mg/m² every 3 weeks, and bevacizumab will be administered at a dose of 15 mg/kg every 3 weeks. Atezolizumab will be administered at a dose of 1200 mg every 3 weeks.

Primary Outcome Measure: Progression-free survival (PFS) at 6 months, as determined by an independent reviewer.

Secondary Outcome Measures: PFS, objective response rate (ORR), overall survival (OS), time until definitive health-related quality of life score deterioration, incidence, nature, and severity of adverse events, and overall health status.

This study aims to investigate the efficacy and safety of paclitaxel-bevacizumab with or without atezolizumab in patients with advanced NSCLC who have progressed after immunotherapy and chemotherapy.

Title: Pilot Study: Prospective Comparison of ICG Microangiography and Conventional Angiography in Severe Frostbite

Objective: To compare the accuracy of Indocyanine Green (ICG) microangiography and conventional angiography in diagnosing and assessing ischemic tissue in patients with severe frostbite.

Methodology: The study will enroll adult patients with severe frostbite who are undergoing thrombolysis. Patients will undergo both conventional angiography and ICG microangiography, and the images will be scored using the Hennepin Frostbite Score. The primary outcome measure will be the concordance between the two imaging modalities in demonstrating ischemic tissue. Secondary outcomes will include the safety of ICG dye when delivered in close association with contrast dye.

Population: Adult patients (≥18 years old) with severe frostbite who are undergoing thrombolysis.

Inclusion criteria: Patients must have been diagnosed with severe frostbite by conventional angiography, be clinically sober, and have normal kidney function.

Exclusion criteria: Pregnant patients or patients with an iodine allergy.

Duration: The study will be conducted over a period of approximately 2 years.

The study aims to compare the diagnostic accuracy of ICG microangiography and conventional angiography in severe frostbite patients, and to assess the safety of ICG dye when used in conjunction with contrast dye.

Objective: To evaluate the impact of a multidisciplinary approach in the Perioperative Geriatrics Unit (GPOU) on the functional status of patients aged 70 and over operated on for colorectal cancer.

Design: Randomized open-label controlled study

Participants: Patients aged 70 and over with proven colorectal cancer undergoing scheduled colorectal surgery at the University Hospital of Nîmes.

Intervention: Patients were randomly assigned to either the control group (classical management in the digestive surgery department) or the GPOU group (treatment in the Perioperative Geriatrics Unit to optimize specific geriatric care).

Title: Pilot Trial Using 64Cu-DOTA Pembrolizumab (64CDP) in Patients Receiving Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy for Oligo-Progressive Solid Tumors

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab (64CDP) in patients with metastatic solid tumors receiving stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT).

Design: Open-label, single-group assignment trial.

Eligibility: Patients with metastatic solid tumors, Karnofsky performance status ≥ 70, and receiving single-agent pembrolizumab. Exclusion criteria include patients with planned treatment interruption or discontinuation of pembrolizumab, active infection, or immunosuppressive medication use.

Interventions: Patients receive standard-of-care pembrolizumab at baseline, followed by 64CDP on days 1 and 29, and undergo PET scans on days 2 and 30. Patients also receive SBRT on days 8-18.

Primary outcomes: Dose-limiting toxicities, changes in 64CDP uptake, change in standard-uptake-value (SUV-max), and incidence of adverse events.

Duration: Average of 6 weeks.

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of left bundle branch area pacing in patients with heart failure and ejection fraction below 50%.

**Title:** Quantitation and Spatial Registration of Airways Dysfunction With Dynamic 19F MRI in Cystic Fibrosis

**Objective:** To evaluate the use of dynamic 19F MRI in quantifying and spatially registering airways dysfunction in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF).

**Design:** This is a single-arm, open-label study that will enroll patients with CF who are at least 18 years old and have a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Participants will undergo 19F MRI scans at multiple time points, including at baseline, Day 14, and Day 365. The scans will be used to measure ventilation defect parameters (VDP) and functional lung volume (FLVlongtau2) over time.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The study will assess changes in VDP and FLVlongtau2 over 14 days and 365 days, as well as changes in these measures occurring with a protocol-defined CF pulmonary exacerbation.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The study will also evaluate changes in MRI severity score over 365 days and the correlation of MRI severity score with VDP and FLVlongtau2 at baseline.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients must be at least 18 years old, non-smokers, have a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, stable lung function, and no pulmonary exacerbations in the past 4 weeks.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with certain medical conditions, such as active or past smoking, certain metal implants, or claustrophobia, will be excluded from the study.

Title: A Bioequivalence Trial of Fasting Single Oral STI-1558 Capsule in Healthy Chinese Subjects

Objective: To evaluate the bioequivalence of a test preparation of STI-1558 capsule with a reference preparation in healthy Chinese subjects under fasting conditions.

Design: Randomized, open-label, single-dose, two-sequence, two-cycle, double-cross design bioequivalence study.

Participants: 32 healthy adult Chinese subjects aged 18-45 years, with a body mass index (BMI) of 19-24 kg/m2, and no history of significant medical conditions or use of medications that may affect the absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion of oral drugs.

Intervention: Subjects will receive either the test preparation or the reference preparation of STI-1558 capsule, 200 mg once, on day 1 and day 8, after an overnight fast of at least 10 hours.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Comparison of maximum observed concentration (Cmax) profiles of the test and reference preparations
* Comparison of area under the curve (AUC) from time 0 to last time point (AUC0-t) profiles of the test and reference preparations
* Comparison of AUC from time 0 extrapolated to infinity (AUC0-inf) profiles of the test and reference preparations

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Comparison of time to maximum concentration (Tmax) of the test and reference preparations
* Comparison of half-life (t1/2) of the test and reference preparations
* Comparison of lambda-z (λz) of the test and reference preparations
* Comparison of percentage of AUC extrapolated to infinity (%AUCex) of the test and reference preparations

Duration: Up to 2 weeks.

This study aims to establish the bioequivalence of the test preparation of STI-1558 capsule with the reference preparation in healthy Chinese subjects under fasting conditions.

Title: Effectiveness of Detachment of the Breathing Circuit on the Rate of DLT Malposition After Postural Change

This randomized controlled trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of detaching the breathing circuit on the rate of double-lumen endotracheal tube (DLT) malposition in patients undergoing thoracic surgery. The study enrolled patients aged 18-65 years who required a left-sided DLT and were undergoing elective surgery. The primary outcome measure was the rate of DLT malposition, defined as more than 5 mm away from the optimal position. The secondary outcomes included effects of lung collapse, blood oxygen saturation, and length of stay in the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU).

The study involved two arms: the experimental arm, where the breathing circuit was detached when the patient's position was changed from supine to lateral, and the control arm, where the breathing circuit was maintained. The study found that detaching the breathing circuit reduced the rate of DLT malposition and improved lung collapse and blood oxygen saturation.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with severe depressive episodes, psychiatric comorbidities, or suicidal risk, and those with contraindications to telemedicine.

Title: Comparative Evaluation of Microneedling Alone vs Microneedling Along with Hyaluronic Acid in Thin Gingival Phenotype: A Split-Mouth Randomized Clinical Trial

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of microneedling alone versus microneedling with hyaluronic acid in increasing gingival thickness in patients with thin gingival phenotype.

Design: Split-mouth randomized controlled trial with 20 patients, each with two sites randomly assigned to either the microneedling alone group or the microneedling with hyaluronic acid group.

Interventions: Microneedling with 30-gauge lancet needles 1 mm below the gingival margin, with or without injection of cross-linked hyaluronic acid. Procedure will be repeated three times with 10-day intervals.

Outcome Measures: Primary outcome measure is the measurement of gingival thickness (GT) at 9 months. Secondary outcomes include keratinized tissue width, gingival index, bleeding on probing, and probing depth.

Inclusion Criteria: Thin gingival phenotype with gingival tissue thickness <1 mm in mandibular anteriors, healthy gingiva, and willing to participate in the study.

Exclusion Criteria: Systemic diseases, smoking, tobacco use, previous periodontal surgery, haematological disorders, use of blood thinners, and use of drugs that might lead to gingival enlargement.

**Study Overview:** This is a Phase 2a, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial investigating the efficacy and safety of methylprednisolone in patients with cognitive deficits in post-COVID-19 syndrome (PCS). The study aims to demonstrate improvement in memory satisfaction as measured by the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire (MMQ) in patients with PCS treated with methylprednisolone compared to placebo.

**Study Design:** The study is a two-arm, parallel-group design with 52 weeks of follow-up. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either methylprednisolone or placebo for 6 weeks, followed by an additional 6 weeks of open-label methylprednisolone treatment. The primary outcome measure is the improvement in memory satisfaction as measured by the MMQ.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Participants must have a history of confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection, ongoing symptoms of PCS for at least 3 months, and self-reported cognitive deficits. They must also be 18 years or older and willing to provide informed consent.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Participants with ongoing central nervous system disease, major psychiatric disease, or certain medical conditions are excluded from the study.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** The primary outcome measure is the improvement in memory satisfaction as measured by the MMQ, with a change of 15 points or more from baseline to week 8 considered a meaningful improvement.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The study will also assess long-term improvement in memory satisfaction, memory ability, memory strategy, neurocognitive functions, quality of life, physical and mental fatigue, and mood.

**Study Significance:** This study has the potential to benefit individuals with PCS by exploring the effects of methylprednisolone on cognitive impairment and fatigue, and may provide crucial insights into the pathophysiological processes of PCS, leading to the development of more effective therapies and improved patient outcomes.

Title: Analysis of the Aetiological Factors of Malnutrition: Inflammation and Oral Intake

Objective: To investigate the relationship between inflammation and malnutrition in patients with disease-related malnutrition (DRM) and to assess the effectiveness of a dietary supplement rich in omega-3 and olive oil polyphenols in improving nutritional status and reducing inflammation.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients with DRM diagnosed according to GLIM criteria, presence of an inflammatory response (CRP > 3 mg/dl), and candidate for medical nutritional treatment.

Exclusion Criteria: Pregnant or breastfeeding women, patients with advanced liver cirrhosis or chronic hepatitis, patients with advanced neoplastic disease, patients with renal insufficiency, and patients taking certain medications.

Primary Outcome Measures: Blood biochemistry data, including albumin, prealbumin, C-reactive protein, ferritin, neutrophils, lymphocytes, and platelets.

Additionally, functional parameters, such as test up and go, dynamometry, and oral intake data, including energy, protein, carbohydrate, fat, monounsaturated fatty acids, polyunsaturated fatty acids, EPA, DHA, and fibre.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of the dietary supplement in improving nutritional status, reducing inflammation, and improving functional parameters in patients with DRM.

Title: A Phase II/III Study to Evaluate the Immunogenicity and Safety and Efficacy of SWIM816 Vaccines for SARS-CoV-2

Objective: To evaluate the immunogenicity, safety, and efficacy of a heterologous booster dose of SWIM816 vaccine compared to Pfizer Bivalent vaccine in previously vaccinated subjects against COVID-19.

Design: This is a randomized, double-blinded, parallel controlled trial with two phases: Phase II and Phase III.

* Phase II: Immunogenicity measured by GMTs of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron and related strain neutralizing antibody levels for SWIM816.
* Phase III: Non-inferiority of neutralizing antibody response in terms of GMT of COVID-19 mRNA vaccine (SWIM816) compared to mRNA COVID-19 vaccine (Pfizer Bivalent vaccine) 14 days post dose.

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Safety and efficacy of the vaccines, including the occurrence of local and systemic adverse events, unsolicited adverse events, and serious adverse events.

Duration: The study will be conducted over a period of 180 days.

**Study Overview:**
This is a Phase I safety and feasibility study evaluating the use of autologous T cells lentivirally transduced to express L1CAM-specific chimeric antigen receptors (CARs) in treating patients with locally advanced and unresectable or metastatic small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer.

**Objective:**
The primary objectives are to assess the safety and feasibility of the treatment, including the incidence of adverse events, dose-limiting toxicity rates, and objective response. Secondary objectives include evaluating radiographic progression-free survival and overall survival.

**Design:**
The study is an open-label, single-group assignment trial with a dose-escalation design. Patients will undergo leukapheresis to obtain peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) for T cell product manufacturing. They will then receive lymphodepleting chemotherapy followed by an autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cell infusion. Patients may receive additional lymphodepletion chemotherapy and T cell infusions based on disease response and persistence of CAR T cells.

**Eligibility Criteria:**
Patients must be ≥ 18 years old, have a confirmed diagnosis of small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer, and have received prior platinum-based chemotherapy. They must also have adequate performance status, expected survival > 3 months, and measurable disease.

**Interventions:**
The treatment consists of autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cells, lymphodepleting chemotherapy (cyclophosphamide and fludarabine or bendamustine), and bridging therapy (if necessary). Patients will also undergo echocardiography, multigated acquisition scan, computed tomography, bone scan, and blood sample collection throughout the trial.

**Outcome Measures:**
The primary outcome measures are incidence of adverse events, dose-limiting toxicity rates, objective response, radiographic progression-free survival, and overall survival.

The study, titled "Improving Alcohol and Substance Use Care Access, Outcome, Equity During the Reproductive Years: A Type 1 Hybrid Trial in Family Planning Clinics", aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral to Treatment (SBIRT) program in family planning clinics to improve alcohol and substance use care access, outcomes, and equity among reproductive-aged women. The study will be conducted in a large Northeastern regional affiliate and its four clinics, with a national reach to a diverse and largely structurally disadvantaged population.

The SBIRT program will be implemented in two phases: implementation and sustainment. During the implementation phase, providers will receive training and support to deliver the SBIRT program, and patients will be screened for risky alcohol and substance use behaviors. Those who screen positive will receive a brief intervention, and those who screen at a severe level will receive a referral to specialty addiction treatment.

**Study Overview**

The study is a Phase 1, open-label trial evaluating the pharmacokinetics, safety, and tolerability of ARV-471 in Chinese participants with ER+/HER2- advanced breast cancer.

**Eligibility Criteria**

Participants must have a histological or cytological diagnosis of breast cancer with evidence of ER+/HER2- locally advanced or metastatic disease, and have received at least one line of standard of care (SOC) endocrine therapy with or without a CDK4/6 inhibitor. Up to two prior regimens of chemotherapy for advanced or metastatic disease are allowed.

**Study Design**

The study is a single-arm, open-label design with a single treatment arm: ARV-471 administered orally once daily with food for 28-day cycles. The primary objective is to assess the pharmacokinetics of ARV-471.

**Primary Outcome Measures**

The primary outcome measures include:

1. Single-dose pharmacokinetic parameters (Cmax, AUCtau, Tmax, AUClast, CL/F, Vz/F, t½)
2. Multiple-dose pharmacokinetic parameters (Cmax, AUCtau, Tmax, Vz/F, MRCmax, Rac, t½eff, CL/F, t½)

**Secondary Outcome Measures**

The secondary outcome measures include:

1. Objective response rate (ORR)
2. Percentage of participants with clinical benefit
3. Duration of objective response (DOR)
4. Presence or absence of blood biomarkers
5. Number of participants with notable electrocardiogram (ECG) values
6. Number of participants with laboratory abnormalities
7. Number of participants with clinically significant changes from baseline in vital signs
8. Number of participants with adverse events (AEs) by type, frequency, severity, timing, and seriousness

**Study Timeline**

The study will enroll participants for approximately 24 weeks, with a maximum treatment duration of 28 days per cycle. The study will assess participants up to 100 weeks after the first dose of study drug.

* Objective response rate (ORR) in Cohort 3

* PFS in Cohort 3

* Concordance of diagnostic tumor mutation profile in both Cohorts 2 and 3

**Title:** A Randomized Controlled Trial of Schema Therapy for Patients With Chronic Treatment Resistant Depression

**Objective:** To investigate whether Schema Therapy (ST) of longer duration (up to 30 sessions) outperforms Treatment as Usual (TAU) for patients with chronic and treatment-resistant depression (CTRD) on depression outcomes at 12 months after baseline measurements.

**Design:** This is a multi-center, two-arm, parallel group, assessor-blinded, randomized controlled superiority study.

**Interventions:** Participants will be randomized to either Schema Therapy (ST) or Treatment as Usual (TAU). ST will consist of up to 30 individual, weekly sessions of consecutive Schema Therapy. TAU will be standard care package content, including prescription and monitoring of psychopharmacological treatment, as well as up to 3 hours of preparatory and diagnostic sessions and up to 4 hours of meetings with the participation of next-of-kin and/or collaboration partners in other public instances.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Change from baseline in depression symptoms on the clinician-rated Hamilton-6 Rating Scale for Depression at 12 months after baseline measurements.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Changes in depression symptoms, functional impairment, psychological well-being, personal recovery, anger processing, repetitive negative thinking, anxiety symptoms, health-related quality of life, and schema modes as mediators of treatment effect.

**Sample Size:** A total of 129 participants will be randomized to either ST or TAU.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Participants must have a diagnosis of chronic or treatment-resistant depression, with a minimum score of 9 points on the Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression 6 (HAMD-6) and a minimum score of 6 on the Maudsley Staging Model (MSM) scale.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Participants with a history of alcohol or substance abuse, bipolar or psychotic disorder, acute suicidal risk, mental disability (estimated IQ < 70), or non-Danish speaker will be excluded.

**Duration:** The study will last for 24 months, with assessments at baseline, 6 months, 12 months, and 24 months after baseline.

Title: Paramedical Protocol for Ventilation in Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome

Study Overview:
This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, controlled, open-label, phase III trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a paramedical protocol for ventilation in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study involves 28-day follow-up and assesses the primary endpoint of mortality rate and number of days without mechanical ventilation.

Eligibility Criteria:
The study includes patients aged 18 years or older with ARDS, intubated and mechanically ventilated, and evolving for less than 72 hours. Exclusion criteria include long-term oxygen therapy, pneumothorax, documented pulmonary embolism, and ARDS refractory to inclusion.

Study Design:
The study is a stepped wedge cluster randomized design, where clusters (hospitals) receive the intervention sequentially over several periods. The order of intervention is randomly assigned, and all clusters receive the intervention at some point during the study.

Intervention:
The experimental group receives ventilatory adjustments by nurses according to a pre-established care protocol, while the control group receives usual care.

Primary Outcome Measures:
The primary endpoint is a composite of mortality rate and number of days without mechanical ventilation at 28 days.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
The study also assesses various secondary outcomes, including measures of tidal volume, plateau pressure, PEEP, FiO2, oxygenation, and duration of mechanical ventilation, among others.

Keywords:
The study keywords include acute respiratory distress syndrome, ARDS, paramedical care protocol, and mortality.

Title: Uptake of the Childhood Live Attenuated Influenza Vaccine (LAIV) and Influenza-related Healthcare Resource Use in England During the 2012 to 2022 Flu Seasons; a Retrospective, Observational Study in the CPRD and HES Databases

Objective: To evaluate the uptake of influenza vaccines, including LAIV, in children aged 2-17 years in England between 2012 and 2020, and to describe healthcare resource use associated with laboratory-confirmed influenza and influenza-like illness (ILI) in these children.

Methodology: This retrospective, observational study used data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD) and Hospital Episode Statistics (HES) databases to analyze the uptake of LAIV and healthcare resource use in children aged 2-17 years in England between 2012 and 2020.

Primary outcome measures: The study aimed to evaluate the proportion of eligible individuals receiving a flu vaccine (LAIV, QIV, or other) in each flu season.

Secondary outcome measures: The study also aimed to describe healthcare resource use associated with ILI, including GP consultations, laboratory-confirmed influenza, Admitted Patient Care (APC) episodes, Accident and Emergency (A&E) attendances, outpatient attendances, length of stay in APC, antibiotic prescriptions, and antiviral prescriptions.

The study will provide up-to-date epidemiological evidence on the uptake of LAIV and its impact on healthcare resource use related to ILI in children in England, which may be used by the National Health Service (NHS) for planning and evaluation of the childhood influenza vaccination program.

Title: A Digitally Assisted Risk Reduction Platform for Youth at High Risk for Suicide

Objective: To test the effectiveness of a digitally assisted risk reduction platform, called Vira, in reducing suicidal behaviors and improving clinical outcomes among youth at high risk for suicide.

Design: This is a pragmatic randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 200 adolescent patients aged 13-18 years old, randomized to either the Vira group or the treatment as usual (TAU) control group. Participants will receive intensive outpatient treatment, and all treatment decisions will be overseen by practitioners within the program.

Intervention: The Vira platform uses mobile sensing data and HIPAA-compliant client communication tools to provide a unique understanding of risk factors, including psychological distress, anhedonia, and behavioral withdrawal, and sleep disturbance. Patients will be asked to use Vira for the duration of their intensive outpatient treatment, and practitioners will provide support and just-in-time reminders to arrive in the user's phone to support their behavior change plan and DBT treatment.

Primary Outcome Measures: The study will assess suicidal thoughts and behaviors using the Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS) and the Scale for Suicidal Ideation (SSI) at 6 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures: The study will also assess anxiety, risky behaviors, sleep quality, mood, and social anhedonia using various self-report questionnaires at 3 and 6 months.

Keywords: Depression, Depressive Disorder, Mood Disorders, Mental Disorders, Suicidal Behaviors, Suicidal Thoughts, Suicidal Ideation.

**Title:** Open-label, Single-center, Single-arm Futility Trial Evaluating Daily Remote Ischemic Conditioning for Reducing Progression of Disability in Patients With Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS)

**Objective:** To investigate whether remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) treatment can prevent disability worsening in patients with Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS) by reducing progression of disability, as measured by the timed 25-foot walk (T25FW).

**Design:** Phase II open-label, single-center, single-arm futility trial following the Simon-2-stage MiniMax design.

**Intervention:** Participants will undergo daily RIC sessions for 12 months, using an electric auto-control device with a blood pressure cuff that inflates up to 200 mmHg during the ischemic period.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Worsening of disability, defined as an increase by 20% or more in the T25FW at 12 months follow-up compared to baseline.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Nine Hole Peg Test, MRI measure of remyelination, and Single Digit Modalities Test (SDMT).

**Eligibility Criteria:** Patients with Primary Progressive MS, aged 18-65 years, with a screening Expanded Disability Status Scale score between 4.0 and 6.5, and a screening T25FW of 5.5 seconds or more. Exclusion criteria include patients with known renal or hepatic impairment, allergy to gadolinium, or current use of immune-modulators, anticoagulation, or certain medications.

The SMaRT Mom study is a randomized, controlled trial designed to investigate the effectiveness of a smartphone management and responsive time intervention for breastfeeding mothers. The study aims to reduce smartphone addiction and improve mother-infant interaction during breastfeeding.

The study will recruit 40 breastfeeding mothers aged 20-40 years with infants aged 3-6 months and a Smartphone Addiction Scale score of 31 or above. The mothers will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group.

The intervention group will receive a one-week program that includes instructions not to use their smartphone during breastfeeding, daily reports of distractions while breastfeeding, and remote sessions with a research assistant. The control group will not receive any intervention.

The primary outcomes measured will be infant temperament and maternal self-efficacy. Secondary outcomes will include breastfeeding as a rewarding experience, maternal attention towards the infant, and changes in breastfeeding mothers' neural activity, physiology, and behavior.

The study will use a range of measures, including questionnaires, behavioral observations, and physiological recordings, to assess the outcomes. The results will provide insights into the effects of the intervention on breastfeeding mothers and their infants, and may inform the development of interventions to support mothers in managing their smartphone use during breastfeeding.

**Title:** Photobiomodulation Therapy for Plantar Fasciitis: A Single-Blind Randomized Control Trial

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) in reducing pain and improving function in patients with plantar fasciitis.

**Design:** Single-blind randomized control trial with two arms: active PBMT and sham PBMT.

**Participants:** 54-year-old or younger, with plantar fasciitis diagnosed by a healthcare provider, and able to commit to 6-week intervention and 3- and 6-month follow-up.

**Intervention:** Participants will receive either active PBMT or sham PBMT, three times a week for 3 weeks.

**Key Inclusion Criteria:** Diagnosis of plantar fasciitis, ability to read and understand English, and commitment to study procedures.

**Key Exclusion Criteria:** Pregnancy, history of traumatic injury to the foot, significant portion of calf area covered in tattoos/ink/scarring, history of neuropathy, and current use of medications associated with sensitivity to heat or light.

Title: Bioequivalence Study of Entacapone, Levodopa and Carbidopa Tablets in the Postprandial State in Healthy Chinese Subjects

Objective: To evaluate the bioequivalence of test and reference preparations of Entacapone, Levodopa, and Carbidopa tablets in healthy Chinese subjects in the postprandial state.

Design: Single-center, open, randomized, single-dose, completely repeated crossover study.

Population: Healthy adult Chinese subjects aged 18 years or older, weighing at least 45 kg for females and 50 kg for males, with a body mass index (BMI) between 19.0 and 28.0 kg/m2.

Inclusion criteria: Volunteers who have signed an informed consent form, are willing to participate, and meet the above physical and demographic criteria.

Exclusion criteria: Subjects with a history of serious medical conditions, abnormal physical examination, vital signs, electrocardiogram, or clinical laboratory tests, or those with allergies to the study medications.

Interventions: Subjects will receive either the test or reference preparation of Entacapone, Levodopa, and Carbidopa tablets in a randomized, crossover design.

Outcome measures: Peak plasma concentration (Cmax), area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUC0-t), and area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUC0-∞) will be evaluated.

Duration: The study will be conducted over a period of at least 10 hours, with a washout period of at least 2 days between doses.

The study aims to assess the bioequivalence of the test and reference preparations of Entacapone, Levodopa, and Carbidopa tablets in healthy Chinese subjects in the postprandial state.

Title: Effect of Weight Loss on Hepcidin Levels and Iron Status in Subjects With Obesity.

Objective: To investigate the impact of weight loss on hepcidin levels and iron status in individuals with obesity and iron deficiency.

Design: A randomized controlled clinical trial with two arms: a calorie-restricted diet with red meat and a calorie-restricted diet without red meat. Participants will be recruited from those identified in a cross-sectional study who exhibit iron deficiency.

Inclusion Criteria: Adults with obesity (BMI 30-40 kg/m2) and serum iron < 50 micrograms/dL, with no history of diabetes, kidney disease, or other conditions that may affect iron metabolism.

Intervention: Participants will receive a calorie-restricted diet (reducing caloric intake by less than 25% of resting energy expenditure) with either red meat or without red meat, for 60 days. All participants will also receive ferrous sulfate 200mg every 48 hours for three months to correct iron-deficiency anemia.

Outcome Measures: Primary outcomes include changes in serum hepcidin concentration, serum iron concentration, and other iron status markers. Secondary outcomes include changes in inflammatory markers, oxidative stress markers, and metabolic parameters such as body weight, fat mass percentage, and waist circumference.

Duration: The study will consist of two phases: a cross-sectional study (Phase 1) and a randomized controlled clinical trial (Phase 2). The total study duration is approximately 6 months.

The NIEM-O Study is a non-randomized, single-center, prospective cohort intervention study that aims to investigate the effectiveness of continuous non-invasive electrophysiological monitoring (eCTG) using the Nemo Fetal Monitoring System (NFMS) in high-risk pregnancies. The study will enroll 1911 pregnant women aged 18 years or older with a singleton pregnancy between 23+0 and 32+0 weeks of gestation who require hospitalization on the obstetric high care (OHC) for maternal or fetal surveillance.

The study will compare the outcomes of women who receive standard intermittent CTG monitoring with those who receive continuous eCTG monitoring using the NFMS. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of perinatal mortality and major neonatal morbidity. Secondary outcomes include maternal mortality, neonatal morbidity, patient satisfaction, caregiver satisfaction, and various other measures related to pregnancy duration, admission to the OHC, and obstetric interventions.

The study will also develop and verify mathematical models for predicting time until preterm birth and for automated detection of fetal movements in NFMS data. The study is expected to provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of continuous eCTG monitoring in high-risk pregnancies and its potential to improve perinatal outcomes.

Title: Genetic Susceptibility to Severe Infections

Objective: To identify genetic susceptibility to severe infections, including viral, bacterial, and fungal infections, by studying the genetic factors that contribute to the development of these infections.

Eligibility Criteria: The study includes patients with a proven rare and severe infection, as well as their relatives up to the 3rd degree. Exclusion criteria include acquired immunodeficiency, pregnancy, and being under court protection.

Interventions: The study involves drawing blood samples and performing skin biopsies on participants.

Primary Outcome Measures:

1. Identification of chromosomal regions associated with the disease through a homozygosity mapping study on multiplex and/or consanguineous families.
2. Identification of candidate genes for genetic susceptibility to infectious diseases through exome and genome sequencing.
3. Validation of candidate genes as factors of susceptibility to infectious diseases through functional and complementation tests.

Study Duration: The study is expected to last approximately 10 years.

This randomized controlled experimental study aims to determine the effect of nursing care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory on the comfort, care satisfaction, and sleep quality of intensive care patients. Data will be collected using four scales: the General Comfort Scale, the Newcastle Satisfaction Scale, the Richard Campbell Sleep Scale, and the Comfort Behaviors Checklist. The study will assess the primary outcomes of comfort, care satisfaction, and sleep quality at 24 hours after the intervention. The study's inclusion criteria include being 18 years or older, staying in the intensive care unit for at least 24 hours, and being open to communication, while exclusion criteria include taking sedative medication, having a sleep disorder, or being illiterate.

The P-KIDs CARE Health Systems Intervention in Tanzania is a clinical trial aimed at addressing health systems delays to care for injured children in Tanzania. The study has three aims: (1) formative research to inform the development of the P-KIDs CARE intervention, (2) development of the intervention, and (3) pilot testing of the intervention in two study facilities in the Kilimanjaro Region.

The P-KIDs CARE intervention consists of two components: the World Health Organization (WHO) Basic Emergency Care Course for training on patient assessment and stabilization, and a decision support tool that integrates adaptation of two evidence-based tools for mortality risk assessment and timely referral decisions.

The study will enroll 200 pediatric injury patients, 100 in the pre-intervention period and 100 in the post-intervention period, and will collect data on patient-level outcomes including time from first care to definitive care, disposition, morbidity, and mortality. The primary outcome is mortality, with secondary outcomes including time to definitive care, disposition, and morbidity.

The study will also conduct surveys and exit interviews with healthcare providers and family members of pediatric injury patients to assess acceptability and satisfaction with the intervention. The study aims to pilot test the intervention in two study facilities and assess its feasibility, acceptability, and fidelity.

Title: Combining Pelvic Floor Rehabilitation With Postural Re-education in Women With Stress Urinary Incontinence and Chronic Low Back Pain: a Preliminary Study.

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of combining pelvic floor rehabilitation with postural re-education in women with stress urinary incontinence (SUI) and chronic low back pain (CLBP).

Design: Randomized, parallel-group trial with two arms: pelvic floor rehabilitation and postural re-education, and pelvic floor rehabilitation and spinal mobilization.

Eligibility: Women aged 18-75 with SUI and CLBP, excluding those with severe pelvic organ prolapse, pregnancy, or other exclusion criteria.

Interventions:

* Arm 1: 10 sessions of pelvic floor rehabilitation and postural re-education, consisting of 40 minutes of postural exercise and 20 minutes of perineal exercises, performed twice a week for 5 weeks.
* Arm 2: 10 sessions of pelvic floor rehabilitation and spinal mobilization, consisting of 40 minutes of thoracolumbar spine mobilization and 20 minutes of perineal exercises, performed twice a week for 5 weeks.

Primary outcome measures: Change in International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF) scores from baseline to 10 sessions and 30 days after treatment.

Secondary outcome measures: Change in Pain Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) and Modified Oxford Scale (MOS) scores from baseline to 10 sessions and 30 days after treatment.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

The study aims to develop a pharmacodynamic model for propofol in older adults (65 years and above) to improve the titration of this anesthetic drug and avoid potential deleterious effects. The model will use pharmacokinetic parameters from the Eleveld model and new pharmacodynamic parameters derived from frontal electroencephalography (EEG) signals. The study will enroll patients undergoing non-cardiac elective surgery and will compare the performance of two models: the original Eleveld model and the new model using EEG parameters. The primary outcome measures will assess the accuracy and bias of the models in predicting propofol concentrations, as well as the time of loss and return of response to anesthesia. The study aims to improve the safety and efficacy of propofol administration in older adults.
