Title: Very Short-course Versus Standard Course Antibiotic Therapy in Patients With Acute ChOlangitis After Adequate Endoscopic BiliaRy drAinage

Objective: To compare the effectiveness and safety of a very short-course (1 day) of antibiotic therapy versus a standard course (4-7 days) in patients with acute cholangitis after adequate endoscopic biliary drainage.

Study Design: Multicenter, open-label, randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 2 arms: experimental (very short-course antibiotics) and active comparator (standard course antibiotics).

Eligibility Criteria: Patients with acute cholangitis due to common bile duct stones, benign or malignant distal biliary obstruction, or distal biliary stent dysfunction, who have undergone endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with adequate biliary drainage.

Primary Outcome Measure: Clinical cure rate by day 14 after ERCP without relapse by day 30.

Secondary Outcome Measures: All-cause 90-day mortality, relapse of cholangitis within 90 days, rate of any other subsequent infection requiring antibiotic therapy within 90 days, rate of subsequent infections with multi-drug resistant bacteria or Clostridioides difficile within 90 days, rate of other adverse drug events within 14 days, length of intensive care and hospital stay for the initial episode of cholangitis, quality of life and health utility, and societal costs and cost-effectiveness/utility.

Keywords: antibiotics, randomized controlled trial.

Title: Conventional Versus Ultrasound-guided Lung Recruitment Manoeuvre in Morbidly Obese Patients Undergoing Laparoscopic Bariatric Surgery

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of conventional and ultrasound-guided lung recruitment manoeuvres in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.

Design: Prospective, randomized, double-blinded clinical trial with 60 patients (30 in each group) at the Anesthesiology Department in Tanta University Hospitals.

Interventions:

* Conventional group: Manual inflation with a pressure of 30 cmH2O for 30 seconds.
* Ultrasound-guided group: Manual inflation with a pressure of 10 cmH2O for 10 seconds, increased 10 cmH2O every 10 seconds until no collapsed areas are visible on ultrasound, with a maximum airway pressure of 40 cmH2O.

Primary outcome measure: Change in lung ultrasound score 2 hours post-surgery.

Secondary outcome measures: Incidence of atelectasis and intra-operative desaturation.

Eligibility criteria: Adult morbidly obese patients (BMI > 40) scheduled for laparoscopic bariatric surgery, excluding those with severe obstructive or restrictive pulmonary disease, severe obstructive sleep apnea, emphysematous lung bullae, or uncontrolled hepatic or renal disorders.

Duration: One year, from August 2023 to August 2024.

**Title:** Optimization of Fractionation Schedules of Heel Spur Radiotherapy: A Prospective Randomized Open-label Trial

**Objective:** To evaluate the efficacy and safety of different fractionation schedules of radiotherapy for treating heel spurs (plantar fasciitis) in patients aged 40 years or older.

**Design:** Prospective, randomized, open-label, non-inferiority trial with six arms: standard fractionated dose (6 Gy in 4 fractions) and five experimental single-dose arms (0.5 Gy, 1 Gy, 1.5 Gy, 2 Gy, and 3 Gy).

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Non-inferiority of single fraction radiotherapy compared to standard fractionated dose in terms of pain relief and quality of life at 3 months after radiotherapy.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Comparison of different single fraction radiotherapy prescriptions, need for reirradiation, quality of life, and visual analogue scale (VAS) scores at various time points.

**Study Population:** Patients with painful unilateral plantar heel spur for at least 6 months, aged 40 years or older, and suitable for radiotherapy.

**Duration:** 44 months.

**Locations:** Masaryk Memorial Cancer Institute, Brno, Czech Republic.

**Funding:** Supported by the Ministry of Health of the Czech Republic.

**Study Title:** Lifestyle Intervention in Overweight/Obese People Suffering From Chronic Low Back Pain: an International Multi-center Randomized Controlled Trial

**Objective:** To examine the effectiveness of a behavioral weight reduction program combined with pain neuroscience education and cognition-targeted exercise therapy (CTET) compared to CTET alone in reducing pain and improving quality of life in overweight or obese individuals with chronic low back pain (CLBP).

**Methods:** This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 252 participants aged 18-65 years who are overweight or obese and have CLBP. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which will receive the behavioral weight reduction program combined with pain neuroscience education and CTET, or the control group, which will receive only CTET. The study will consist of 18 treatment sessions over 14 weeks, with follow-up assessments at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months post-intervention.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** The primary outcome measure is the Brief Pain Inventory - Average pain Intensity, which will be assessed at 12 months post-intervention.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The study will also assess various secondary outcomes, including pain interference, pain distribution, Tampa Scale for Kinesiophobia, fear avoidance beliefs, body composition, muscle mass, fat mass, waist-hip circumference, regional body composition, sedentary behavior, physical activity, sleep quality, dietary intake, and health economics (medical consumption, productivity costs, and quality of life).

**Inclusion Criteria:** Adults aged 18-65 years who are overweight or obese and have CLBP, defined as nonspecific low back pain for at least 3 months duration.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with BMI ≥ 40 kg/m², morbid obesity, pregnancy, breastfeeding, or current receipt of dietary or exercise interventions.

Title: Comparison of Outcomes for Single vs Double Pyloromyotomy for Gastroparesis Randomized Controlled Trial

Objective: To compare the clinical outcomes and efficacy of single versus double pyloromyotomy techniques for gastric per-oral endoscopic pyloromyotomy (G-POEM) in the treatment of refractory and severe gastroparesis.

Design: Randomized controlled prospective multicenter study with two arms: single pyloromyotomy and double pyloromyotomy.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients with refractory and severe gastroparesis (GCSI > 2) with confirmed impaired gastric emptying, aged 18 years or older.

Exclusion Criteria: Previous gastric surgery, esophageal or gastric varices, portal gastropathy, pregnancy, malignant or pre-malignant gastric diseases.

Primary Outcome Measures: Clinical success at 3, 6, and 12 months follow-up, Gastroparesis Cardinal Symptom Index (GCSI) score before and after GPOEM at 3, 6, and 12 months follow-up, and technical success rate.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Total procedure time, adverse events, recurrence of symptoms.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of single versus double pyloromyotomy techniques in G-POEM for refractory and severe gastroparesis, and to determine which technique is more effective in improving clinical outcomes and reducing symptoms.

Title: A Single Arm, Open-label Study of the Efficacy of Minayo Iron-rich Yeast Drink With SOD on Female Nutritional Anemia, Skin Condition and Qi-blood Deficiency Syndrome

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy of Minayo Iron-rich Yeast Drink with SOD in improving nutritional anemia, skin condition, and Qi-blood deficiency syndrome in female subjects aged 18-35 years.

Design: Single-arm, open-label study with a single intervention group.

Intervention: Participants will receive Minayo Yeast Drink Product, containing iron, SOD, and other ingredients, for 4 consecutive weeks.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Cerebral Hemodynamic and Metabolic Responses to Anesthesia and Vasopressors in Adult Surgery: A 2x2 Factorial Design Randomized Controlled Trial With Light-based Neuromonitoring (CHEM-FACT Study)

Objective: To investigate the effects of different anesthetic maintenance agents (propofol vs. sevoflurane) and vasopressors (phenylephrine vs. ephedrine) on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism during surgery.

Design: A 2x2 factorial design randomized controlled trial with 80 adult patients undergoing surgery under general anesthesia. Patients will be randomized to one of four groups: propofol-based anesthetic maintenance with phenylephrine, propofol-based anesthetic maintenance with ephedrine, sevoflurane-based anesthetic maintenance with phenylephrine, or sevoflurane-based anesthetic maintenance with ephedrine.

Primary outcome measures: Differences in cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen consumption (CMRO2) during surgery between the four groups.

Secondary outcome measures: Effects of anesthetic maintenance agents and vasopressors on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism during anesthesia induction.

Methods: Patients will undergo light-based neuromonitoring using a hybrid time-resolved near-infrared spectroscopy (trNIRS) and diffuse correlation spectroscopy (DCS) system to measure cerebral blood flow (CBF) and cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen consumption (CMRO2). The study will also collect data on patient characteristics, medical comorbidities, and systemic blood pressure.

This study aims to provide insights into the effects of different anesthetic maintenance agents and vasopressors on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism during surgery, which may help inform the development of more effective anesthetic strategies to ensure optimal cerebral perfusion and metabolism during surgical procedures.

The IDMet (RaDiCo Cohort) study is a national cohort study aimed at investigating the clinical, genetic, biological, and morphometric characteristics of individuals with Imprinting Disorders (IDs) in both pediatric and adult populations. The study includes patients with various IDs, such as Silver Russell Syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome, and Prader-Willi Syndrome, among others.

The primary outcome measures include the clinical, genetic, biological, and morphometric characteristics of IDs patients over an average of 10 years. Secondary outcome measures focus on the metabolic phenotype of IDs patients, prevalence of metabolic abnormalities, risk of metabolic complications, therapeutic approaches, quality-of-life scores, and transmission of (epi)genetic mutations in probands and relatives.

The study aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of IDs and their metabolic consequences, ultimately informing the development of targeted therapeutic approaches and improving the quality of life for individuals with these disorders.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

This randomized controlled trial compares the effectiveness of unipolar versus bipolar interlocking in adults with humeral shaft fractures. The study includes patients aged 18 years or older with a diagnosis of humeral shaft fracture requiring surgical treatment with intramedullary nailing. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with radiologically assessed bone healing at 12 months. Patients will complete questionnaires (EQ-5D-5L and SF-12) and undergo CT scans at 9 months and 12 months if the humerus is not consolidated at 6 months. The study aims to determine whether unipolar interlocking is non-inferior to bipolar interlocking in terms of bone healing at 12 months.

The EPI-MINN study aims to investigate the effectiveness of a cognitive training program combined with a personalized real-time intervention for motivational enhancement (PRIME) app in improving cognitive function, motivation, and quality of life in individuals with early psychosis. The study will enroll 180 participants aged 18-40 with a diagnosis of bipolar disorder, psychosis, or schizophrenia, who are receiving treatment at an early psychosis coordinated specialty care clinic. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a treatment-as-usual group or a group that receives the cognitive training program and PRIME app. The cognitive training program consists of 20 hours of training, delivered over 12 weeks, and focuses on improving auditory information processing, working memory, and cognitive control. The PRIME app is designed to enhance motivation by providing personalized support and encouragement from a motivation coach. The primary outcome measures include changes in cognitive function, motivation, and quality of life, as assessed by various scales and questionnaires at baseline, 6 months, 12 months, and 18 months. The study aims to provide data-driven knowledge on factors that contribute to treatment response trajectories in early psychosis and to optimize coordinated specialty care to improve clinical outcomes.

**Title:** Assessment, Monitoring and Optimisation of Prehabilitation Patients Using Wearable Fitness Trackers

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of using wearable fitness trackers to monitor and optimize prehabilitation exercise programs for patients with non-metastatic oesophago-gastric, hepatobiliary, or lung cancer undergoing surgical resection.

**Design:** A prospective, two-arm randomized parallel group clinical trial with 82 participants. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a control group (exercise to Rating of Perceived Exertion) or an intervention group (exercise to a Heart Rate Zone).

**Primary Outcome Measure:** The total number of minutes of moderate intensity exercise achieved over 8 weeks.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Volume of physical activity, weekly adherence, duration and intensity of exercise, and patient feedback on using heart rate trackers.

**Intervention:** Participants in the intervention group will be prescribed moderate intensity aerobic exercise using personalized heart rate zones, while those in the control group will be prescribed exercise based on Rating of Perceived Exertion.

**Population:** Patients aged 18-80 years with non-metastatic oesophago-gastric, hepatobiliary, or lung cancer undergoing surgical resection.

**Duration:** 8 weeks or until patients undergo surgery.

The LA POPA Trial is a randomized, controlled, superiority trial comparing two minimally invasive treatments for pilonidal disease: pit-picking surgery (Pit-picking surgery) and pit-picking surgery with sinus laser-assisted closure (SiLaC). The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of these treatments in patients with primary pilonidal sinus disease.

The trial will enroll patients aged 12 years and older with Type 1b and 3 pilonidal sinus disease, as defined by the Dutch staging system. Exclusion criteria include asymptomatic, recurrent, or chronic wounds, as well as underlying medical conditions that may interfere with wound healing.

The primary outcome measure is the success rate of treatment at 1 year, which includes wound healing outcomes, absence of symptoms, and absence of persisting sinuses or recurrence. Secondary outcome measures include success rate at long-term follow-up, pain scores, patient-reported outcome measures, wound healing and complications, work rehabilitation, return to daily activities, recurrence rate, need for secondary or revision surgery, patient satisfaction, and quality of life.

The study will be conducted at multiple centers in a single-blind, randomized design, with patients randomly assigned to either the Pit-picking surgery or SiLaC group. The trial will assess the efficacy and safety of these treatments in patients with pilonidal disease, with a primary focus on wound healing outcomes and patient-reported outcomes.

The primary outcome measures include identifying sociodemographic characteristics, personality traits, and patterns of substance abuse among patients with SUD. **Title:** A Phase 2 Study on Immune Checkpoint Inhibitors and Radioembolisation for Previously Untreated Metastatic Hepatocellular Carcinoma

**Objective:** To investigate the efficacy and safety of combining immune checkpoint inhibitors (durvalumab and tremelimumab) with radioembolisation (yttrium-90 microspheres) in patients with previously untreated metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma.

**Design:** Open-label, single-arm study with 7 cycles of durvalumab and tremelimumab, and a single dose of radioembolisation.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Best objective response rate and rate of abscopal effect (tumour response outside the liver).

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Progression-free survival, overall survival, incidence of treatment-related side effects, local control rate, and distant control rate.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Patients with metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma, aged 18 years or older, with Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0 or 1, and adequate liver and kidney function.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with severe autoimmune disease, prior monoclonal antibody therapy, or active infection requiring intravenous systemic therapy.

**Title:** Neoadjuvant Tremelimumab and Durvalumab With Gem/Cis in Intrahepatic Cholangiocarcinoma

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and efficacy of neoadjuvant durvalumab and tremelimumab combination therapy with gemcitabine and cisplatin in patients with borderline resectable or resectable intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

**Design:** Single-group assignment, open-label study with 8 cycles of treatment.

**Population:** Patients with histologically proven intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma, age 18 years or older, with an estimated life expectancy of more than 6 months.

**Interventions:** Durvalumab (1500mg IV every 3 weeks for up to 8 cycles), tremelimumab (300mg IV on Cycle 1), gemcitabine (1000mg/m2 IV on days 1 and 8 of each cycle), and cisplatin (25mg/m2 on days 1 and 8 of each cycle). If the tumor is deemed resectable after 4 or 8 cycles, patients may proceed with surgical tumor resection.

**Primary Outcome Measures:**

1. Rate of conversion from unresectable to resectable tumor after neoadjuvant treatment.
2. Incidence of related treatment-emergent adverse events.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:**

1. Objective Response Rate (ORR).
2. Pathological complete response (pCR).
3. Overall survival (OS).
4. Progression-free survival (PFS).
5. Rate of R0 resection.
6. Relapse-free survival (RFS).
7. Patient-reported outcomes (PRO) decline.
8. Event-free survival (EFS).

**Study Duration:** 36 months.

Title: Enhanced Hippocampal Neuroplasticity for Surfacing of Inaccessible Traumatic Memories in Veterans With PTSD

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of combining hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) with hippocampal training in enhancing memory recovery and reducing symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in veterans with combat-associated PTSD and peritraumatic amnesia.

Design: Randomized, parallel-group trial with 40 male veterans aged 25-60 years, with PTSD and peritraumatic amnesia, randomly assigned to either HBOT alone or HBOT plus hippocampal training. Participants will receive 60 daily sessions of HBOT, with or without hippocampal training, and undergo psychological evaluation, anatomic and functional MRI, electroencephalogram, and autonomic nervous system data collection at baseline, during, and after treatment.

Primary outcome measures:

* Changes in memory gaps as assessed by the traumatic scene form
* Time to inaccessible memory surfacing

Secondary outcome measures:

* Changes in brain activity as assessed by fMRI
* Cognitive performance as assessed using Neurotrax
* Memory performance as assessed using RAVLT, ROCFT, and Verbal Pairs tests

The study aims to investigate the potential benefits of combining HBOT with hippocampal training in improving memory recovery and reducing symptoms of PTSD in veterans with combat-associated PTSD and peritraumatic amnesia.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

The CuDOSIS trial aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging for cardiac sarcoidosis, a serious condition that can lead to death. The study will compare the results of 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT scans with those of 18F-FDG PET/CT scans, which have limitations due to high physiological uptake in normal cardiac muscle. The study will include four groups: patients with suspected or confirmed cardiac sarcoidosis, patients with acute lymphocytic myocarditis, patients with neuroendocrine tumors (negative controls), and patients with previously scanned neuroendocrine tumors (control group). The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with tracer uptake in the heart on 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT in patients with cardiac sarcoidosis and neuroendocrine tumors. Secondary outcomes include rates of adverse outcomes, such as death, heart failure hospitalizations, and arrhythmias, as well as the distribution of tracer uptake in the heart. The study will assess the diagnostic accuracy of 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging for cardiac sarcoidosis and other inflammatory heart diseases.

Title: Effect of Probiotics on Immunosuppressive-drug-associated Diarrhea Among Renal Transplant Recipients

This is a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled, single-center pilot/exploratory trial to evaluate the effect of probiotics on immunosuppressive-drug-associated diarrhea among renal transplant recipients. The study aims to assess the reduction in diarrhea, inflammatory biomarkers, and the association between inflammatory markers and fecal microbiome.

The trial will enroll 60 participants who have received a living or deceased donor kidney transplant and are experiencing mild to severe diarrhea. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either a probiotics capsule (Florajen Digestion) or a placebo capsule daily for six months. The primary outcomes will be measured through a gastrointestinal questionnaire, Bristol Stool Chart, inflammatory biomarkers, and fecal microbiome analysis.

The study aims to investigate the effect of probiotics on immunosuppressive-drug-associated diarrhea and its underlying mechanisms in renal transplant recipients.

**Title:** Randomized Clinical Trial of Inhaled Sedation With Sevoflurane in Critically Ill Patients at Risk of Developing the Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)

**Objective:** To assess the efficacy of inhaled sevoflurane compared to current intravenous sedation practice in improving PaO2/FiO2 in ICU patients at high risk for ARDS.

**Design:** Single-center, prospective, randomized, stratified, parallel-group clinical trial with blinded outcome assessment and concealed allocation.

**Population:** Critically ill patients aged 18 years or older, admitted to participating ICUs with at least one known risk factor for ARDS, and expected to receive sedation for at least 4 hours.

**Interventions:** Inhaled sedation with sevoflurane or intravenous sedation (current practice).

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Longitudinal evolution in the PaO2/FiO2 ratio within 5 days from randomization.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Progression to ARDS, rate of pneumonia, ventilator-free days to day 28, organ failure to day 5, mortality at day 28, length of ICU-stay up to 28 days, and various physiological and hemodynamic measures.

**Duration:** Up to 28 days after randomization.

**Keywords:** ARDS, Sedation, Inhaled sevoflurane.

The study aims to investigate the outcomes of different treatment modalities for massive rotator cuff tendon tears in patients aged 50-80 years. Patients with grade III tears according to Davidson and Burkhart classification will be included in the study. The primary objective is to evaluate the functional status of patients in different treatment groups, while the secondary objective is to assess the integrity of surgically repaired rotator cuff tendons on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) at 6, 12, and 24 months post-operatively.

The study will randomize patients to one of three treatment groups: arthroscopic rotator cuff partial repair with superior capsular augmentation using the long head of the biceps tendon (LHBBT), arthroscopic partial rotator cuff repair, or arthroscopic complete rotator cuff repair. Patients who refuse operative treatment will be followed as a conservative treatment group.

The study will recruit 100 patients with peri-implantitis and 100 healthy controls. Title: Examining Engagement Predictors of Health and Fitness App Uptake and Subscription in the General Population

Objective: To examine predictors of initial six-month subscription and subscription renewal rates at six months for the WayBetter app, a wellness lifestyle mHealth app, and to characterize app engagement over the first 24 weeks of app use.

Methodology:

* 24-week prospective study with approximately 400 adult users (≥18 years old) who are new app users and have engaged in a 7-day free trial.
* Users will be asked to complete a survey to collect information on socio-demographics, past health behaviors, psychological determinants, and app engagement metrics.
* The study will examine associations between user-specific metrics, psychological metrics, and app engagement metrics to identify underlying homogenous subgroups of individuals using Latent Class Analysis (LCA).
* The primary outcomes are rates of initial six-month subscription and subscription renewal rates at six months.

Secondary objectives:

* To describe WayBetter app engagement over 24 weeks using 'WayBetter' and 'Industry' specific engagement metrics.
* To examine associations between user 'latent classes' and app engagement metrics.

Study design:

* New users will receive a free 1-week trial and $10 USD deposit from WayBetter Inc.
* Users can use the deposit for any game during the trial, regardless of continuing membership.
* To continue to use the app, users pay $69 USD for 6 months.
* Games require players to achieve specific behavioral goals and have varying validation methods.

Primary outcome measures:

* Six-month subscription
* Subscription renewal rates

Secondary outcome measures:

* App opens per week
* Date of joining first game
* Game adherence
* Number of games started and won each week
* Non-usage attrition
* Re-engagement

Title: Comparison of Aerobics and Pilates Exercises on Depression and Sleep Quality in Primigravida Females

Objective: To compare the effects of aerobic exercises and Pilates exercises on depression and sleep quality in primigravida females.

Design: Randomized controlled trial with 42 participants, aged 18-35 years, in their third trimester of pregnancy, randomly assigned to either an aerobic exercise group or a Pilates exercise group.

Interventions: Participants in both groups will receive 16 sessions of either aerobic exercises or Pilates exercises over 8 weeks.

Outcomes: The primary outcomes measured are depression (using the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale) and sleep quality (using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index).

Inclusion criteria: Primigravida females, aged 18-35 years, in their third trimester of pregnancy, with depressive symptoms (CES-D score ≥ 16).

Exclusion criteria: Gestational diabetes, pregnancy hypertension, placenta previa, previous miscarriage, medically prohibited to exercise, incompetent cervix, polyhydramnios, or oligohydramnios.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of aerobic exercises and Pilates exercises as a primary and secondary preventive strategy for depression and sleep quality in primigravida females.

Objective: To assess the safety and efficacy of indium In 111 panitumumab (111In-panitumumab) as a molecular imaging agent in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) for nodal staging.

Title: Immediate Effects of Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation With Lower Leg Kinesiotaping on Ankle Dorsiflexion, Gait, and Functional Mobility in Patients With Chronic Stroke

Objective: To investigate the immediate effects of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) with lower leg kinesiotaping on ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke.

Methods: This randomized controlled trial enrolled 18 patients with chronic stroke who were randomly assigned to one of three groups: PNF with lower leg kinesiotaping, PNF without kinesiotaping, and no treatment. The primary outcome measures included ankle dorsiflexion, gait parameters, and functional mobility assessed using the Time Up and Go test, Barthel Index, Motor Assessment Scale, and Dynamic Gait Index.

Results: The study found that PNF with lower leg kinesiotaping significantly improved ankle dorsiflexion and gait parameters compared to the other two groups. Additionally, functional mobility was improved in the PNF with lower leg kinesiotaping group compared to the other two groups.

Conclusion: The study suggests that PNF with lower leg kinesiotaping may be an effective treatment for improving ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke.

**Title:** Development and Evaluation of an Algorithm for Vascular Access Management (ALCOV Pilot Study)

**Objective:** To develop and evaluate an algorithm for vascular access management (VAM) to improve the quality of peripheral venous catheter placement.

**Design:** Mixed-methods, multicentre, non-randomized, quasi-experimental study with three phases: observational, interventional, and post-processing.

**Phases:**

1. Observational phase: Describes existing practices and organization in inclusion centers.
2. Interventional phase 1: Implementation of the A-DIVA Scale alone to evaluate its impact on practitioners' approaches to peripheral venous catheter placement.
3. Interventional phase 2: Implementation of the algorithm composed of the A-DIVA Scale and the new decision-making tree (A-DIVA Tool) to evaluate its impact on quality of peripheral venous catheter placement.
4. Post-processing phase: Data analysis, scientific production, and writing of the final report.

**Interventions:**

* Implementation of the A-DIVA Scale
* Implementation of the algorithm composed of the A-DIVA Scale and the new decision-making tree (A-DIVA Tool)

**Primary Outcome Measures:**

* Number of venipunctures performed per patient after implementation of the algorithm

**Secondary Outcome Measures:**

* Number of participants who approve the co-constructed algorithm
* Acceptability and feasibility of using the VAD score in isolation and with the catheter placement algorithm
* Patient pain score measured immediately after vascular puncture
* Number of venipunctures performed per patient after implementation of the venous access difficulty score
* Insertion technique used for catheter placement
* Number of operators required for catheter insertion
* Frequency of second-line referral to another practitioner
* Puncture result: success/failure
* Care strategies implemented in the event of difficulties encountered when inserting peripheral venous lines

**Keywords:** Difficult Intravenous Access (DIVA), Difficult Intravenous Access Scale (A-DIVA Scale), Algorithm, Peripheral venous catheter, Decision-making tree

**Study Overview:** This randomized controlled trial aims to evaluate the clinical efficacy of a digital emotion regulation treatment (POET) for adolescents with mental health problems.

**Objectives:** The primary objectives are to test the effects of POET on mental health problems and emotion regulation. Secondary objectives include examining the cost-effectiveness of POET, identifying individual differences in treatment response, and assessing distal outcomes 12-60 months post-treatment.

**Design:** The study is a parallel-group randomized controlled trial with a single-blind design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the POET group or an active comparator group receiving supportive treatment.

**Interventions:** POET is a 6-week digital treatment program consisting of six guided modules for the youth and six modules for their parents. **Outcomes:** The primary outcome measure is the Clinical Global Impressions - Severity scale (CGI-S) at post-treatment. Secondary outcome measures include various scales assessing symptoms of depression and anxiety, emotion regulation, quality of life, and healthcare resource use.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Participants must be between 12-17 years old, seeking care for mental health problems, and have at least one guardian interested in participating in the parent program. The primary outcome measure is the analysis of lymphadenectomy in relation to the radicality of surgical resection, including tumor-free margin, terminal ileum length, vascular ligatures, and mesocolon integrity. Secondary outcome measures include vascular anatomical variability, including the position of the superior mesenteric artery relative to the superior mesenteric vein, and anatomical variants of the vessels.

**Interventions:** Participants will be randomized to either the HAPC-ESG group, which will receive hybrid argon plasma coagulation followed by endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty, or the ESG group, which will receive only endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Durability of plications and endoscopic sutures on repeat endoscopy at 6 months.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Percentage of total body weight loss, percentage of excess weight loss, blood pressure, HbA1c percentage, quality of life, depression, eating behavior, and binary outcomes such as ≥25% change in %EWL and incidence of esophagitis.

**Duration:** 6 months.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Age 21-65, BMI ≥ 30 and ≤40 kg/m², willingness to comply with dietary restrictions, history of failure with non-surgical weight-loss methods, and ability to give informed consent.

**Exclusion Criteria:** History of foregut or gastrointestinal surgery, prior gastrointestinal surgery with sequelae, prior open or laparoscopic bariatric surgery, and several other medical conditions.

This systematic review assessed the effectiveness of neoadjuvant chemotherapy and Trastuzumab in achieving pathological complete response (pCR) in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. Nine clinical trials were included, involving 1,209 patients who received neoadjuvant chemotherapy and Trastuzumab. The overall pCR rate was 42%. The review found that Trastuzumab was given at dosages of 4mg/kg or 8mg/kg, and chemotherapy regimens varied across trials. The primary outcome measure was pCR, defined as the absence of residual invasive cancer or invasive neoplastic cells at microscopic examination. The review did not analyze survival outcomes.

**Study Overview**: The Technical Evaluation of Earswitch Phase A study aims to evaluate the robustness of the EarSwitch technology in detecting voluntary eardrum movements in individuals with assistive technology needs and healthy participants. The study consists of four parts: co-design questionnaires, EarSwitch insertion, ear rumbling test, and usability testing.

**Primary Objective**: To evaluate the robustness of the EarSwitch technology in detecting voluntary eardrum movements.

**Secondary Objectives**:

1. To gather information on the accuracy of voluntary tensor tympani movements in individuals with assistive technology needs.
2. To compare the accuracy of voluntary tensor tympani movements between individuals with assistive technology needs and healthy participants.
3. To assess the comfort and ease of use of the EarSwitch device.
4. To evaluate the physical comfort and fit of the EarSwitch device.

**Methodology**: The study will recruit individuals with assistive technology needs and healthy participants. Participants will undergo a series of tasks, including co-design questionnaires, EarSwitch insertion, ear rumbling test, and usability testing. The ear rumbling test will involve recording videos of the participant's ear drum while they contract the tensor tympani muscle voluntarily in response to different stimuli.

**Outcome Measures**: The primary outcome measure is the robustness of the EarSwitch technology in detecting voluntary eardrum movements, measured using the F-score, Matthews correlation coefficient, receiver operating characteristics curve, and Area Under the ROC curve. Secondary outcome measures include the accuracy of voluntary tensor tympani movements, comfort and ease of use of the EarSwitch device, and physical comfort and fit of the device.

**Study Population**: The study will recruit individuals aged 18 years or older with assistive technology needs and healthy participants. Exclusion criteria include individuals with severe learning disabilities or inability to communicate.

The study aims to evaluate the performance of PRISM in identifying high-risk individuals for pancreatic cancer and to assess its potential for use in screening and early detection.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the Global Burden Estimation of Human Papillomavirus (GLOBE-HPV) clinical trial:

**Objective:** The GLOBE-HPV study aims to estimate the point-prevalence of high-risk Human Papillomavirus (HR HPV) infection in low socio-economic populations and the incidence of persistent HPV infection in specific sub-populations in 8 countries.

**Methods:** The study will conduct cross-sectional surveys (CSS) in urban and rural areas to estimate the point prevalence of HPV infection in girls and women aged 9-50 years. Longitudinal studies (LS) will also be conducted to estimate the incidence of persistent HPV infection in sexually active girls and young women. Urine and self-collected vaginal swabs will be collected for HPV testing, and data will be collected on demographics, socioeconomic status, sexual and reproductive history, attitudes towards and awareness of cervical cancer screening and HPV vaccination, and potential risk factors for HPV infection and cervical cancer.

**Outcomes:** The primary outcomes are the prevalence of HPV 16 and/or 18 infection and the incidence of ≥6-month persistent HPV 16 and/or 18 infection. Secondary outcomes include the prevalence of HR HPV infection, incidence of ≥6-month persistent HR HPV infection, and descriptive statistics of knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs regarding HPV vaccination, cervical cancer screening and treatment.

**Countries:** The study will be conducted in 8 countries, including Bangladesh, Nepal, Pakistan, Sierra Leone, DR Congo, Tanzania, Ghana, and Zambia.

**Timeline:** The study is expected to be completed by Q4 2026.

The DESC-HBR trial is a randomized, open-label study designed to compare the impact of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor therapy on platelet reactivity and clinical outcomes in high bleeding risk patients with recent acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The study aims to assess the proportion of patients achieving optimal platelet reactivity (OPR) at peak level following drug maintenance dose (MD) using the VerifyNow system. Secondary objectives include exploring the effect of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor therapy on clinical events, quality of life, and cost-effectiveness.

The study enrolled 250 patients with recent ACS and treated with full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitors, who were randomized to one of four arms: continuation of full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitor, or de-escalation to clopidogrel 75mg, prasugrel 5mg, or ticagrelor 60mg bid. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients achieving OPR at peak level following MD using the VerifyNow system. Secondary outcomes include incidence of bleeding events, platelet reactive units (PRU) at VerifyNow system, proportion of high platelet reactivity (HPR) and low platelet reactivity (LPR), platelet-derived thrombogenicity at Total Thrombus Formation (T-TAS), adverse clinical events, and cost-effectiveness.

The study will be conducted over a period of 5 months, with study visits scheduled at baseline, 14±2 days, 3 and 5 months after randomization. The study will provide valuable insights into the impact of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor therapy on platelet reactivity and clinical outcomes in high bleeding risk patients with recent ACS.

The study aims to identify patients at higher risk of readmission using the RecuR Score, a novel AI-powered risk score, and provide them with enhanced care interventions, including additional educational materials, focus on readmission risk during interdisciplinary team huddles, and home health services.

The study will enroll patients with a high readmission risk (RecuR Score ≥ 3) or medium-high risk (RecuR Score 2 or 3) and randomly assign them to either the Standard of Care arm or the Enhanced Care arm. The Standard of Care arm will receive the current transitional care protocol, while the Enhanced Care arm will receive the same protocol plus additional interventions.

The primary outcomes of the study are the number of patients with 30-day post-discharge hospital readmission in the overall study population and the number of moderate-high risk patients with 30-day post-discharge hospital readmission. Secondary outcomes include 30-day post-discharge mortality, 30-day and 90-day post-discharge unplanned hospital readmissions, and 30-day and 90-day post-discharge emergency department usage.

The study will use a fallback design, where the first primary endpoint will be tested against a 0.025 significance level, and if significant, the unused alpha level will be added to the reserved alpha level to test the second primary endpoint.

**Title:** Trans-coronary Cooling and Dilution for Cardioprotection During Revascularisation for ST-elevation Myocardial Infarction

**Objective:** To investigate the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of trans-coronary cooling and dilution during primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

**Design:** Randomized, open-label pilot trial with 60 patients with STEMI undergoing primary PCI at Harefield Hospital.

**Intervention:** Patients were randomly assigned to either the treatment group (trans-coronary cooling and dilution) or the control group (standard of care). The treatment group received an intracoronary infusion of room temperature 0.9% Normal Saline solution through the guiding catheter to achieve a target intracoronary temperature of 6-8°C below baseline.

**Primary outcomes:** Recruitment rate, feasibility, and safety.

**Secondary outcomes:** Invasive haemodynamic assessment of coronary flow and microvascular function, blood biomarkers, myocardial salvage, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to assess infarct size and left ventricular function.

**Inclusion criteria:** Clinical STEMI within 6 hours of symptom onset, total ST-segment deviation of at least 1 mm in two contiguous ECG leads, and ability to provide informed consent.

**Exclusion criteria:** Cardiac arrest, severe left ventricular impairment, previous myocardial infarction, and other conditions.

**Duration:** The trial will run for 1 year, with follow-up at 6 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months.

**Endpoints:** Composite of all-cause mortality and hospitalization for heart failure, hospitalization for heart failure, all-cause mortality, and cardiovascular mortality at 6 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months.

Title: Remotely Delivered, Culturally Tailored Weight Loss Interventions Among Latina Breast Cancer Survivors

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of remotely delivered, culturally tailored weight loss interventions among Latina breast cancer survivors.

Design: This is a randomized controlled trial with a sequential assignment design. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of six arms: Baseline, Stage I Arm I, Stage I Arm II, Stage II Arm III, Stage II Arm IV, or Stage II Arm VI.

Interventions:

* Baseline: Participants will receive written instructions and a website link to an instructional video, along with supportive materials, including a measuring tape, Aria WiFi-enabled scale, and Actigraph accelerometer.
* Stage I Arm I: Participants will participate in the online ¡Vida! program, which includes 26 health education online sessions, dietary modifications, and home-based exercise sessions.
* Stage I Arm II: Participants will participate in the online ¡Vida! program and attend remote lifestyle health education sessions.
* Stage II Arms III-VI: Participants will receive interventions similar to those in Stage I Arms I and II, with additional components such as individualized telephone health coaching sessions and a bag of groceries each month.

Primary Outcome Measure: Body weight (kg) percent change at month 12.

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Body weight (kg) percent change as moderated by baseline characteristics.

Eligibility Criteria:

* Biologically female
* Age ≥ 18 years
* Self-identifies as Hispanic/Latina
* Previously diagnosed with stage I-III breast cancer within the past 5 years
* No evidence of recurrent or metastatic disease > 60 days post-treatment
* Body mass index (BMI) ≥ 30 kg/m²
* Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status score of 0 or 1
* Willingness to participate in all study activities
* Access to phone, internet, and smartphone, tablet, or computer
* Lives within grocery delivery range for online delivery service

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of remotely delivered, culturally tailored weight loss interventions among Latina breast cancer survivors and to identify the most effective components of these interventions.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

**Study Overview**

The study aims to investigate the relationship between cerebral perfusion, blood pressure changes, and brain function under general anesthesia. The study will measure non-invasively the variations of cerebral perfusion in patients with or without cardiovascular risk factors during controlled blood pressure changes.

**Objectives**

The primary objective is to identify a significant linear relationship between the percentage change in mean velocity (Vm) and the percentage change in the 95% spectral frequency front (SEF95) during mean arterial pressure (MAP) changes. The secondary objective is to evaluate the relationship between Vm and EEG markers such as alpha band power, time spent in burst-suppression, and delta-to-alpha ratio.

**Methods**

The study will enroll 100 patients undergoing scheduled surgery under general anesthesia at Lariboisière Hospital. Patients will be monitored with transcranial Doppler, frontal EEG, and cerebral oximetry. Blood pressure will be controlled to achieve a MAP target of 90% to 70% of the baseline value, without ever falling below 60 mmHg for patients without cardiovascular risk factors and 80 mmHg for patients with cardiovascular risk factors.

**Outcomes**

The primary outcome measures include mean arterial pressure, cerebral blood velocity in the middle cerebral artery, burst suppression, 95% spectral frequency front, and delivered doses of hypnotics, morphine, and paralytic agents. The secondary outcome measures include cerebral O2 saturation.

**Conclusion**

This study aims to investigate the relationship between cerebral perfusion, blood pressure changes, and brain function under general anesthesia, with the goal of identifying a significant linear relationship between Vm and SEF95 during MAP changes.

The "Pain Rating Challenges and Patterns" study aims to improve pain communication between patients and healthcare nurses. The study explores patients' and nurses' mental effort when choosing or understanding pain intensity ratings, and their confidence in the accuracy of these ratings. The study consists of five aims:

Aim 1 compares the mental effort of using different pain intensity rating scales, with a focus on the worst pain you have ever felt scale, 7-day recall period, and focus on one body area.

Aim 2 compares patients' and nurses' perceptions of mental effort when choosing or understanding pain intensity ratings.

Aim 3 examines the relationship between perceptions of mental effort and the importance of decreasing mental effort for patients and nurses.

Aim 4 evaluates the equivalence of patients' and nurses' confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity rating patterns.

Aim 5 tests the relationship between confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity rating patterns and the importance of increasing confidence for patients and nurses.

The study includes patients with chronic musculoskeletal pain and healthcare nurses who regularly assess patients' pain. Participants complete a survey to assess mental effort and confidence in pain intensity ratings. **Title:** Playfulness in Online and Face-to-face Interactions, From Adulthood to Aging

**Objective:** To examine the beneficial effects of playful interactions on cognitive, social, and mood outcomes in older adults, comparing online and face-to-face interactions.

**Design:** Randomized controlled trial with a crossover design, involving 80 participants aged 60 and above. Participants will be randomly assigned to four arms: playful interactions in face-to-face or online formats, or active control conditions in face-to-face or online formats.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Healthy cognitive functioning, age above 60, ability to speak Hebrew, and no history of auditory or visual pathology.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Mini-Mental State Examination score above 25, participants who do not follow or understand instructions, and those with auditory or visual pathology.

Primary Outcome Measure: Overall survival rate in the 12th month (12m-OS).

The study aims to investigate the physiological effects of prone versus supine position on lung recruitability in infants and children with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The trial will enroll patients with ARDS who meet specific inclusion criteria and exclude those with contraindications. Patients will be ventilated in a semi-recumbent position with a tidal volume of 6 mL/kg and a plateau pressure less than 30 cmH2O. After neuromuscular paralysis, patients will be ventilated for 30 minutes with a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and then undergo a 4-step decremental PEEP trial. Patients will then be positioned in either the supine or prone position for 1 hour, during which time arterial blood gases will be analyzed, and respiratory mechanics will be assessed. The primary outcome measure is the effect of prone positioning on lung recruitability, measured by the PaO2/FiO2 ratio. Secondary outcomes include differences in gas exchanges, ventilatory ratio, and regional lung volume and strain, as well as safety endpoints such as the number of endotracheal tube displacements and oxygen desaturations.

Title: Implementing Oral (Event-driven and Daily) and Long-acting Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis in Mobile Men in Sub-Saharan Africa

Objective: To assess the effectiveness and implementation of oral TDF-FTC (event-driven and daily) and CAB-LA pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) in mobile men in South Africa and Uganda, with a focus on men who are at high risk of HIV acquisition due to high HIV prevalence in their partners or risky behaviors.

Design: This is a Phase 3b, open-label, hybrid type 2 implementation and effectiveness trial, using a mixed-method, multi-setting, and multi-country randomized controlled trial design.

Interventions:

* Group A: Oral TDF-FTC PrEP (event-driven or daily) for 9 months, followed by choice of TDF-FTC or CAB-LA for an additional 9 months.
* Group B: Long-acting injectable CAB-LA for 9 months, followed by choice of TDF-FTC or CAB-LA for an additional 9 months.

Primary Outcomes:

* Primary user effectiveness outcome: persistent use of PrEP in the randomized period and throughout the full follow-up period.
* Primary implementation outcomes: PrEP adoption (uptake and choice) across different PrEP modalities.

Secondary Outcomes:

* Effective coital coverage of oral daily/on-demand oral TDF-FTC versus CAB-LA.
* Safety, tolerability, and acceptance of all methods.
* Reach of PrEP for mobile men and barriers to and facilitators of uptake.
* Patterns of use of daily, on-demand, and long-acting PrEP amongst different groups of mobile men.

Eligibility Criteria:

* Male participants aged 18 years and above.
* Willing to provide informed consent.
* Available for follow-up for the duration of the study.
* Exclusion criteria include known HIV infection, confirmed HIV-positive test result, and other medical or social conditions that may interfere with the conduct of the study or safety of the participant.

This study aims to provide evidence on the effectiveness and implementation of different PrEP modalities in mobile men in sub-Saharan Africa, with the goal of informing PrEP guidelines and improving HIV prevention in this population.

**Study Title:** Non-myeloablative Haploidentical HCT Study for Patients With Sickle Cell Disease, Including Compromised Organ Function

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and efficacy of a non-myeloablative haploidentical hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) regimen in patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) who have compromised organ function.

**Intervention:** Patients will receive a non-myeloablative haploidentical peripheral blood stem cell transplantation with briquilimab and abatacept added to the NIH-established regimen of alemtuzumab-TBI-sirolimus and infusion of filgrastim-mobilized peripheral blood hematopoietic cells from haploidentical related donors.

* Secondary endpoints: Event-free survival, overall survival, incidence of viral reactivation and disease, autoimmune and hyperinflammatory complications, and graft failure.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients with SCD who have compromised organ function, including stroke, silent cerebral infarct, sickle cell-related renal insufficiency, tricuspid regurgitant jet velocity, sickle hepatopathy, or other complications.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with available HLA-matched sibling donor, ECOG performance status of 3 or more, DLCO <35% predicted, baseline oxygen saturation of <85% or PaO2 <70 mmHg, or other exclusion criteria.

**Study Population:** Patients with SCD who have compromised organ function, aged 4-100 years, with a haploidentical relative donor available.

Title: Dalpiciclib With Endocrine Therapy for Advanced Breast Cancer After CDK4/6 Inhibitor Failure (DAWNA-FES)

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy of combining Dalpiciclib with physician-selected endocrine therapy in patients with HR-positive and HER2-negative recurrent or metastatic breast cancer who have failed treatment with CDK4/6 inhibitors.

Design: Open-label, randomized, parallel assignment study with two arms: Experimental (Dalpiciclib with endocrine therapy) and Active Comparator (chemotherapy selected by the physician).

Eligibility Criteria: Patients with HR-positive and HER2-negative breast cancer who have failed treatment with CDK4/6 inhibitors, have at least one measurable lesion, and have an ECOG performance status score of 0-2.

Interventions: Experimental arm: Dalpiciclib 150mg daily for 3 weeks followed by 1 week off, combined with physician-selected endocrine therapy (Letrozole, Anastrozole, Exemestane, Fulvestrant, or Tamoxifen). Active Comparator arm: Chemotherapy selected by the physician.

Primary Outcome Measure: Investigator-assessed progression-free survival (PFS).

Secondary Outcome Measures: Objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and overall survival (OS).

This study aims to investigate the effectiveness of combining Dalpiciclib with endocrine therapy in patients with HR-positive and HER2-negative breast cancer who have failed treatment with CDK4/6 inhibitors.

Title: XELOX Combined With Fruquintinib and Sintilimab Regimen Conversion Therapy for Gastric Cancer/Gastroesophageal Junction Adenocarcinoma with Liver and/or Retroperitoneal Lymph Node Metastasis

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of XELOX combined with Fruquintinib and Sintilimab in patients with gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients aged 18-75 years with histopathologically confirmed gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma, HER2-negative or unknown, with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis, and no prior treatment with VEGFR-targeted drugs and PD-1/PD-L1 monoclonal antibodies.

Primary Outcome Measure: Progression-free survival (PFS) from randomization to disease progression or death from any cause.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), duration of response (DOR), and translational rate. Adverse events will also be recorded.

Study Design: Prospective, single-arm, multicenter study with open-label design.

Patient Population: Patients with gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis.

Title: Incentives for Physical Activity for Older Adults

Objective: To evaluate the impact of alternative incentives (prosocial and personal) on step count and physical and mental health of older adults.

Design: Randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 200 participants aged 55 and above. Participants will be randomized into two groups: treatment group receiving incentives (meal donations and monetary incentives) and control group without incentives. The study will track step count using Fitbits and Fitabase software for 8 weeks.

Incentives:

* Treatment group: earns meal donations and monetary incentives for each day they reach 7,500 steps (up to 5 days a week).
* Control group: does not receive incentives and only wears Fitbit to collect step count data.

Outcome measures:

* Primary outcome: change in step count from baseline to week 8.
* Secondary outcomes: change in CES-D (Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale) score from baseline to week 8.

Eligibility criteria:

* Age: 55 and above
* Own a smartphone
* Can walk independently
* Never or seldom walk outside for fun or exercise in the past week.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of alternative incentives in promoting physical activity among older adults and improving their physical and mental health.

Title: A Study to Evaluate Pre- or Post-operative HYPOfractionated Radiation Therapy in Aged (≥ 70 Years Old) or Fragile (≥ 65 Years) Patients With Limb or Trunk Soft Tissue Sarcoma.

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of pre- or post-operative hypofractionated radiation therapy in patients with limb or trunk soft tissue sarcoma who are aged ≥ 70 years or fragile (≥ 65 years).

Design: This is a Phase II, non-randomized, open-label study with two arms: neo-adjuvant and adjuvant cohorts.

Eligibility: Patients with histologically confirmed soft tissue sarcoma of the limbs or trunk, aged ≥ 70 years with a performance status ECOG ≤ 2 and/or aged 65-70 years with an ECOG of 2 and identified as fragile, and affiliated with a Social Health Insurance in France.

Interventions: Patients will receive either pre-operative hypofractionated radiation therapy (30 Gy in 5 fractions) followed by surgery or surgery followed by post-operative hypofractionated radiation therapy (40 Gy in 15 fractions).

Primary Outcome Measure: The rate of patients free of major surgical complications within 6 months of surgery.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Disease-free survival, surgical complications, wound disorders, healing time, quality of life, patient autonomy, geriatric parameters, and toxicities of radiation therapy.

Follow-up: Patients will be followed for 3 years, with assessments at 6 months, 1 year, and every 6 months thereafter.

**Title:** Workplace Intervention to Reduce Sitting Time: a Randomized Clinical Trial

**Objective:** To determine the effect of the Stand up for your Health computer app on sitting time, musculoskeletal symptoms, cardiometabolic markers, and physical activity in office workers.

**Design:** A 2-arm randomized controlled trial with a 6-month follow-up period. Participants will be recruited from educational establishments and will be measured at baseline, 3rd, and 6th months.

**Intervention:** The experimental group will receive the Stand up for your Health computer app and educational information, while the control group will only receive educational information.

**Outcomes:** Primary outcomes include sedentary behavior (occupational sitting time), cardiometabolic biomarkers (fasting blood glucose, insulin, cortisol, triglycerides, total cholesterol, LDL, and HDL cholesterol), and musculoskeletal symptoms (pain and symptoms). Secondary outcomes include anthropometric measurements (height, weight, waist circumference, and body mass index).

**Inclusion Criteria:** Office workers over 18 years of age, full-time employees (≥35 hours per week), who spend most of their workday sitting (>60%), and are able to walk without assistance.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Pregnant women, desktop workers using a height-adjustable workstation, and office workers who are sufficiently active according to WHO criteria.

**Masking:** Single-blinded, with participants unaware of their group assignment.

Title: Artificial Intelligence for Preventing Heart Disease (AiPHD): Observational, Single Center, Prospective and Retrospective Study

Objective: To develop an AI-based model for coronary artery disease (CAD) risk stratification and identify patients at high risk of disease progression, with the aim of improving patient outcomes.

Methodology: This observational, single-center study will include a retrospective cohort of 2500 patients who underwent coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA) for CAD evaluation, and a prospective cohort of 500 patients undergoing cCTA for CAD evaluation. The primary outcome measure is a composite outcome of death by cardiovascular events or non-fatal myocardial infarction, and the secondary outcome measure is a composite outcome of all-cause mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, hospitalization due to angina or angina-like symptoms, and late coronary revascularization.

The study aims to integrate multiple prognostic factors, including coronary artery plaque features, atherosclerotic burden, pericoronary adipose tissue attenuation, and coronary artery topology, using AI-based analysis to select the most important determinants of CAD progression and create a clinically valuable risk stratification model. The study also aims to develop a novel imaging marker of CAD with unfavorable outcome based on topological features of the coronary artery tree.

The study will be conducted at a single center and will enroll patients aged 18 years or older with a diagnosis of CAD. The study duration is 54 months, with a total follow-up period of 36 months for the prospective cohort.

Title: Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Different Doses of Edaravone Dexborneol Concentrated Solution for Injection Combined With Conventional Medical Therapy in the Treatment of Patients With Cerebral Hemorrhage

Objective: To evaluate the safety and tolerability of different doses of Edaravone Dexborneol concentrate for injection combined with conventional medical therapy in patients with cerebral hemorrhage.

Population: Patients with cerebral hemorrhage, aged 18-80 years, with a clinical diagnosis of cerebral hemorrhage, and a hematoma volume ≤ 30 ml at the bleeding site.

Intervention: Edaravone Dexborneol concentrate for injection (37.5 mg, 62.5 mg, or placebo) combined with conventional medical therapy.

Primary outcome measures: Incidence of serious adverse events (SAEs) up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment.

Duration: Up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment.

**Title:** Manzhi Guben Granules Improve Novel Coronavirus Infection (COVID-19) Efficacy and Safety of Convalescent Exercise Tolerance -- A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Clinical Study

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Manzhi Guben granules in improving exercise tolerance and promoting body rehabilitation in patients with novel coronavirus infection (COVID-19).

**Study Design:** A multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical study with two arms: experimental (Manzi Guben granules) and placebo comparator.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients with COVID-19 who have entered the convalescent phase, aged 50-80 years, with symptoms of fatigue, shortness of breath, and cough, and a 6-minute walking test result less than 80% of the predicted value.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Severe and critically ill hospitalized patients, patients with tumor, immune deficiency disease, or other primary diseases, and patients with a life expectancy of less than 12 weeks due to underlying diseases.

**Intervention:** Patients in the experimental arm will receive Manzi Guben granules for 1-4 weeks, while patients in the placebo comparator arm will receive a placebo.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Results of the 6-minute walking test on day 14 after treatment.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Results of the 6-minute walking test on day 28 after treatment, and pulmonary ventilation function on days 14 and 28 after treatment.

**Study Duration:** The study will last for approximately 4 weeks.

This study aims to provide reliable evidence for the treatment and improvement of COVID-19 with Manzhi Guben granules and promote patients' recovery.

The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial aimed at enhancing adherence to adjuvant endocrine therapy (AET) among breast cancer survivors. The trial is a cluster-randomized design, where 66 pharmacies in Quebec, Canada are randomly assigned to either a control group or an intervention group. The intervention group receives the PACHA program, which includes a web-based training for pharmacists, standardized consultation guides, and evidence-based web sheets for women. The program aims to improve pharmacists' knowledge and skills in providing AET consultations, and women's understanding and management of AET side effects.

The primary outcome measures include changes in intention to adhere to AET, AET knowledge, attitude towards AET, perceived social support, perceived behavioral control, anticipated regret, coping planning, fear of recurrence, and side effects. Secondary outcomes include proportion of days covered by AET, proportion of women having AET, quality of life, and program acceptability and feasibility.

The study will recruit approximately 132 women and 66 pharmacists over a period of 6 months. The results will be used to optimize the PACHA program and design a large-scale randomized controlled trial if the results are promising.

Title: Efficacy, Safety, and Tolerability of Higher Doses Estrogen Therapy in Women With Premature Ovarian Insufficiency

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of higher doses of estrogen therapy in women with premature ovarian insufficiency (POI).

Population: Women with POI, diagnosed before the age of 40, who are taking standard-dose estradiol hormone replacement therapy (HRT).

The Symbiont-Restore Study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial aimed at investigating the immunological effects of a synbiotic supplement containing Limosilactobacillus reuteri PB-W1™ and a prebiotic blend in adults with a body mass index (BMI) of 30-40 kg/m². The study will compare the effects of the synbiotic, probiotic, prebiotic, and placebo on markers of immune health, host metabolome, and gut microbiome.

The trial will enroll 120 participants, aged 21-45 years, who will be randomly assigned to one of four arms: probiotic, prebiotic, synbiotic, or placebo. Participants will consume the assigned supplement for eight weeks, and their immune profile, faecal microbiome composition, metabolic profile, satiety rating, and gastrointestinal tolerance to dietary fibre will be assessed at baseline and at the end of the intervention period.

The primary outcome measure is the change in immune profile at eight weeks, while secondary outcome measures include changes in faecal microbiome composition and diversity, metabolic profile, satiety rating, and gastrointestinal tolerance to dietary fibre. The study aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the immunological effects of the synbiotic supplement and its potential benefits for immune health and gut microbiome modulation.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the role of oxidative stress and mitochondrial telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) in the progression and therapeutic resistance of papillary thyroid cancer. The study will enroll patients with papillary thyroid cancer and collect tumor and healthy tissue samples for analysis. The primary outcome measures include H2O2 generation in tumor and normal tissues, TERT mitochondrial localization in tumors, and the effect of exogenous oxidative stress and therapeutic agents on TERT nuclear to mitochondrial translocation in thyroid cancer cell lines. Secondary outcome measures include genetic characterization of tumor tissues, expression profile of tumor tissues, and the effects of Src kinase inhibitors on cell proliferation, apoptosis, and migration. The study will run for approximately 36 months, with multiple time points for data collection.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

**Title:** Cooling in Mild Encephalopathy Versus Targeted Normothermia (COMET) Trial

**Objective:** To compare the effectiveness of whole-body hypothermia (33.5°C) versus targeted normothermia (36.5°C) in reducing the risk of adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes in babies with mild hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (HIE) born at or after 36 weeks of gestation.

**Design:** A phase III, prospective, multi-centre, open-label, randomized controlled trial with an internal pilot and masked outcome assessments.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Babies born at or after 36 weeks of gestation with birth acidosis or requiring resuscitation at birth, with evidence of mild HIE, and normal amplitude on aEEG.

**Interventions:** Whole-body hypothermia (33.5°C) for 72 hours followed by rewarming, or targeted normothermia (36.5°C) for 80 hours.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Mean Cognitive Composite Scale score from the Bayley IV examination at 22-26 months.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Neonatal seizures, duration of intensive care, hospital stay, mechanical ventilation, inotropic support, bloodstream or cerebrospinal fluid positive infection, thrombocytopenia or coagulopathy requiring transfusion of blood products, opioid use, number of babies exclusively breastfeeding at hospital discharge, brain injury scores on conventional magnetic resonance imaging, survival without any neurological impairment, and Preschool Child Behaviour Checklist (CBCL 1½-5) scores.

**Follow-up:** Conventional MRI at discharge, and follow-up assessment at 24 months, including Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development IV, detailed neurological examination, and vision and hearing assessment.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

**Study Title:** A First-In-Human, Phase I/IIa Trial of the Novel T Cell Immunotherapy pTTL in Patients With Advanced Colorectal Cancer

**Objective:** To investigate the safety and tolerability of pTTL, an immunotherapy consisting of autologous T cells activated and expanded in vitro using tumour-specific personalised neoantigens, in patients with advanced colorectal cancer (CRC).

**Design:** Open-label, non-randomised, single-group assignment trial with a dose-escalation design.

**Population:** Adults with stage IV CRC who have received standard of care therapies or are not eligible for further standard of care treatment.

**Intervention:** pTTL, an autologous cell product for adoptive cancer immunotherapy containing in vitro expanded T cells stimulated with patient-specific tumour neoantigens derived from tumour-draining lymph nodes.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Safety of pTTL administration, assessed by incidence and severity of adverse events, including immunological adverse events and adverse events known to be associated with T cell therapies.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Objective response, time to treatment response, duration of treatment response, time to tumour progression, kinetics of tumour progression/growth, overall survival, progression-free survival, and disease-specific survival.

**Duration:** Up to 5 years after pTTL administration.

**Keywords:** Immunotherapy, Adoptive cell therapy, T cell therapy, Neoantigens, Autologous cell therapy.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: The Diagnostic and Prognostic Role of SAA in Intrathoracic Sarcoidosis

This study aims to investigate the diagnostic and prognostic value of serum amyloid A (SAA) in patients with intrathoracic sarcoidosis. The study includes 150 patients with newly diagnosed intrathoracic sarcoidosis and 150 healthy controls. The primary outcome measures include the correlation of SAA levels with:

1. Clinical staging of sarcoidosis
2. Biomarkers of granulomatous inflammation and pulmonary interstitial disease
3. Pulmonary function test results
4. Radiologic extent of disease
5. Changes in lung function tests and HRCT disease extent after 3 years of follow-up
6. Need for recent/ongoing therapy after 3 years of follow-up

The study aims to determine whether SAA levels can be used as a diagnostic and prognostic tool for patients with intrathoracic sarcoidosis.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Benefit of Early Intrauterine Transfer of Blank Culture Medium Prior to Transfer of a Thawed Embryo From 1st in Vitro Fertilization

Objective: To investigate the effect of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium prior to transfer of a thawed embryo from the first in vitro fertilization (IVF) attempt on clinical outcomes.

Design: Randomized, single-blind, multicenter controlled trial with two arms: experimental (with blank culture) and sham comparator (without blank culture).

Eligibility: Women who have had a first fresh or frozen IVF attempt with failed pregnancy and have at least two eligible embryos for transfer or freezing.

Intervention: In the experimental arm, a maximum of 0.1 ml of gassed embryo culture medium is injected into the uterine cavity two to three days before transfer of the thawed embryo. In the sham comparator arm, an empty catheter is inserted into the uterine cavity at the same time.

Primary outcome measure: Clinically progressive pregnancy rate between groups, measured at 12 weeks of amenorrhea.

Secondary outcome measures: Occurrence of pregnancy, biochemical pregnancy, clinical pregnancy, early miscarriage, live birth, differential cost-result ratio, and total estimated expenditure for the two care strategies.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium prior to transfer of a thawed embryo from the first IVF attempt.

This multicenter, observational cohort study aims to construct a database of prognostic risk factors and quality of life in patients with primary solid malignant cancers receiving immunotherapy for the first time. The study will collect baseline information before treatment, including demographic characteristics, tumor and anti-tumor information, and questionnaire evaluation information, as well as follow-up information after treatment. The primary outcome measures include disease-free progression survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS), while secondary outcomes include scoring results from various questionnaires. The study aims to identify risk factors affecting treatment efficacy and prognosis, and to provide high-level evidence-based medical evidence for the selection of immunotherapy schemes and the prevention and management of adverse reactions. The study will enroll patients with solid malignant tumors who are receiving immunotherapy for the first time, with no prior history of other malignant tumors or immunotherapy, and who are willing to participate in the study and attend follow-up visits.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

**Title:** The Effect of Acupressure Applied in the Late Postpartum Period After Cesarean Section on Back Pain

**Objective:** To examine the effect of acupressure on back pain in postpartum women who have had a cesarean section.

**Design:** Randomized controlled experimental study with two groups: Acupressure group and Control group.

**Population:** Women aged 18-49 years who have had a cesarean section, are experiencing back pain, and are in the late postpartum period (1st week and 4th week).

**Intervention:** Acupressure application to specific points on the body (LI4, HT2, LI11, ST36, GB21, and UB43) for 12 minutes, once a week, for two weeks.

**Outcome Measures:** Primary outcome measure: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for assessing back pain at the end of the first week and fourth week after birth. Secondary outcome measure: VAS for assessing back pain at the end of the first month after birth.

**Sample Size:** 70 participants (35 in each group).

**Inclusion Criteria:** Women who meet the above criteria and have a VAS score above 4 for back pain.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Women with a history of mental illness, taking antidepressants or anxiolytic drugs, with comorbid diseases, and those who have had a vaginal delivery or are taking painkillers.

**Study Duration:** Two weeks, with follow-up assessments at the end of the first week, fourth week, and first month after birth.

This clinical trial, "Confidential Social Network Referrals for HIV Testing," aims to evaluate the effectiveness of two referral methods for HIV testing among individuals in Moshi, Tanzania. The study will randomly assign participants to either an experimental arm, where they will receive both SMS-based confidential social network referrals (CONSORT referrals) and physical invitation cards (card referrals), or a control arm, where they will only receive physical invitation cards (card referrals). The primary outcome measure is the uptake of HIV testing among referred clients, with the goal of identifying the most effective referral method for increasing HIV testing rates.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Effects of Paroxetine on Cardiovascular Function in Septic Patients

Objective: To evaluate the effect of paroxetine on cardiovascular function in patients with septic shock.

Design: Randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind trial.

Eligibility: Patients over 18 years old with septic shock, using a minimum dose of noradrenaline, and providing informed consent.

Interventions: Participants received either paroxetine (40mg/day for 5 consecutive days or 24 hours after shock resolution) or placebo.

Primary Outcome Measure: Time to vasopressor discontinuation (discontinuation of all vasopressors for at least 48 consecutive hours).

Secondary Outcome Measures: Cumulative vasopressor dose in the first 48 hours after randomization, variation in cardiovascular sequential organ failure assessment score, cumulative vasopressor dose for 120 hours after randomization, total sequential organ failure assessment score variation, length of stay in the ICU, and mortality during ICU stay.

The study aimed to assess the effect of paroxetine on cardiovascular function in septic patients, with a focus on vasopressor discontinuation and organ dysfunction.
